Rapport SANTANDER

Idx Question Instructions Answer Solution LLM (GPT4o) Answer Solution PyPDF Answer Solution Azure
E1-4

Quel est le plan de transition pour l'atténuation du changement climatique ? Pour répondre à cette question, nous souhaitons avoir une description brève des principaux leviers de décarbonation, du plan d'investissement et de financement du plan de transition, et de la comptabilité avec un scénario 1,5°C ou 2°C.

Parmi les informations que nous recherchons, nous pouvons lister les éléments suivants :

Plan de transition est aligné avec un scénario 1,5°C.

Leviers de décarbonation programmés.

Plan d'investissement et de financement des leviers de décarbonation.

Alignement de la stratégie et le plan de financement.

Suivi des progrès.

Je suis désolé, mais les informations spécifiques concernant les principaux leviers de décarbonation, le plan d'investissement et de financement du plan de transition, ainsi que la comptabilité avec un scénario 1,5°C ou 2°C ne sont pas disponibles dans les documents fournis. Les contextes mentionnent des éléments comme l'évaluation des trajectoires d'émissions des clients, l'intégration de l'ESG dans la gestion des risques, et les efforts pour aligner les activités avec les objectifs de l'Accord de Paris, mais pour des détails précis sur le plan de transition, il faudrait consulter le rapport annuel complet de l'entreprise ou d'autres documents pertinents.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • The first step involves assessing how our customers' emissions trajectory aligns with our current sectoral portfolio baseline and future sectoral portfolio targets. The second step assesses the quality of each customer's transition plan. Our transition plan assessment methodology focuses on four pillars: 1. Targets: it focuses on the quality and ambition of the customer's quantitative GHG emissions targets. Where possible, we assess short- and long-term, as well as absolute and intensity reduction targets. 2. Action plan: it considers the credibility of the customer's alignment strategy. We assess the business strategy integration of climate change risks and opportunities; the existence of climate scenario planning; as well as time-bound action plans to achieve alignment targets. The first step involves assessing how our customers' emissions trajectory aligns with our current sectoral portfolio baseline and future sectoral portfolio targets. The second step assesses the quality of each customer's transition plan. Our transition plan assessment methodology focuses on four pillars: 1. Targets: it focuses on the quality and ambition of the customer's quantitative GHG emissions targets. Where possible, we assess short- and long-term, as well as absolute and intensity reduction targets. 2. Action plan: it considers the credibility of the customer's alignment strategy. We assess the business strategy integration of climate change risks and opportunities; the existence of climate scenario planning; as well as time-bound action plans to achieve alignment targets.
  • ### Transition finance and just transition The regulatory framework must support growth, which is key to a stable and orderly transition. We want to help achieve sustainable development and pledge to play an active role in supporting the green transition. It is vital that the transition is just and inclusive, taking into account regional and sector specificities to avoid isolating communities and stranding assets. ### Transition finance and just transition The regulatory framework must support growth, which is key to a stable and orderly transition. We want to help achieve sustainable development and pledge to play an active role in supporting the green transition. It is vital that the transition is just and inclusive, taking into account regional and sector specificities to avoid isolating communities and stranding assets.
  • 3. Disclosure: it focuses on the transparency of reporting on historical emissions performance across all relevant scopes, the level of assurance, as well as the degree of reporting alignment with the TCFD. Where possible, it also includes assessing whether or not previous GHG emission targets were achieved. 4. Governance: it considers the level of management oversight and governance of the customer's transition strategy. We assess the level of seniority of executives accountable for climate strategy, board committee oversight of climate change issues, and whether executive remuneration is linked to climate change performance. We draw on established transition plan assessment methodologies, such as the Transition Pathway Initiative (TPI), CDP, ACT (Assessing Low Carbon Transition), TCFD, as well as other related initiatives including the UK's Transition Plan Taskforce (TPT). 3. Disclosure: it focuses on the transparency of reporting on historical emissions performance across all relevant scopes, the level of assurance, as well as the degree of reporting alignment with the TCFD. Where possible, it also includes assessing whether or not previous GHG emission targets were achieved. 4. Governance: it considers the level of management oversight and governance of the customer's transition strategy. We assess the level of seniority of executives accountable for climate strategy, board committee oversight of climate change issues, and whether executive remuneration is linked to climate change performance. We draw on established transition plan assessment methodologies, such as the Transition Pathway Initiative (TPI), CDP, ACT (Assessing Low Carbon Transition), TCFD, as well as other related initiatives including the UK's Transition Plan Taskforce (TPT).
  • Our approach aims to facilitate the achievement of our emissions targets and to develop a strong understanding of our customers' transition strategies towards low-carbon business models. This approach is supported by governance processes, involving various internal stakeholders, such as front office teams, risk reporting functions, and senior management to guide the potential portfolio steering actions (for more details, see the Portfolio Steering section below). It is structured around four main iterative steps: Collect, Assess, Engage and Review. We have used various internationally recognized references and the Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership (CISL) 'Let's Discuss Climate' guide as inputs and adapted them to our requirements and objectives. Our approach aims to facilitate the achievement of our emissions targets and to develop a strong understanding of our customers' transition strategies towards low-carbon business models. This approach is supported by governance processes, involving various internal stakeholders, such as front office teams, risk reporting functions, and senior management to guide the potential portfolio steering actions (for more details, see the Portfolio Steering section below). It is structured around four main iterative steps: Collect, Assess, Engage and Review. We have used various internationally recognized references and the Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership (CISL) 'Let's Discuss Climate' guide as inputs and adapted them to our requirements and objectives.
  • ## Risk management and compliance ### 2.1.2 Our ambition We continue working towards our ambition of net zero carbon emissions by 2050 by progressively setting specific actions to make headway with our three-pillar strategy. Incentive policies and frameworks are key to driving the energy transition. The challenge goes beyond increasing the flow of capital from the regulated financial sector to funding the energy transition. We need to scale transition activity and the demand for solutions, which will require better risk-profitability profiles. Achieving climate objectives depends largely on the macroeconomic landscape and public policy. ## Risk management and compliance ### 2.1.2 Our ambition We continue working towards our ambition of net zero carbon emissions by 2050 by progressively setting specific actions to make headway with our three-pillar strategy. Incentive policies and frameworks are key to driving the energy transition. The challenge goes beyond increasing the flow of capital from the regulated financial sector to funding the energy transition. We need to scale transition activity and the demand for solutions, which will require better risk-profitability profiles. Achieving climate objectives depends largely on the macroeconomic landscape and public policy.
  • ### 2.1.1 Our approach Santander considers climate a material topic, having identified impacts, risks and opportunities in the double materiality assessment. Per legal requirements, below we disclose our transition plan, based on three pillars. The purpose of each pillar is to support our customers and the communities we serve in their transition objectives; assess our customers' climate-related risks to manage the impact on their business and on our operations; and make progress with the alignment of our portfolios: 1 Supporting our customers in their transition goals ### 2.1.1 Our approach Santander considers climate a material topic, having identified impacts, risks and opportunities in the double materiality assessment. Per legal requirements, below we disclose our transition plan, based on three pillars. The purpose of each pillar is to support our customers and the communities we serve in their transition objectives; assess our customers' climate-related risks to manage the impact on their business and on our operations; and make progress with the alignment of our portfolios: 1 Supporting our customers in their transition goals
  • ## Risk management and compliance E1-2 - Policies related to climate change mitigation and adaptation 2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) ## Risk management and compliance E1-2 - Policies related to climate change mitigation and adaptation 2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)
  • ### 2.5.1 Strategy for engagement with other key stakeholders As mentioned previously, we believe that the banks are enablers of the transition and as such, should not be considered as the sole drivers of this process. In order for banks to support the transition of their clients, the enabling conditions must be in place. Our aim is to contribute constructively to the transition debate by supporting policymakers and regulators take a common approach to legislation. In this sense, it is now necessary that the predominant regulatory and "finance-centric" approach to the net zero transition that has been adopted to date is reconsidered, acknowledging that the financial sector is an enabler, but that it cannot be the sole driver of sectors' investments towards a low carbon transition. ### 2.5.1 Strategy for engagement with other key stakeholders As mentioned previously, we believe that the banks are enablers of the transition and as such, should not be considered as the sole drivers of this process. In order for banks to support the transition of their clients, the enabling conditions must be in place. Our aim is to contribute constructively to the transition debate by supporting policymakers and regulators take a common approach to legislation. In this sense, it is now necessary that the predominant regulatory and "finance-centric" approach to the net zero transition that has been adopted to date is reconsidered, acknowledging that the financial sector is an enabler, but that it cannot be the sole driver of sectors' investments towards a low carbon transition.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" La tabla detalla la información no financiera que debe divulgarse, organizada en tres columnas: "Non-financial information to be disclosed", "Chapter/section of the annual report" y "Correspondence with CSRD/other regulations". Los temas abordados incluyen: 1. **Efectos ambientales y riesgos**: Información sobre los efectos actuales y previsibles de las actividades de la empresa en el medio ambiente, incluyendo riesgos ambientales y provisiones, se encuentra en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y corresponde a regulaciones como SBM-3, IRO-1, MDR-A, MDR-M, E1, entre otras. 2. **Contaminación**: Medidas para prevenir, reducir o reparar emisiones de CO2 y otras formas de contaminación están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a MDR-A, E1-3, E1-7. 3. **Economía circular y gestión de residuos**: Acciones como prevención, reciclaje y reutilización de residuos se encuentran en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a E5, IRO-1. 4. **Uso sostenible de recursos**: Incluye el uso de agua y materias primas, con medidas para mejorar la eficiencia, en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135) [Table 2. Environmental footprint]", correspondiendo a E3, E5, IRO-1. 5. **Energía**: Consumo directo e indirecto, eficiencia energética y uso de energías renovables están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-A, MDR-M, E1-3, E1-5. 6. **Cambio climático**: Emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, medidas de adaptación y objetivos de reducción están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-M, E1-6, MDR-T, E1-4. 7. **Biodiversidad**: Medidas para preservar o restaurar la biodiversidad están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.3.5 Our approach to nature and biodiversity]" y corresponden a E4, IRO-1. and

    0 1 2
    Non-financial information to be disclosed Chapter/section of the annual report Correspondence with CSRD/other regulations

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta estrategias relacionadas con el cambio climático y la integración de ESG en la gestión de riesgos. Los encabezados son: "Strategy", "Section", "Sub-section", "Sub-sub-section" y "Comments". En la fila 1, la estrategia "E1-1 - Transition plan for climate change mitigation" está vinculada a la sección "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) Sustainability notes (p. 107)", con sub-secciones como "2.1 Strategy (p. 32)", "2.2 Supporting our customers in their transition goals (p. 35)", "2.4 Aiming to align our activity with the Paris Agreement Goals (p. 59)", y "2.5 Further actions and enablers (p. 72) SN 4. Our transition plan- (p. 129)". La sub-sub-sección destacada es "2.5.2 Governance & policies". En la fila 2, la estrategia "ESRS 2 SBM-3 - Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with S&BM" está asociada a la sección "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)", con la sub-sección "2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management (p. 40)". Las sub-sub-secciones incluyen "2.3.1 Resilience of our strategy and business model to climate change" y "2.3.2 Risk management cycle". No se proporcionan comentarios adicionales en ninguna de las filas. and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance": La tabla presenta cinco áreas clave relacionadas con la gestión de riesgos y el cumplimiento: 1. **Inclusive Culture**: Avances en la cultura inclusiva y otras iniciativas como la accesibilidad. 2. **Financial inclusion**: Progresos en los objetivos de inclusión financiera y otras iniciativas clave en la agenda social, como la educación financiera y la inversión comunitaria. 3. **Sustainable finance**: Avances en las finanzas sostenibles y la inversión socialmente responsable. 4. **Climate**: Progresos en el plan de transición y los principales mecanismos para cumplir con la ambición de alcanzar emisiones netas cero. 5. **Governance and cross cutting matters**: Realización de la evaluación de doble materialidad, implementación de políticas de sostenibilidad y mejora de la eficiencia y calidad de los datos. and

    Risk management and compliance

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1
    Inclusive Culture Progress with inclusive culture and other initiatives such as accessibility.
    Financial inclusion Progress with financial inclusion targets and other key initiatives in the social agenda (financial education, community investment, etc.).
    Sustainable finance Progress with sustainable finance and socially responsible investment.
    Climate Progress with our transition plan and the key levers to fulfil our net zero ambition.
    Governance and cross cutting matters Conducting our double materiality assessment, implementing sustainability policies, and enhancing data efficiency and quality.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta información sobre "ESRS E2, E3, E4, E5" y está organizada en cinco columnas: "0", "1", "2", "3" y "4". Las etiquetas de las columnas son: "Section", "Sub-section", "Sub-sub-section" y "Comments". En la fila 1, se menciona "ESRS 2 IRO-1 - Description of the processes to identify and assess material climate-related impacts, risks and opportunities". En la columna "Section", se indica "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)". En la columna "Sub-section", se detalla "2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management (p. 40)". En la columna "Sub-sub-section", se especifica "2.3.5 Our approach to nature and biodiversity". La columna "Comments" está vacía. No se mencionan años en el contenido de la tabla. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1 2 3 4
    ESRS E2, E3, E4, E5. Section Sub-section Sub-sub-section Comments
    ESRS 2 IRO-1 - Description of the processes to identify and assess material climate-related impacts, risks and opportunities 2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) 2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management (p. 40) 2.3.5 Our approach to nature and biodiversity

Je ne dispose pas d'informations spécifiques sur le plan de transition pour l'atténuation du changement climatique qui incluent une description détaillée des principaux leviers de décarbonation, du plan d'investissement et de financement, et de la comptabilité avec un scénario 1,5°C ou 2°C. Les documents fournis mentionnent des initiatives générales pour soutenir la transition verte, aligner les activités avec les objectifs de l'Accord de Paris, et intégrer les critères ESG dans la gestion des risques, mais ne fournissent pas de détails précis sur le plan de transition demandé.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • The first step involves assessing how our customers' emissions trajectory aligns with our current sectoral portfolio baseline and future sectoral portfolio targets. The second step assesses the quality of each customer's transition plan. Our transition plan assessment methodology focuses on four pillars: 1. Targets: it focuses on the quality and ambition of the customer's quantitative GHG emissions targets. Where possible, we assess short- and long-term, as well as absolute and intensity reduction targets. 2. Action plan: it considers the credibility of the customer's alignment strategy. We assess the business strategy integration of climate change risks and opportunities; the existence of climate scenario planning; as well as time-bound action plans to achieve alignment targets.
  • ### Transition finance and just transition The regulatory framework must support growth, which is key to a stable and orderly transition. We want to help achieve sustainable development and pledge to play an active role in supporting the green transition. It is vital that the transition is just and inclusive, taking into account regional and sector specificities to avoid isolating communities and stranding assets.
  • 3. Disclosure: it focuses on the transparency of reporting on historical emissions performance across all relevant scopes, the level of assurance, as well as the degree of reporting alignment with the TCFD. Where possible, it also includes assessing whether or not previous GHG emission targets were achieved. 4. Governance: it considers the level of management oversight and governance of the customer's transition strategy. We assess the level of seniority of executives accountable for climate strategy, board committee oversight of climate change issues, and whether executive remuneration is linked to climate change performance. We draw on established transition plan assessment methodologies, such as the Transition Pathway Initiative (TPI), CDP, ACT (Assessing Low Carbon Transition), TCFD, as well as other related initiatives including the UK's Transition Plan Taskforce (TPT).
  • Our approach aims to facilitate the achievement of our emissions targets and to develop a strong understanding of our customers' transition strategies towards low-carbon business models. This approach is supported by governance processes, involving various internal stakeholders, such as front office teams, risk reporting functions, and senior management to guide the potential portfolio steering actions (for more details, see the Portfolio Steering section below). It is structured around four main iterative steps: Collect, Assess, Engage and Review. We have used various internationally recognized references and the Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership (CISL) 'Let's Discuss Climate' guide as inputs and adapted them to our requirements and objectives.
  • ## Risk management and compliance ### 2.1.2 Our ambition We continue working towards our ambition of net zero carbon emissions by 2050 by progressively setting specific actions to make headway with our three-pillar strategy. Incentive policies and frameworks are key to driving the energy transition. The challenge goes beyond increasing the flow of capital from the regulated financial sector to funding the energy transition. We need to scale transition activity and the demand for solutions, which will require better risk-profitability profiles. Achieving climate objectives depends largely on the macroeconomic landscape and public policy.
  • ### 2.1.1 Our approach Santander considers climate a material topic, having identified impacts, risks and opportunities in the double materiality assessment. Per legal requirements, below we disclose our transition plan, based on three pillars. The purpose of each pillar is to support our customers and the communities we serve in their transition objectives; assess our customers' climate-related risks to manage the impact on their business and on our operations; and make progress with the alignment of our portfolios: 1 Supporting our customers in their transition goals
  • ## Risk management and compliance E1-2 - Policies related to climate change mitigation and adaptation 2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)
  • ### 2.5.1 Strategy for engagement with other key stakeholders As mentioned previously, we believe that the banks are enablers of the transition and as such, should not be considered as the sole drivers of this process. In order for banks to support the transition of their clients, the enabling conditions must be in place. Our aim is to contribute constructively to the transition debate by supporting policymakers and regulators take a common approach to legislation. In this sense, it is now necessary that the predominant regulatory and "finance-centric" approach to the net zero transition that has been adopted to date is reconsidered, acknowledging that the financial sector is an enabler, but that it cannot be the sole driver of sectors' investments towards a low carbon transition.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" La tabla detalla la información no financiera que debe divulgarse, organizada en tres columnas: "Non-financial information to be disclosed", "Chapter/section of the annual report" y "Correspondence with CSRD/other regulations". Los temas abordados incluyen: 1. **Efectos ambientales y riesgos**: Información sobre los efectos actuales y previsibles de las actividades de la empresa en el medio ambiente, incluyendo riesgos ambientales y provisiones, se encuentra en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y corresponde a regulaciones como SBM-3, IRO-1, MDR-A, MDR-M, E1, entre otras. 2. **Contaminación**: Medidas para prevenir, reducir o reparar emisiones de CO2 y otras formas de contaminación están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a MDR-A, E1-3, E1-7. 3. **Economía circular y gestión de residuos**: Acciones como prevención, reciclaje y reutilización de residuos se encuentran en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a E5, IRO-1. 4. **Uso sostenible de recursos**: Incluye el uso de agua y materias primas, con medidas para mejorar la eficiencia, en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135) [Table 2. Environmental footprint]", correspondiendo a E3, E5, IRO-1. 5. **Energía**: Consumo directo e indirecto, eficiencia energética y uso de energías renovables están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-A, MDR-M, E1-3, E1-5. 6. **Cambio climático**: Emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, medidas de adaptación y objetivos de reducción están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-M, E1-6, MDR-T, E1-4. 7. **Biodiversidad**: Medidas para preservar o restaurar la biodiversidad están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.3.5 Our approach to nature and biodiversity]" y corresponden a E4, IRO-1.

Los encabezados son: "Strategy", "Section", "Sub-section", "Sub-sub-section" y "Comments". En la fila 1, la estrategia "E1-1 - Transition plan for climate change mitigation" está vinculada a la sección "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) Sustainability notes (p. 107)", con sub-secciones como "2.1 Strategy (p. 32)", "2.2 Supporting our customers in their transition goals (p. 35)", "2.4 Aiming to align our activity with the Paris Agreement Goals (p. 59)", y "2.5 Further actions and enablers (p. 72) SN 4. Our transition plan- (p. 129)". La sub-sub-sección destacada es "2.5.2 Governance & policies". En la fila 2, la estrategia "ESRS 2 SBM-3 - Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with S&BM" está asociada a la sección "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)", con la sub-sección "2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management (p. 40)". Las sub-sub-secciones incluyen "2.3.1 Resilience of our strategy and business model to climate change" y "2.3.2 Risk management cycle". No se proporcionan comentarios adicionales en ninguna de las filas.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance": La tabla presenta cinco áreas clave relacionadas con la gestión de riesgos y el cumplimiento: 1. **Inclusive Culture**: Avances en la cultura inclusiva y otras iniciativas como la accesibilidad. 2. **Financial inclusion**: Progresos en los objetivos de inclusión financiera y otras iniciativas clave en la agenda social, como la educación financiera y la inversión comunitaria. 3. **Sustainable finance**: Avances en las finanzas sostenibles y la inversión socialmente responsable. 4. **Climate**: Progresos en el plan de transición y los principales mecanismos para cumplir con la ambición de alcanzar emisiones netas cero. 5. **Governance and cross cutting matters**: Realización de la evaluación de doble materialidad, implementación de políticas de sostenibilidad y mejora de la eficiencia y calidad de los datos.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta información sobre "ESRS E2, E3, E4, E5" y está organizada en cinco columnas: "0", "1", "2", "3" y "4". Las etiquetas de las columnas son: "Section", "Sub-section", "Sub-sub-section" y "Comments". Je suis désolé, mais les informations spécifiques concernant les principaux leviers de décarbonation, le plan d'investissement et de financement du plan de transition, ainsi que la comptabilité avec un scénario 1,5°C ou 2°C ne sont pas disponibles dans les documents fournis. Les contextes mentionnent des éléments comme l'évaluation des trajectoires d'émissions des clients, l'intégration de l'ESG dans la gestion des risques, et les efforts pour aligner les activités avec les objectifs de l'Accord de Paris, mais pour des détails précis sur le plan de transition, il faudrait consulter le rapport annuel complet de l'entreprise ou d'autres documents pertinents.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • diversification, competitive advantage and revenue; •lower-emission energy sources that benefit from less exposure to Greenhouse Gases (GHG) emissions, lower costs, policy incentives; and •efficient production and distribution of resources to lower operational costs and raise both production capacity and the value of fixed assets. Transition finance and just transition The regulatory framework must support growth, which is key to a stable and orderly transition. We want to help achieve sustainable development and pledge to play an active role in supporting the green transition. It is vital that the transition is just and inclusive, taking into account regional and sector specificities to avoid isolating communities and stranding assets. We aim to embed and promote the just transition through our engagement approach, our risk management policies and processes, and our sustainable and investment products. We consider this approach when devising our policies and reviewing diversification, competitive advantage and revenue; •lower-emission energy sources that benefit from less exposure to Greenhouse Gases (GHG) emissions, lower costs, policy incentives; and •efficient production and distribution of resources to lower operational costs and raise both production capacity and the value of fixed assets. Transition finance and just transition The regulatory framework must support growth, which is key to a stable and orderly transition. We want to help achieve sustainable development and pledge to play an active role in supporting the green transition. It is vital that the transition is just and inclusive, taking into account regional and sector specificities to avoid isolating communities and stranding assets. We aim to embed and promote the just transition through our engagement approach, our risk management policies and processes, and our sustainable and investment products. We consider this approach when devising our policies and reviewing

  • achieve alignment targets. 3.Disclosure: it focuses on the transparency of reporting on historical emissions performance across all relevant scopes, the level of assurance, as well as the degree of reporting alignment with the TCFD. Where possible, it also includes assessing whether or not previous GHG emission targets were achieved. 4.Governance: it considers the level of management oversight and governance of the customer’s transition strategy. We assess the level of seniority of executives accountable for climate strategy, board committee oversight of climate change issues, and whether executive remuneration is linked to climate change performance. We draw on established transition plan assessment methodologies, such as the Transition Pathway Initiative (TPI), CDP, ACT (Assessing Low Carbon Transition), TCFD, as well as other related initiatives including the UK’s Transition Plan Taskforce (TPT).   • to categorize our customers according to their emissions pathway and perceived quality of their transition strategy. The first step involves assessing how our customers’ emissions trajectory aligns with our current sectoral portfolio baseline and future sectoral portfolio targets. The second step assesses the quality of each customer’s transition plan. Our transition plan assessment methodology focuses on four pillars:1.Targets: it focuses on the quality and ambition of the customer’s quantitative GHG emissions targets. Where possible, we assess short- and long-term, as well as absolute and intensity reduction targets. 2.Action plan: it considers the credibility of the customer’s alignment strategy. We assess the business strategy integration of climate change risks and opportunities; the existence of climate scenario planning; as well as time-bound action plans to achieve alignment targets. 3.Disclosure: it focuses on the transparency of reporting on to categorize our customers according to their emissions pathway and perceived quality of their transition strategy.   • make headway with our three-pillar strategy. Incentive policies and frameworks are key to driving the energy transition. The challenge goes beyond increasing the flow ofcapital from the regulated financial sector to funding the energy transition. We need to scale transition activity and the demand for solutions, which will require better risk-profitability profiles. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A.   • sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable. sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable.
  • shares are meant to help the foundation financially; it can use the dividends to cover some (if not all) of the cost of fulfilling its founding purposes.66 These include managing the bank's art collection and financing numerous literary, educational, social, cultural and environmental productions and activities, in which the remodelling of the Santander's headquarters on Paseo de Pereda in Santander and our relations with universities in Spain will play an important role. For more details, visit the website fundacionbancosantander.com/es/ fundacion/transparencia. We have other Santander foundations in countries where we operate (Argentina, the US, Mexico, Portugal, Poland and the UK), which boost the number of initiatives we run. Their focus varies according to local needs; for instance, in Argentina on art and culture; in Portugal on education, inclusion and culture; and in Poland on education for children and young people. For more details, visit the website fundacionbancosantander.com/es/ fundacion/transparencia. We have other Santander foundations in countries where we operate (Argentina, the US, Mexico, Portugal, Poland and the UK), which boost the number of initiatives we run. Their focus varies according to local needs; for instance, in Argentina on art and culture; in Portugal on education, inclusion and culture; and in Poland on education for children and young people. Activities from
E1-5

Les objectifs de réduction fixés sont-ils alignés avec une trajectoire de 1,5°C conformément aux Accords de Paris ? L'entreprise mentionne-t-elle une trajectoire conforme aux objectifs SBTi ? Il convient également de noter que, si l'entreprise affiche des objectifs de neutralité carbone, cette neutralité doit nécessairement être alignée avec les recommandations de l'Accord de Paris.

Pour garantir la compatibilité avec un scénario de transition conforme à l'accord de Paris, l'entreprise doit fournir les informations suivantes :

- Un/des objectif(s) de réduction avec une trajectoire de réchauffement à 1,5°C grâce à une trajectoire de décarbonation sectorielle si disponible, soit grâce à une trajectoire d'émissions transsectorielle compatible avec la limitation de réchauffement de la planète à 1,5°C (cf. AR 26 et 27).

- Les facteurs de réduction des émissions évoluent et ne sont pas fixes encore. Par conséquent, les entreprises sont encouragées à n'utiliser que des informations actualisées et publiquement accessibles. L'EFRAG préconise Pathways to Net-Zero - SBTi Technical Summary). Les cibles de réduction doivent être fixées respectivement à 2030 et 2050, avec des échellons tous les 5 ans.

D'après les informations fournies dans le contexte, l'entreprise a effectivement fixé des objectifs de réduction alignés avec une trajectoire de 1,5°C conformément aux Accords de Paris. Ces objectifs sont en ligne avec le scénario "International Energy Agency - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario" (IEA-NZE), qui vise à atteindre zéro émission nette d'ici 2050, limitant ainsi l'augmentation de température à 1,5°C.

L'entreprise mentionne également qu'elle utilise des objectifs alignés sur les recommandations de l'initiative Science Based Targets (SBTi) pour ses secteurs financés, ce qui renforce l'alignement avec les objectifs de l'Accord de Paris.

Concernant la neutralité carbone, l'entreprise a annoncé son ambition d'atteindre des émissions nettes nulles d'ici 2050, une démarche qui doit nécessairement être alignée avec les recommandations de l'Accord de Paris.

En résumé, l'entreprise montre un engagement à suivre une trajectoire de réduction d'émissions conforme à une limitation du réchauffement à 1,5°C, en s'appuyant sur des scénarios et des objectifs reconnus internationalement, comme ceux proposés par SBTi.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Scenarios:85 To set 2030 science-based alignment targets for our financed sectors, we choose a credible scenario that draws a pathway to reach net zero emissions by 2050 and will limit temperature increase to 1.5 ℃ in line with the Paris Agreement. The scenario we have chosen for the sectors for which we have released alignment targets is the "International Energy Agency - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario" (IEA-NZE). Our aviation target is consistent with the expected adoption of current technologies. This scenario takes into account the technological, regulatory and market changes that need to take place. Regarding our scope 1 and 2 own emission reduction objective by 2030, it is aligned with the cross-sector absolute reduction method considered by SBTi, going beyond the minimum ambition of a linear annual reduction of a 4.2% linear annual reduction between the base year and target year. Scenarios:85 To set 2030 science-based alignment targets for our financed sectors, we choose a credible scenario that draws a pathway to reach net zero emissions by 2050 and will limit temperature increase to 1.5 ℃ in line with the Paris Agreement. The scenario we have chosen for the sectors for which we have released alignment targets is the "International Energy Agency - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario" (IEA-NZE). Our aviation target is consistent with the expected adoption of current technologies. This scenario takes into account the technological, regulatory and market changes that need to take place. Regarding our scope 1 and 2 own emission reduction objective by 2030, it is aligned with the cross-sector absolute reduction method considered by SBTi, going beyond the minimum ambition of a linear annual reduction of a 4.2% linear annual reduction between the base year and target year.
  • Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected. Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected.
  • Regarding our own operations, we disclose our direct and indirect emissions (scopes 1, 2 and 3) data as well as other climate- relevant metrics such as energy consumption. We report on our 17 targets for renewable electricity"and the compensation of our scope 1 and scope 2 emissions. Since 2021, we have also been disclosing financed scope 3 emissions (category 15) related to our alignment objectives. We announced our ambition to work to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050 in February 2021. We are constantly reviewing our strategy and targets to incorporate the latest science insights and changes in local regulation. Regarding our own operations, we disclose our direct and indirect emissions (scopes 1, 2 and 3) data as well as other climate- relevant metrics such as energy consumption. We report on our 17 targets for renewable electricity"and the compensation of our scope 1 and scope 2 emissions. Since 2021, we have also been disclosing financed scope 3 emissions (category 15) related to our alignment objectives. We announced our ambition to work to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050 in February 2021. We are constantly reviewing our strategy and targets to incorporate the latest science insights and changes in local regulation.
  • This maturity scale on the degree of issuers' alignment with net zero emissions targets provides us with a framework to check the progress that issuers are making in their transition and identify areas that require further effort in terms of engagement. It considers these factors: 1. A long-term ambition consistent with the goal of achieving net- zero by 2050. 2. Short- and medium-term targets to reduce GHG emissions. 3. Disclosure of scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions. 4. Emissions performance against targets. 5. Alignment strategy. In 2024, we worked on developing our Net Zero engagement strategy, which aims to use dialogue and voting policies to encourage issuers to commit to alignment plans and transparency and disclose accurate and credible information to be able to monitor performance. It also motivates issuers to set ambitious targets that are consistent with the Paris Agreement goals. This maturity scale on the degree of issuers' alignment with net zero emissions targets provides us with a framework to check the progress that issuers are making in their transition and identify areas that require further effort in terms of engagement. It considers these factors: 1. A long-term ambition consistent with the goal of achieving net- zero by 2050. 2. Short- and medium-term targets to reduce GHG emissions. 3. Disclosure of scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions. 4. Emissions performance against targets. 5. Alignment strategy. In 2024, we worked on developing our Net Zero engagement strategy, which aims to use dialogue and voting policies to encourage issuers to commit to alignment plans and transparency and disclose accurate and credible information to be able to monitor performance. It also motivates issuers to set ambitious targets that are consistent with the Paris Agreement goals.
  • ### Climate tiering aggregated for the sectors for which we had set targetsª Leader Strong Moderate Weak A. Based on 2024 year-end drawn exposure, according to portfolio alignment methodology, and including project finance, both in operation and under construction. Of our corporate customers with drawn exposure where transition plan assessments were conducted in 2024, approximately: . two-thirds have set quantitative emissions reduction targets on sector-material GHG scopes between 2030 and 2039; . one-third have set, or committed to set, science-based targets (SBTi), if available for the sector; . over two-thirds have a time-bound action plan to align their business, with almost half providing details of the expected proportional impact of different alignment levers, according to our assessment; . over half provide details or commitments for CAPEX alignment with future low-carbon solutions; Santander Annual report 2024 62 ### Climate tiering aggregated for the sectors for which we had set targetsª Leader Strong Moderate Weak A. Based on 2024 year-end drawn exposure, according to portfolio alignment methodology, and including project finance, both in operation and under construction. Of our corporate customers with drawn exposure where transition plan assessments were conducted in 2024, approximately: . two-thirds have set quantitative emissions reduction targets on sector-material GHG scopes between 2030 and 2039; . one-third have set, or committed to set, science-based targets (SBTi), if available for the sector; . over two-thirds have a time-bound action plan to align their business, with almost half providing details of the expected proportional impact of different alignment levers, according to our assessment; . over half provide details or commitments for CAPEX alignment with future low-carbon solutions; Santander Annual report 2024 62
  • Target types: To help our customers' transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective. However, due to the absence of a widely accepted "transition finance taxonomy", we consider alignment targets to be an effective tool for informing portfolio decisions, provided that each case is managed individually. For the different targets' design Target types: To help our customers' transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective. However, due to the absence of a widely accepted "transition finance taxonomy", we consider alignment targets to be an effective tool for informing portfolio decisions, provided that each case is managed individually. For the different targets' design
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines alignment targets across various sectors, scenarios, metrics, baselines, years (2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, and 2030 targets), scopes of emissions, and value chains in scope. 1. **Sector**: "S Power generation" follows the "IEA Net Zero 2050" scenario with the metric "tCO2e/MWh" and a baseline of "0.21 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "0.17" in 2020 to "0.15" in 2023, targeting "0.11 (-46%)" by 2030. Scope is "1," covering "Upstream / Generation," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / End product." 2. **Sector**: "B Oil & gas" uses the metric "mtCO2e" with a baseline of "23.84 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions range from "22.58" in 2020 to "20.27" in 2023, targeting "16.98 (-29%)" by 2030. Scope is "1 + 2 + 34," covering "Integrated / Diversified," "Upstream / Extraction," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / Trading." 3. **Sector**: "ET Aviation" uses the metric "gCO2e/RPK" with a baseline of "92.47 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions fluctuate from "93.05" in 2020 to "82.99" in 2023, targeting "61.71 (-33%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Suppliers," "Midstream / Manufacturing," and "Downstream / Airliners." 4. **Sector**: "Steel" uses the metric "tCO2e/ts" with a baseline of "1.58 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "1.40" in 2020 to "1.38" in 2023, targeting "1.07 (-32%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Materials extraction," "Manufacturing," and "Downstream / End product." 5. **Sector**: "Auto manufacturing" uses the metric "gCO2/vkm" with a baseline of "149 (2020 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "149" in 2020 to "134" in 2023, targeting "103 (-31%)" by 2030. Scope is "3A," covering "Upstream / Suppliers-Materials," "Midstream Manufacturing Dealers," and "Downstream / End product." 6. **Sector**: "Auto lending Europe" uses the metric "gCO2e/vkm" with a baseline of "137 (2022 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "137" in 2022 to "133" in 2023, targeting "75-89 (-35-45%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Downstream / End users."   • ### 2.4.1 Alignment targets As part of our climate ambition, we prioritize the high-emitting sectors (which also bear high and very high transition risk according to our climate materiality) to which we have material exposure and must support the transition to a low-carbon economy. In 2021 and 2022 we set targets for the wholesale segment in the power generation, thermal coal, oil & gas, aviation, and steel portfolios. In 2023, we focused on the automotive sector from two perspectives: auto manufacturing (wholesale segment) and auto lending (consumer loans for the purchase of passenger cars in Europe). Within the sectorial climate approach described above, cement, shipping and aluminium are deemed not material given their low level of exposure. Agriculture, mortgages and commercial real estate (CRE) are considered material in the retail segment. ### 2.4.1 Alignment targets As part of our climate ambition, we prioritize the high-emitting sectors (which also bear high and very high transition risk according to our climate materiality) to which we have material exposure and must support the transition to a low-carbon economy. In 2021 and 2022 we set targets for the wholesale segment in the power generation, thermal coal, oil & gas, aviation, and steel portfolios. In 2023, we focused on the automotive sector from two perspectives: auto manufacturing (wholesale segment) and auto lending (consumer loans for the purchase of passenger cars in Europe). Within the sectorial climate approach described above, cement, shipping and aluminium are deemed not material given their low level of exposure. Agriculture, mortgages and commercial real estate (CRE) are considered material in the retail segment.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento, con enfoque en los impactos y oportunidades relacionados con la fuerza laboral (S1 - Own workforce) y los consumidores y usuarios finales (S4 - Consumers and end users). Los años considerados son de corto a mediano plazo. 1. **S1 - Own workforce**: Se identifican impactos positivos como el desarrollo profesional continuo y el bienestar general de los empleados, promoviendo programas de aprendizaje, condiciones laborales justas y remuneración adecuada basada en mérito y tasas de mercado. También se mencionan riesgos negativos como conductas discriminatorias, condiciones laborales inadecuadas, acoso, corrupción y conflictos con empleados debido a fallos éticos o de gestión. 2. **S4 - Consumers and end users**: Se destacan impactos positivos como la inclusión financiera y la salud financiera de los clientes mediante productos y servicios adaptados a sus necesidades, así como la educación y concienciación sobre ciberseguridad para reducir amenazas en línea. Por otro lado, se identifican impactos negativos como la pérdida de confianza si los clientes no tienen acceso a canales de quejas o si estas no son atendidas adecuadamente. Los impactos están vinculados principalmente a las operaciones propias de la organización y se clasifican como específicos o sistémicos. Las estrategias incluyen programas de desarrollo de talento, esquemas de remuneración, campañas interactivas y talleres de concienciación. Las áreas relacionadas son "Our employees" (3.1) y "Our customers" (3.3). and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento, con el enfoque en el impacto negativo y los riesgos relacionados con los consumidores y usuarios finales (S4 - Consumers and end users). Los años considerados son "Short/ medium term". Las columnas incluyen: "ESRS", "IRO description", "IRO type", "Value chain", "Summary of current/ potential effects (narrative)", "People/ environment", "Strategy- and business model-related impacts", "Time horizon 1", "Linked to impact due to own operations or business relations 2", "Systemic/ specific", "Core activities that lead to positive impacts", "Risks and/or opportunities stemming from impacts", y "More details". 1. **Impacto negativo por falta de información**: Si el banco no proporciona suficiente información sobre productos o servicios, puede haber una ruptura de confianza y relaciones a largo plazo con los clientes. Esto afecta la cadena de valor "Downstream" y está vinculado a las relaciones comerciales. Detalles adicionales: "3.3 Our customers - 3.3.1 Customer conduct". 2. **Impacto negativo por infracción de derechos**: La falta de medidas técnicas u organizativas adecuadas para proteger datos personales puede generar una ruptura de confianza. Esto afecta la cadena de valor "Upstream" y está vinculado a las relaciones comerciales. Detalles adicionales: "3.3 Our customers - 3.3.3 Privacy, data protection and cybersecurity". 3. **Impacto negativo por obstáculos en productos/servicios**: La incapacidad de garantizar acceso o uso adecuado de productos y servicios puede generar una ruptura de confianza. Esto afecta las operaciones propias ("Own operations") y está vinculado a las operaciones propias. Detalles adicionales: "3.3 Our customers - 3.3.1 Customer conduct - iv. Vulnerable customers". 4. **Pérdidas potenciales por sanciones o reducción de clientes**: La falta de respuesta efectiva ante brechas de privacidad puede causar daños si los riesgos se materializan. Esto afecta la cadena de valor "Downstream". Detalles adicionales: "3.3 Our customers - 3.3.3 Privacy, data protection and cybersecurity". 5. **Pérdidas potenciales por prácticas subestándar**: Prácticas deficientes con clientes a lo largo de su ciclo de vida pueden causar daños si los riesgos se materializan. Esto afecta la cadena de valor "Downstream". Detalles adicionales: "3.3 Our customers - 3.3.1 Customer conduct". and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla TCFD en el Informe Anual de Santander 2024 La tabla presenta un índice de contenido relacionado con las recomendaciones del "Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosure (TCFD)" y sus referencias en el informe anual. Se organiza en cuatro categorías principales: **Governance**, **Strategy**, **Risk Management**, y **Metrics and Targets**, con subapartados etiquetados como "a", "b" y "c". 1. **Governance**: - **a**: Describe la supervisión del consejo sobre riesgos y oportunidades climáticas. Referencias: "1.4 Sustainability governance; SN 2. Sustainability governance". - **b**: Describe el rol de la gestión en la evaluación y manejo de riesgos y oportunidades climáticas. Referencias: "1.4 Sustainability governance; SN 2. Sustainability governance; 2.5.2 Governance & policies; 2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management". 2. **Strategy**: - **a**: Describe los riesgos y oportunidades climáticas identificados a corto, mediano y largo plazo. - **b**: Describe el impacto de estos riesgos y oportunidades en los negocios, estrategia y planificación financiera. Referencias: "2.1 Strategy; 2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management". - **c**: Describe la resiliencia de la estrategia considerando escenarios climáticos, incluyendo uno de 2℃ o menor. 3. **Risk Management**: - **a**: Describe los procesos de identificación y evaluación de riesgos climáticos. - **b**: Describe los procesos de gestión de riesgos climáticos. Referencias: "2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management". - **c**: Describe cómo estos procesos se integran en la gestión general de riesgos. 4. **Metrics and Targets**: - **a**: Divulga las métricas utilizadas para evaluar riesgos y oportunidades climáticas. Referencias: "2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management; 2.4 Aiming to align our activity with the Paris Agreement Goals". - **b**: Divulga las emisiones de Gases de Efecto Invernadero (GEI) de Alcance 1, 2 y, si corresponde, 3, y los riesgos relacionados. Referencias: "2.4.5 Our environmental footprint; SN 4. Our transition plan; SN 7.1 Green transition". - **c**: Describe los objetivos para gestionar riesgos y oportunidades climáticas y el desempeño frente a estos. Referencias: "2.4.1 Alignment targets; SN 4. Our transition plan". and
