    0 1 2 3
    TCFD Recommendations Reference in this Annual Report
    Governance a Describe the board's oversight of climate-related risks and opportunities. 1.4 Sustainability governance; SN 2. Sustainability governance
    b Describe management's role in assessing and managing climate- related risks and opportunities. 1.4 Sustainability governance; SN 2. Sustainability governance 2.5.2 Governance & policies; 2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management
    Strategy a Describe the climate-related risks and opportunities the organization has identified over the short, medium, and long term.
    b Describe the impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on the organization's businesses, strategy, and financial planning. 2.1 Strategy; 2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management
    c Describe the resilience of the organization's strategy, taking into consideration different climate-related scenarios, including a 2℃ or lower scenario.
    Risk Management a Describe the organization's processes for identifying and assessing climate-related risks.
    b Describe the organization's processes for managing climate- related risks. 2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management
    c Describe how processes for identifying, assessing, and managing climate-related risks are integrated into the organization's overall risk management.
    Metrics and Targets a Disclose the metrics used by the organization to assess climate- related risks and opportunities in line with its strategy and risk management process. 2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management; 2.4 Aiming to align our activity with the Paris Agreement Goals
    b Disclose Scope 1, Scope 2, and, if appropriate, Scope 3 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, and the related risks. 2.4.5 Our environmental footprint; SN 4. Our transition plan; SN 7.1 Green transition
    c Describe the targets used by the organization to manage climate- related risks and opportunities and performance against targets. 2.4.1 Alignment targets; SN 4. Our transition plan
  • ### Resumen de la tabla La tabla presenta información sobre los principales proveedores de préstamos en el financiamiento de energía renovable en 2024, con las siguientes etiquetas: **Rank**, **Loan Provider**, **Vol. (EUR million)**, **No. transactions** y **Market Share**. 1. **Rank 1**: **Bank 1** lidera con un volumen de 8,009 millones de euros, 79 transacciones y una participación de mercado del 4.95%. 2. **Rank 2**: **Banco Santander** ocupa el segundo lugar con 7,346 millones de euros, 82 transacciones y un 4.54% de participación de mercado. 3. **Rank 3**: **Bank 2** sigue con 7,175 millones de euros, 94 transacciones y un 4.44% de participación de mercado. 4. **Rank 4**: **Peer 1** registra 5,641 millones de euros, 80 transacciones y un 3.49% de participación de mercado. 5. **Rank 5**: **Bank 3** tiene 4,930 millones de euros, 66 transacciones y un 3.05% de participación de mercado. 6. **Rank 6**: **Peer 2** alcanza 4,126 millones de euros, 59 transacciones y un 2.55% de participación de mercado. 7. **Rank 7**: **Peer 3** suma 4,044 millones de euros, 49 transacciones y un 2.50% de participación de mercado. 8. **Rank 8**: **Bank 4** registra 3,978 millones de euros, 41 transacciones y un 2.46% de participación de mercado. 9. **Rank 9**: **Bank 5** tiene 3,538 millones de euros, 44 transacciones y un 2.19% de participación de mercado. 10. **Rank 10**: **Bank 6** cierra con 3,411 millones de euros, 46 transacciones y un 2.11% de participación de mercado. Los datos fueron extraídos el 15 de enero de 2025. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1 2 3 4
    Rank Loan Provider Vol. (EUR million) No. transactions Market Share
    1 Bank 1 8,009 79 4.95%
    2 Banco Santander 7,346 82 4.54%
    3 Bank 2 7,175 94 4.44%
    4 Peer 1 5,641 80 3.49%
    5 Bank 3 4,930 66 3.05%
    6 Peer 2 4,126 59 2.55%
    7 Peer 3 4,044 49 2.50%
    8 Bank 4 3,978 41 2.46%
    9 Bank 5 3,538 44 2.19%
    10 Bank 6 3,411 46 2.11%

L'entreprise mentionne des objectifs de réduction alignés avec une trajectoire de réchauffement à 1,5°C conformément aux Accords de Paris en utilisant le scénario de l'Agence Internationale de l'Énergie - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario (IEA-NZE). Cette trajectoire est intégrée dans les cibles d'alignement qu'ils ont établies pour leurs secteurs financés. De plus, l'entreprise indique que son objectif de réduction des émissions propres (scope 1 et 2) d'ici 2030 est aligné avec la méthode de réduction absolue transsectorielle considérée par le Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi), dépassant l'ambition minimale d'une réduction linéaire annuelle de 4,2 %.

Cependant, il n'est pas explicitement mentionné si l'entreprise a fixé des objectifs de neutralité carbone spécifiquement alignés avec les recommandations de l'Accord de Paris, autres que les trajectoires de réduction mentionnées ci-dessus.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • Scenarios:85 To set 2030 science-based alignment targets for our financed sectors, we choose a credible scenario that draws a pathway to reach net zero emissions by 2050 and will limit temperature increase to 1.5 ℃ in line with the Paris Agreement. The scenario we have chosen for the sectors for which we have released alignment targets is the "International Energy Agency - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario" (IEA-NZE). Our aviation target is consistent with the expected adoption of current technologies. This scenario takes into account the technological, regulatory and market changes that need to take place. Regarding our scope 1 and 2 own emission reduction objective by 2030, it is aligned with the cross-sector absolute reduction method considered by SBTi, going beyond the minimum ambition of a linear annual reduction of a 4.2% linear annual reduction between the base year and target year.
  • Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected.
  • Regarding our own operations, we disclose our direct and indirect emissions (scopes 1, 2 and 3) data as well as other climate- relevant metrics such as energy consumption. We report on our 17 targets for renewable electricity"and the compensation of our scope 1 and scope 2 emissions. Since 2021, we have also been disclosing financed scope 3 emissions (category 15) related to our alignment objectives. We announced our ambition to work to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050 in February 2021. We are constantly reviewing our strategy and targets to incorporate the latest science insights and changes in local regulation.
  • This maturity scale on the degree of issuers' alignment with net zero emissions targets provides us with a framework to check the progress that issuers are making in their transition and identify areas that require further effort in terms of engagement. It considers these factors: 1. A long-term ambition consistent with the goal of achieving net- zero by 2050. 2. Short- and medium-term targets to reduce GHG emissions. 3. Disclosure of scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions. 4. Emissions performance against targets. 5. Alignment strategy. In 2024, we worked on developing our Net Zero engagement strategy, which aims to use dialogue and voting policies to encourage issuers to commit to alignment plans and transparency and disclose accurate and credible information to be able to monitor performance. It also motivates issuers to set ambitious targets that are consistent with the Paris Agreement goals.
  • ### Climate tiering aggregated for the sectors for which we had set targetsª Leader Strong Moderate Weak A. Based on 2024 year-end drawn exposure, according to portfolio alignment methodology, and including project finance, both in operation and under construction. Of our corporate customers with drawn exposure where transition plan assessments were conducted in 2024, approximately: . two-thirds have set quantitative emissions reduction targets on sector-material GHG scopes between 2030 and 2039; . one-third have set, or committed to set, science-based targets (SBTi), if available for the sector; . over two-thirds have a time-bound action plan to align their business, with almost half providing details of the expected proportional impact of different alignment levers, according to our assessment; . over half provide details or commitments for CAPEX alignment with future low-carbon solutions; Santander Annual report 2024 62
  • Target types: To help our customers' transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective. However, due to the absence of a widely accepted "transition finance taxonomy", we consider alignment targets to be an effective tool for informing portfolio decisions, provided that each case is managed individually. For the different targets' design
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines alignment targets across various sectors, scenarios, metrics, baselines, years (2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, and 2030 targets), scopes of emissions, and value chains in scope. 1. **Sector**: "S Power generation" follows the "IEA Net Zero 2050" scenario with the metric "tCO2e/MWh" and a baseline of "0.21 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "0.17" in 2020 to "0.15" in 2023, targeting "0.11 (-46%)" by 2030. Scope is "1," covering "Upstream / Generation," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / End product." 2. **Sector**: "B Oil & gas" uses the metric "mtCO2e" with a baseline of "23.84 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions range from "22.58" in 2020 to "20.27" in 2023, targeting "16.98 (-29%)" by 2030. Scope is "1 + 2 + 34," covering "Integrated / Diversified," "Upstream / Extraction," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / Trading." 3. **Sector**: "ET Aviation" uses the metric "gCO2e/RPK" with a baseline of "92.47 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions fluctuate from "93.05" in 2020 to "82.99" in 2023, targeting "61.71 (-33%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Suppliers," "Midstream / Manufacturing," and "Downstream / Airliners." 4. **Sector**: "Steel" uses the metric "tCO2e/ts" with a baseline of "1.58 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "1.40" in 2020 to "1.38" in 2023, targeting "1.07 (-32%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Materials extraction," "Manufacturing," and "Downstream / End product." 5. **Sector**: "Auto manufacturing" uses the metric "gCO2/vkm" with a baseline of "149 (2020 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "149" in 2020 to "134" in 2023, targeting "103 (-31%)" by 2030. Scope is "3A," covering "Upstream / Suppliers-Materials," "Midstream Manufacturing Dealers," and "Downstream / End product." 6. **Sector**: "Auto lending Europe" uses the metric "gCO2e/vkm" with a baseline of "137 (2022 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "137" in 2022 to "133" in 2023, targeting "75-89 (-35-45%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Downstream / End users." The table provides detailed emissions metrics, baselines, and reduction targets for each sector, along with their respective scopes and value chains.
  • ### 2.4.1 Alignment targets As part of our climate ambition, we prioritize the high-emitting sectors (which also bear high and very high transition risk according to our climate materiality) to which we have material exposure and must support the transition to a low-carbon economy. In 2021 and 2022 we set targets for the wholesale segment in the power generation, thermal coal, oil & gas, aviation, and steel portfolios. In 2023, we focused on the automotive sector from two perspectives: auto manufacturing (wholesale segment) and auto lending (consumer loans for the purchase of passenger cars in Europe). Within the sectorial climate approach described above, cement, shipping and aluminium are deemed not material given their low level of exposure. Agriculture, mortgages and commercial real estate (CRE) are considered material in the retail segment.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento, con enfoque en los impactos y oportunidades relacionados con la fuerza laboral (S1 - Own workforce) y los consumidores y usuarios finales (S4 - Consumers and end users). Los años considerados son de corto a mediano plazo. 1. **S1 - Own workforce**: Se identifican impactos positivos como el desarrollo profesional continuo y el bienestar general de los empleados, promoviendo programas de aprendizaje, condiciones laborales justas y remuneración adecuada basada en mérito y tasas de mercado. También se mencionan riesgos negativos como conductas discriminatorias, condiciones laborales inadecuadas, acoso, corrupción y conflictos con empleados debido a fallos éticos o de gestión. 2. **S4 - Consumers and end users**: Se destacan impactos positivos como la inclusión financiera y la salud financiera de los clientes mediante productos y servicios adaptados a sus necesidades, así como la educación y concienciación sobre ciberseguridad para reducir amenazas en línea. Por otro lado, se identifican impactos negativos como la pérdida de confianza si los clientes no tienen acceso a canales de quejas o si estas no son atendidas adecuadamente. Los impactos están vinculados principalmente a las operaciones propias de la organización y se clasifican como específicos o sistémicos. Las estrategias incluyen programas de desarrollo de talento, esquemas de remuneración, campañas interactivas y talleres de concienciación. Las áreas relacionadas son "Our employees" (3.1) y "Our customers" (3.3).
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento, con el enfoque en el impacto negativo y los riesgos relacionados con los consumidores y usuarios finales (S4 - Consumers and end users). Los años considerados son "Short/ medium term". Las columnas incluyen: "ESRS", "IRO description", "IRO type", "Value chain", "Summary of current/ potential effects (narrative)", "People/ environment", "Strategy- and business model-related impacts", "Time horizon 1", "Linked to impact due to own operations or business relations 2", "Systemic/ specific", "Core activities that lead to positive impacts", "Risks and/or opportunities stemming from impacts", y "More details". 1. **Impacto negativo por falta de información**: Si el banco no proporciona suficiente información sobre productos o servicios, puede haber una ruptura de confianza y relaciones a largo plazo con los clientes. Esto afecta la cadena de valor "Downstream" y está vinculado a las relaciones comerciales. Detalles adicionales: "3.3 Our customers - 3.3.1 Customer conduct". 2. **Impacto negativo por infracción de derechos**: La falta de medidas técnicas u organizativas adecuadas para proteger datos personales puede generar una ruptura de confianza. Esto afecta la cadena de valor "Upstream" y está vinculado a las relaciones comerciales. Detalles adicionales: "3.3 Our customers - 3.3.3 Privacy, data protection and cybersecurity". 3. **Impacto negativo por obstáculos en productos/servicios**: La incapacidad de garantizar acceso o uso adecuado de productos y servicios puede generar una ruptura de confianza. Esto afecta las operaciones propias ("Own operations") y está vinculado a las operaciones propias. Detalles adicionales: "3.3 Our customers - 3.3.1 Customer conduct - iv. Vulnerable customers". 4. **Pérdidas potenciales por sanciones o reducción de clientes**: La falta de respuesta efectiva ante brechas de privacidad puede causar daños si los riesgos se materializan. Esto afecta la cadena de valor "Downstream". Detalles adicionales: "3.3 Our customers - 3.3.3 Privacy, data protection and cybersecurity". 5. **Pérdidas potenciales por prácticas subestándar**: Prácticas deficientes con clientes a lo largo de su ciclo de vida pueden causar daños si los riesgos se materializan. Esto afecta la cadena de valor "Downstream". Detalles adicionales: "3.3 Our customers - 3.3.1 Customer conduct".
  • ### Resumen de la tabla TCFD en el Informe Anual de Santander 2024 La tabla presenta un índice de contenido relacionado con las recomendaciones del "Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosure (TCFD)" y sus referencias en el informe anual. Se organiza en cuatro categorías principales: **Governance**, **Strategy**, **Risk Management**, y **Metrics and Targets**, con subapartados etiquetados como "a", "b" y "c". 1. **Governance**: - **a**: Describe la supervisión del consejo sobre riesgos y oportunidades climáticas. Referencias: "1.4 Sustainability governance; SN 2. Sustainability governance". - **b**: Describe el rol de la gestión en la evaluación y manejo de riesgos y oportunidades climáticas. Referencias: "1.4 Sustainability governance; SN 2. Sustainability governance; 2.5.2 Governance & policies; 2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management". 2. **Strategy**: - **a**: Describe los riesgos y oportunidades climáticas identificados a corto, mediano y largo plazo. - **b**: Describe el impacto de estos riesgos y oportunidades en los negocios, estrategia y planificación financiera. Referencias: "2.1 Strategy; 2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management". - **c**: Describe la resiliencia de la estrategia considerando escenarios climáticos, incluyendo uno de 2℃ o menor. 3. **Risk Management**: - **a**: Describe los procesos de identificación y evaluación de riesgos climáticos. - **b**: Describe los procesos de gestión de riesgos climáticos. Referencias: "2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management". - **c**: Describe cómo estos procesos se integran en la gestión general de riesgos. 4. **Metrics and Targets**: - **a**: Divulga las métricas utilizadas para evaluar riesgos y oportunidades climáticas. Referencias: "2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management; 2.4 Aiming to align our activity with the Paris Agreement Goals". - **b**: Divulga las emisiones de Gases de Efecto Invernadero (GEI) de Alcance 1, 2 y, si corresponde, 3, y los riesgos relacionados. Referencias: "2.4.5 Our environmental footprint; SN 4. Our transition plan; SN 7.1 Green transition". - **c**: Describe los objetivos para gestionar riesgos y oportunidades climáticas y el desempeño frente a estos. Referencias: "2.4.1 Alignment targets; SN 4. Our transition plan".
  • ### Resumen de la tabla La tabla presenta información sobre los principales proveedores de préstamos en el financiamiento de energía renovable en 2024, con las siguientes etiquetas: **Rank**, **Loan Provider**, **Vol. (EUR million)**, **No. transactions** y **Market Share**. 1. **Rank 1**: **Bank 1** lidera con un volumen de 8,009 millones de euros, 79 transacciones y una participación de mercado del 4.95%. 2. **Rank 2**: **Banco Santander** ocupa el segundo lugar con 7,346 millones de euros, 82 transacciones y un 4.54% de participación de mercado. 3. **Rank 3**: **Bank 2** sigue con 7,175 millones de euros, 94 transacciones y un 4.44% de participación de mercado. 4. **Rank 4**: **Peer 1** registra 5,641 millones de euros, 80 transacciones y un 3.49% de participación de mercado. 5. **Rank 5**: **Bank 3** tiene 4,930 millones de euros, 66 transacciones y un 3.05% de participación de mercado. 6. **Rank 6**: **Peer 2** alcanza 4,126 millones de euros, 59 transacciones y un 2.55% de participación de mercado. 7. **Rank 7**: **Peer 3** suma 4,044 millones de euros, 49 transacciones y un 2.50% de participación de mercado. 8. **Rank 8**: **Bank 4** registra 3,978 millones de euros, 41 transacciones y un 2.46% de participación de mercado. 9. **Rank 9**: **Bank 5** tiene 3,538 millones de euros, 44 transacciones y un 2.19% de participación de mercado. 10. **Rank 10**: **Bank 6** cierra con 3,411 millones de euros, 46 transacciones y un 2.11% de participación de mercado. Los datos fueron extraídos el 15 de enero de 2025.

D'après les informations fournies dans le contexte, l'entreprise a effectivement fixé des objectifs de réduction alignés avec une trajectoire de 1,5°C conformément aux Accords de Paris. Ces objectifs sont en ligne avec le scénario "International Energy Agency - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario" (IEA-NZE), qui vise à atteindre zéro émission nette d'ici 2050, limitant ainsi l'augmentation de température à 1,5°C.

L'entreprise mentionne également qu'elle utilise des objectifs alignés sur les recommandations de l'initiative Science Based Targets (SBTi) pour ses secteurs financés, ce qui renforce l'alignement avec les objectifs de l'Accord de Paris.

Concernant la neutralité carbone, l'entreprise a annoncé son ambition d'atteindre des émissions nettes nulles d'ici 2050, une démarche qui doit nécessairement être alignée avec les recommandations de l'Accord de Paris.

En résumé, l'entreprise montre un engagement à suivre une trajectoire de réduction d'émissions conforme à une limitation du réchauffement à 1,5°C, en s'appuyant sur des scénarios et des objectifs reconnus internationalement, comme ceux proposés par SBTi.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • Aiming to align our portfolio with the Paris Agreement goals to help limit global warming. We are setting sector portfolio alignment targets for 2030 in high-emissions portfolios. The progress on these targets is expected to reflect the progress of the economies we serve. We currently have seven targets in five sectors and alignment targets for our asset management activity. Meanwhile, we continue to reduce our impact on the environment by implementing efficiency measures in our own operations and sourcing all our electricity from renewable sources by 2025. To achieve this, we engage with our different stakeholders: •Customers and investors: developing products/services adapted to their needs; participating in a collaborative network of institutions to create financing opportunities; and developing assessment tools to better manage performance and monitor progress towards their transition goals. Aiming to align our portfolio with the Paris Agreement goals to help limit global warming. We are setting sector portfolio alignment targets for 2030 in high-emissions portfolios. The progress on these targets is expected to reflect the progress of the economies we serve. We currently have seven targets in five sectors and alignment targets for our asset management activity. Meanwhile, we continue to reduce our impact on the environment by implementing efficiency measures in our own operations and sourcing all our electricity from renewable sources by 2025. To achieve this, we engage with our different stakeholders: •Customers and investors: developing products/services adapted to their needs; participating in a collaborative network of institutions to create financing opportunities; and developing assessment tools to better manage performance and monitor progress towards their transition goals.
  • individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective. However, due to the absence of a widely accepted “transition finance taxonomy”, we consider alignment targets to be an effective tool for informing portfolio decisions, provided that each case is managed individually. For the different targets’ design choices taken, we considered inputs from several different internal and external stakeholders. Scenarios:85 To set 2030 science-based alignment targets for our financed sectors, we choose a credible scenario that draws a pathway to reach net zero emissions by 2050 and will limit temperature increase to 1.5 ºC in line with the Paris Agreement. The scenario we have chosen for the sectors for which we have released alignment targets is the “International Energy Agency - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario” (IEA-NZE). Our aviation target is consistent with the expected adoption of current technologies. This scenario takes into account the technological, individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective. Based on 2024 year-end drawn exposure, according to portfolio alignment methodology, and including project finance, both in operation and under construction. Of our corporate customers with drawn exposure where transition plan assessments were conducted in 2024, approximately: •two-thirds have set quantitative emissions reduction targets on sector-material GHG scopes between 2030 and 2039; •one-third have set, or committed to set, science-based targets (SBTi), if available for the sector; •over two-thirds have a time-bound action plan to align their business, with almost half providing details of the expected proportional impact of different alignment levers, according to our assessment ; •over half provide details or commitments for CAPEX alignment with future low-carbon solutions; Annual report 2024 62 composition and evolution. Of our corporate customers with drawn exposure where transition plan assessments were conducted in 2024, approximately: •two-thirds have set quantitative emissions reduction targets on sector-material GHG scopes between 2030 and 2039; •one-third have set, or committed to set, science-based targets (SBTi), if available for the sector; •over two-thirds have a time-bound action plan to align their business, with almost half providing details of the expected proportional impact of different alignment levers, according to our assessment ; •over half provide details or commitments for CAPEX alignment with future low-carbon solutions; Annual report 2024 62
  • Contents Business model Sustainability Corporate Economic and Risk management and strategy statement governance financial review and compliance SN 4. Our transition plan i.Alignment targets details Target types : To help our customers’ transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective. Contents Business model Sustainability Corporate Economic and Risk management and strategy statement governance financial review and compliance SN 4. Our transition plan i.Alignment targets details Target types : To help our customers’ transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective.

  • technologies. This scenario takes into account the technological, regulatory and market changes that need to take place. Regarding our scope 1 and 2 own emission reduction objective by 2030, it is aligned with the cross-sector absolute reduction method considered by SBTi, going beyond the minimum ambition of a linear annual reduction of a 4.2% linear annual reduction between the base year and target year. Target coverage:86 All CIB portfolio targets and metrics are global and include our core subsidiaries. SCF's target is European and includes its passenger car portfolio (including loans and leasing) in16 units (13 countries in Europe). This is the same scope we use to measure emissions performance and progress with our targets, though we are working on obtaining information and tracking emissions for other vehicle types. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market.   • sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable. sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable.
  • in ISS. Evol. AA CCCAAA =AA 19.7 100 0 é17.1 A- D- A éA C- 55.6 0 A+ éC+ 58.5 2023 2024 •Regulators: as part of the policy debate we engage with regulators (local and European) and international standard setters on the initiatives that are most important to the bank, our employees, our customers and the communities we serve. Santander works with the Basel Committee, the Financial Stability Board, the European Banking Authority, the European Central Bank, EU institutions, Banco de España, the Bank of England, and other key actors to set out the sustainable financing framework that boosts support for the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris Climate Agreement targets. As part of this engagement, at the corporate level, the Group responded to 53 consultations during 2024. In addition, Brazil’s presidency of the G20 and the COP30 to be held in Belém in 2025 will provide greater opportunity to work with stakeholders on common solutions to ramp up the transition in in ISS. Evol. AA CCCAAA =AA 19.7 100 0 é17.1 A- D- A éA C- 55.6 0 A+ éC+ 58.5 2023 2024 •Regulators: as part of the policy debate we engage with regulators (local and European) and international standard setters on the initiatives that are most important to the bank, our employees, our customers and the communities we serve. Santander works with the Basel Committee, the Financial Stability Board, the European Banking Authority, the European Central Bank, EU institutions, Banco de España, the Bank of England, and other key actors to set out the sustainable financing framework that boosts support for the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris Climate Agreement targets. As part of this engagement, at the corporate level, the Group responded to 53 consultations during 2024. In addition, Brazil’s presidency of the G20 and the COP30 to be held in Belém in 2025 will provide greater opportunity to work with stakeholders on common solutions to ramp up the transition in
E1-6

Quels sont les leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans le plan de transition de l'entreprise ?

Pour répondre à cette question, nous souhaitons avoir la liste ou les noms des actions menées, accompagnées d'une description simple. Si possible, afficher les objectifs de réduction pour chacune des actions, avec l'année cible et l'année de référence.

1. Nom de l'action ou du projet de réduction.
2. Métrique.
3. Périmètre des émissions (Scope 1, 2 ou 3).
4. Année de référence.
5. Objectif de réduction.
6. Année cible. Des informations moins primordiales, mais souhaitables pourraient être :

- La méthodologie utilisée ou l'initiative correspondante.
- Les objectifs intermédiaires (2030, 2035, 2040, 2045).

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur les leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans le plan de transition de l'entreprise avec des détails tels que les noms des actions menées, les métriques, les périmètres des émissions, les années de référence, les objectifs de réduction, ou les années cibles.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • The first step involves assessing how our customers' emissions trajectory aligns with our current sectoral portfolio baseline and future sectoral portfolio targets. The second step assesses the quality of each customer's transition plan. Our transition plan assessment methodology focuses on four pillars: 1. Targets: it focuses on the quality and ambition of the customer's quantitative GHG emissions targets. Where possible, we assess short- and long-term, as well as absolute and intensity reduction targets. 2. Action plan: it considers the credibility of the customer's alignment strategy. We assess the business strategy integration of climate change risks and opportunities; the existence of climate scenario planning; as well as time-bound action plans to achieve alignment targets. The first step involves assessing how our customers' emissions trajectory aligns with our current sectoral portfolio baseline and future sectoral portfolio targets. The second step assesses the quality of each customer's transition plan. Our transition plan assessment methodology focuses on four pillars: 1. Targets: it focuses on the quality and ambition of the customer's quantitative GHG emissions targets. Where possible, we assess short- and long-term, as well as absolute and intensity reduction targets. 2. Action plan: it considers the credibility of the customer's alignment strategy. We assess the business strategy integration of climate change risks and opportunities; the existence of climate scenario planning; as well as time-bound action plans to achieve alignment targets.
  • Our approach aims to facilitate the achievement of our emissions targets and to develop a strong understanding of our customers' transition strategies towards low-carbon business models. This approach is supported by governance processes, involving various internal stakeholders, such as front office teams, risk reporting functions, and senior management to guide the potential portfolio steering actions (for more details, see the Portfolio Steering section below). It is structured around four main iterative steps: Collect, Assess, Engage and Review. We have used various internationally recognized references and the Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership (CISL) 'Let's Discuss Climate' guide as inputs and adapted them to our requirements and objectives. Our approach aims to facilitate the achievement of our emissions targets and to develop a strong understanding of our customers' transition strategies towards low-carbon business models. This approach is supported by governance processes, involving various internal stakeholders, such as front office teams, risk reporting functions, and senior management to guide the potential portfolio steering actions (for more details, see the Portfolio Steering section below). It is structured around four main iterative steps: Collect, Assess, Engage and Review. We have used various internationally recognized references and the Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership (CISL) 'Let's Discuss Climate' guide as inputs and adapted them to our requirements and objectives.
  • ## Risk management and compliance ### 2.1.2 Our ambition We continue working towards our ambition of net zero carbon emissions by 2050 by progressively setting specific actions to make headway with our three-pillar strategy. Incentive policies and frameworks are key to driving the energy transition. The challenge goes beyond increasing the flow of capital from the regulated financial sector to funding the energy transition. We need to scale transition activity and the demand for solutions, which will require better risk-profitability profiles. Achieving climate objectives depends largely on the macroeconomic landscape and public policy. ## Risk management and compliance ### 2.1.2 Our ambition We continue working towards our ambition of net zero carbon emissions by 2050 by progressively setting specific actions to make headway with our three-pillar strategy. Incentive policies and frameworks are key to driving the energy transition. The challenge goes beyond increasing the flow of capital from the regulated financial sector to funding the energy transition. We need to scale transition activity and the demand for solutions, which will require better risk-profitability profiles. Achieving climate objectives depends largely on the macroeconomic landscape and public policy.
  • ### 2.4.1 Alignment targets As part of our climate ambition, we prioritize the high-emitting sectors (which also bear high and very high transition risk according to our climate materiality) to which we have material exposure and must support the transition to a low-carbon economy. In 2021 and 2022 we set targets for the wholesale segment in the power generation, thermal coal, oil & gas, aviation, and steel portfolios. In 2023, we focused on the automotive sector from two perspectives: auto manufacturing (wholesale segment) and auto lending (consumer loans for the purchase of passenger cars in Europe). Within the sectorial climate approach described above, cement, shipping and aluminium are deemed not material given their low level of exposure. Agriculture, mortgages and commercial real estate (CRE) are considered material in the retail segment. ### 2.4.1 Alignment targets As part of our climate ambition, we prioritize the high-emitting sectors (which also bear high and very high transition risk according to our climate materiality) to which we have material exposure and must support the transition to a low-carbon economy. In 2021 and 2022 we set targets for the wholesale segment in the power generation, thermal coal, oil & gas, aviation, and steel portfolios. In 2023, we focused on the automotive sector from two perspectives: auto manufacturing (wholesale segment) and auto lending (consumer loans for the purchase of passenger cars in Europe). Within the sectorial climate approach described above, cement, shipping and aluminium are deemed not material given their low level of exposure. Agriculture, mortgages and commercial real estate (CRE) are considered material in the retail segment.
  • ### Climate opportunities Working with customers to support their transition objectives and carbon reduction emissions goals is key to progressing towards a low-carbon economy. To do this we identify business opportunities for transition financing assessing key sectors, working closely with our clients and with the knowledge of our sustainability experts. These opportunities inform our materiality assessment. In addition, the Group calculates the ratio of green assets aligned with the European Taxonomy. In 2024, it amounts to 3.28% (vs. 2.6% in 2023). The volume of assets as at December 2024 aligned with the European taxonomy for mortgages is EUR 28.1 bn and auto is EUR 8.8 bn. For more details, see SN 5. European Taxonomy. Also, from investment through our assets management business SAM, the top three climate-related opportunities are: · new climate solutions involving products and services that boost diversification, competitive advantage and revenue; ### Climate opportunities Working with customers to support their transition objectives and carbon reduction emissions goals is key to progressing towards a low-carbon economy. To do this we identify business opportunities for transition financing assessing key sectors, working closely with our clients and with the knowledge of our sustainability experts. These opportunities inform our materiality assessment. In addition, the Group calculates the ratio of green assets aligned with the European Taxonomy. In 2024, it amounts to 3.28% (vs. 2.6% in 2023). The volume of assets as at December 2024 aligned with the European taxonomy for mortgages is EUR 28.1 bn and auto is EUR 8.8 bn. For more details, see SN 5. European Taxonomy. Also, from investment through our assets management business SAM, the top three climate-related opportunities are: · new climate solutions involving products and services that boost diversification, competitive advantage and revenue;
  • Target types: To help our customers' transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective. However, due to the absence of a widely accepted "transition finance taxonomy", we consider alignment targets to be an effective tool for informing portfolio decisions, provided that each case is managed individually. For the different targets' design Target types: To help our customers' transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective. However, due to the absence of a widely accepted "transition finance taxonomy", we consider alignment targets to be an effective tool for informing portfolio decisions, provided that each case is managed individually. For the different targets' design
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines alignment targets across various sectors, scenarios, metrics, baselines, years (2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, and 2030 targets), scopes of emissions, and value chains in scope. 1. **Sector**: "S Power generation" follows the "IEA Net Zero 2050" scenario with the metric "tCO2e/MWh" and a baseline of "0.21 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "0.17" in 2020 to "0.15" in 2023, targeting "0.11 (-46%)" by 2030. Scope is "1," covering "Upstream / Generation," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / End product." 2. **Sector**: "B Oil & gas" uses the metric "mtCO2e" with a baseline of "23.84 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions range from "22.58" in 2020 to "20.27" in 2023, targeting "16.98 (-29%)" by 2030. Scope is "1 + 2 + 34," covering "Integrated / Diversified," "Upstream / Extraction," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / Trading." 3. **Sector**: "ET Aviation" uses the metric "gCO2e/RPK" with a baseline of "92.47 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions fluctuate from "93.05" in 2020 to "82.99" in 2023, targeting "61.71 (-33%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Suppliers," "Midstream / Manufacturing," and "Downstream / Airliners." 4. **Sector**: "Steel" uses the metric "tCO2e/ts" with a baseline of "1.58 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "1.40" in 2020 to "1.38" in 2023, targeting "1.07 (-32%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Materials extraction," "Manufacturing," and "Downstream / End product." 5. **Sector**: "Auto manufacturing" uses the metric "gCO2/vkm" with a baseline of "149 (2020 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "149" in 2020 to "134" in 2023, targeting "103 (-31%)" by 2030. Scope is "3A," covering "Upstream / Suppliers-Materials," "Midstream Manufacturing Dealers," and "Downstream / End product." 6. **Sector**: "Auto lending Europe" uses the metric "gCO2e/vkm" with a baseline of "137 (2022 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "137" in 2022 to "133" in 2023, targeting "75-89 (-35-45%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Downstream / End users." The table provides detailed emissions metrics, baselines, and reduction targets for each sector, along with their respective scopes and value chains. and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" La tabla detalla la información no financiera que debe divulgarse, organizada en tres columnas: "Non-financial information to be disclosed", "Chapter/section of the annual report" y "Correspondence with CSRD/other regulations". Los temas abordados incluyen: 1. **Efectos ambientales y riesgos**: Información sobre los efectos actuales y previsibles de las actividades de la empresa en el medio ambiente, incluyendo riesgos ambientales y provisiones, se encuentra en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y corresponde a regulaciones como SBM-3, IRO-1, MDR-A, MDR-M, E1, entre otras. 2. **Contaminación**: Medidas para prevenir, reducir o reparar emisiones de CO2 y otras formas de contaminación están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a MDR-A, E1-3, E1-7. 3. **Economía circular y gestión de residuos**: Acciones como prevención, reciclaje y reutilización de residuos se encuentran en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a E5, IRO-1. 4. **Uso sostenible de recursos**: Incluye el uso de agua y materias primas, con medidas para mejorar la eficiencia, en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135) [Table 2. Environmental footprint]", correspondiendo a E3, E5, IRO-1. 5. **Energía**: Consumo directo e indirecto, eficiencia energética y uso de energías renovables están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-A, MDR-M, E1-3, E1-5. 6. **Cambio climático**: Emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, medidas de adaptación y objetivos de reducción están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-M, E1-6, MDR-T, E1-4. 7. **Biodiversidad**: Medidas para preservar o restaurar la biodiversidad están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.3.5 Our approach to nature and biodiversity]" y corresponden a E4, IRO-1. and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance": La tabla presenta cinco áreas clave relacionadas con la gestión de riesgos y el cumplimiento: 1. **Inclusive Culture**: Avances en la cultura inclusiva y otras iniciativas como la accesibilidad. 2. **Financial inclusion**: Progresos en los objetivos de inclusión financiera y otras iniciativas clave en la agenda social, como la educación financiera y la inversión comunitaria. 3. **Sustainable finance**: Avances en las finanzas sostenibles y la inversión socialmente responsable. 4. **Climate**: Progresos en el plan de transición y los principales mecanismos para cumplir con la ambición de alcanzar emisiones netas cero. 5. **Governance and cross cutting matters**: Realización de la evaluación de doble materialidad, implementación de políticas de sostenibilidad y mejora de la eficiencia y calidad de los datos. and

    Risk management and compliance

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1
    Inclusive Culture Progress with inclusive culture and other initiatives such as accessibility.
    Financial inclusion Progress with financial inclusion targets and other key initiatives in the social agenda (financial education, community investment, etc.).
    Sustainable finance Progress with sustainable finance and socially responsible investment.
    Climate Progress with our transition plan and the key levers to fulfil our net zero ambition.
    Governance and cross cutting matters Conducting our double materiality assessment, implementing sustainability policies, and enhancing data efficiency and quality.

Je ne peux pas fournir une réponse complète à votre question car les informations concernant les leviers de décarbonation précis, les objectifs de réduction, les métriques, et les années cibles ne sont pas spécifiquement détaillées dans les documents fournis. Cependant, je peux résumer quelques initiatives et objectifs généraux mentionnés dans le contexte :

  1. Transition vers des énergies à faibles émissions :

    • L'entreprise s'engage à utiliser des sources d'énergie renouvelables pour réduire l'exposition aux émissions de gaz à effet de serre, ainsi qu'à tirer parti des incitations politiques pour réduire les coûts.
    • Objectif : S'approvisionner entièrement en électricité à partir de sources renouvelables d'ici 2025.

  2. Plan de transition climatique :

    • Inclut des mesures pour améliorer l'efficacité énergétique et utiliser des énergies renouvelables.
    • Aucun objectif spécifique de réduction ou année cible n'est mentionné.

  3. Objectifs d'alignement sectoriel pour 2030 :

    • L'entreprise fixe des cibles d'alignement sectoriel pour les portefeuilles à fortes émissions en lien avec les objectifs de l'Accord de Paris.

  4. Réduction des émissions de carbone dans l'industrie de la production d'énergie :

    • L'industrie vise à réduire l'intensité carbone.

Ces points couvrent certaines des initiatives générales de décarbonation mentionnées dans le contexte, mais sans les détails spécifiques demandés. Pour des informations plus précises, il serait nécessaire de consulter le rapport annuel complet de l'entreprise ou d'autres documents internes détaillant ces initiatives.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • The first step involves assessing how our customers' emissions trajectory aligns with our current sectoral portfolio baseline and future sectoral portfolio targets. The second step assesses the quality of each customer's transition plan. Our transition plan assessment methodology focuses on four pillars: 1. Targets: it focuses on the quality and ambition of the customer's quantitative GHG emissions targets. Where possible, we assess short- and long-term, as well as absolute and intensity reduction targets. 2. Action plan: it considers the credibility of the customer's alignment strategy. We assess the business strategy integration of climate change risks and opportunities; the existence of climate scenario planning; as well as time-bound action plans to achieve alignment targets.
  • Our approach aims to facilitate the achievement of our emissions targets and to develop a strong understanding of our customers' transition strategies towards low-carbon business models. This approach is supported by governance processes, involving various internal stakeholders, such as front office teams, risk reporting functions, and senior management to guide the potential portfolio steering actions (for more details, see the Portfolio Steering section below). It is structured around four main iterative steps: Collect, Assess, Engage and Review. We have used various internationally recognized references and the Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership (CISL) 'Let's Discuss Climate' guide as inputs and adapted them to our requirements and objectives.
  • ## Risk management and compliance ### 2.1.2 Our ambition We continue working towards our ambition of net zero carbon emissions by 2050 by progressively setting specific actions to make headway with our three-pillar strategy. Incentive policies and frameworks are key to driving the energy transition. The challenge goes beyond increasing the flow of capital from the regulated financial sector to funding the energy transition. We need to scale transition activity and the demand for solutions, which will require better risk-profitability profiles. Achieving climate objectives depends largely on the macroeconomic landscape and public policy.
  • ### 2.4.1 Alignment targets As part of our climate ambition, we prioritize the high-emitting sectors (which also bear high and very high transition risk according to our climate materiality) to which we have material exposure and must support the transition to a low-carbon economy. In 2021 and 2022 we set targets for the wholesale segment in the power generation, thermal coal, oil & gas, aviation, and steel portfolios. In 2023, we focused on the automotive sector from two perspectives: auto manufacturing (wholesale segment) and auto lending (consumer loans for the purchase of passenger cars in Europe). Within the sectorial climate approach described above, cement, shipping and aluminium are deemed not material given their low level of exposure. Agriculture, mortgages and commercial real estate (CRE) are considered material in the retail segment.
  • ### Climate opportunities Working with customers to support their transition objectives and carbon reduction emissions goals is key to progressing towards a low-carbon economy. To do this we identify business opportunities for transition financing assessing key sectors, working closely with our clients and with the knowledge of our sustainability experts. These opportunities inform our materiality assessment. In addition, the Group calculates the ratio of green assets aligned with the European Taxonomy. In 2024, it amounts to 3.28% (vs. 2.6% in 2023). The volume of assets as at December 2024 aligned with the European taxonomy for mortgages is EUR 28.1 bn and auto is EUR 8.8 bn. For more details, see SN 5. European Taxonomy. Also, from investment through our assets management business SAM, the top three climate-related opportunities are: · new climate solutions involving products and services that boost diversification, competitive advantage and revenue;
  • Target types: To help our customers' transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective. However, due to the absence of a widely accepted "transition finance taxonomy", we consider alignment targets to be an effective tool for informing portfolio decisions, provided that each case is managed individually. For the different targets' design
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines alignment targets across various sectors, scenarios, metrics, baselines, years (2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, and 2030 targets), scopes of emissions, and value chains in scope. 1. **Sector**: "S Power generation" follows the "IEA Net Zero 2050" scenario with the metric "tCO2e/MWh" and a baseline of "0.21 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "0.17" in 2020 to "0.15" in 2023, targeting "0.11 (-46%)" by 2030. Scope is "1," covering "Upstream / Generation," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / End product." 2. **Sector**: "B Oil & gas" uses the metric "mtCO2e" with a baseline of "23.84 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions range from "22.58" in 2020 to "20.27" in 2023, targeting "16.98 (-29%)" by 2030. Scope is "1 + 2 + 34," covering "Integrated / Diversified," "Upstream / Extraction," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / Trading." 3. **Sector**: "ET Aviation" uses the metric "gCO2e/RPK" with a baseline of "92.47 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions fluctuate from "93.05" in 2020 to "82.99" in 2023, targeting "61.71 (-33%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Suppliers," "Midstream / Manufacturing," and "Downstream / Airliners." 4. **Sector**: "Steel" uses the metric "tCO2e/ts" with a baseline of "1.58 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "1.40" in 2020 to "1.38" in 2023, targeting "1.07 (-32%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Materials extraction," "Manufacturing," and "Downstream / End product." 5. **Sector**: "Auto manufacturing" uses the metric "gCO2/vkm" with a baseline of "149 (2020 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "149" in 2020 to "134" in 2023, targeting "103 (-31%)" by 2030. Scope is "3A," covering "Upstream / Suppliers-Materials," "Midstream Manufacturing Dealers," and "Downstream / End product." 6. **Sector**: "Auto lending Europe" uses the metric "gCO2e/vkm" with a baseline of "137 (2022 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "137" in 2022 to "133" in 2023, targeting "75-89 (-35-45%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Downstream / End users." The table provides detailed emissions metrics, baselines, and reduction targets for each sector, along with their respective scopes and value chains.
  • ## Risk management and compliance · Replacing conventional oil or gas boilers with electric heat pump systems and technologies where the weather allows. With these measures, we want to continue reducing our direct scope 1 and indirect scope 2 emissions, with specific targets that will enable us to reduce:
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" La tabla detalla la información no financiera que debe divulgarse, organizada en tres columnas: "Non-financial information to be disclosed", "Chapter/section of the annual report" y "Correspondence with CSRD/other regulations". Los temas abordados incluyen: 1. **Efectos ambientales y riesgos**: Información sobre los efectos actuales y previsibles de las actividades de la empresa en el medio ambiente, incluyendo riesgos ambientales y provisiones, se encuentra en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y corresponde a regulaciones como SBM-3, IRO-1, MDR-A, MDR-M, E1, entre otras. 2. **Contaminación**: Medidas para prevenir, reducir o reparar emisiones de CO2 y otras formas de contaminación están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a MDR-A, E1-3, E1-7. 3. **Economía circular y gestión de residuos**: Acciones como prevención, reciclaje y reutilización de residuos se encuentran en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a E5, IRO-1. 4. **Uso sostenible de recursos**: Incluye el uso de agua y materias primas, con medidas para mejorar la eficiencia, en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135) [Table 2. Environmental footprint]", correspondiendo a E3, E5, IRO-1. 5. **Energía**: Consumo directo e indirecto, eficiencia energética y uso de energías renovables están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-A, MDR-M, E1-3, E1-5. 6. **Cambio climático**: Emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, medidas de adaptación y objetivos de reducción están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-M, E1-6, MDR-T, E1-4. 7. **Biodiversidad**: Medidas para preservar o restaurar la biodiversidad están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.3.5 Our approach to nature and biodiversity]" y corresponden a E4, IRO-1.
  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta estrategias relacionadas con el cambio climático y la integración de ESG en la gestión de riesgos. Los encabezados son: "Strategy", "Section", "Sub-section", "Sub-sub-section" y "Comments". En la fila 1, la estrategia "E1-1 - Transition plan for climate change mitigation" está vinculada a la sección "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) Sustainability notes (p. 107)", con sub-secciones como "2.1 Strategy (p. 32)", "2.2 Supporting our customers in their transition goals (p. 35)", "2.4 Aiming to align our activity with the Paris Agreement Goals (p. 59)", y "2.5 Further actions and enablers (p. 72) SN 4. Our transition plan- (p. 129)". La sub-sub-sección destacada es "2.5.2 Governance & policies". En la fila 2, la estrategia "ESRS 2 SBM-3 - Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with S&BM" está asociada a la sección "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)", con la sub-sección "2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management (p. 40)". Las sub-sub-secciones incluyen "2.3.1 Resilience of our strategy and business model to climate change" y "2.3.2 Risk management cycle". No se proporcionan comentarios adicionales en ninguna de las filas.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta los "Minimum Disclosure Requirement" (MDR) organizados en las siguientes columnas: "Section", "Sub-section", "Sub-sub-section" y "Comments". Los MDR incluyen: 1. **MDR-P**: Políticas adoptadas para gestionar asuntos materiales de sostenibilidad, con referencias a las secciones: - "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" - "3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p. 75)" - "4. Business conduct (p. 100)" - "Sustainability notes (p. 107)", específicamente "SN 1. Introduction, basis of presentation of the consolidated sustainability statement and other information". 2. **MDR-A**: Acciones y recursos relacionados con asuntos materiales de sostenibilidad, mencionando "Sustainability notes (p. 107)". 3. **MDR-M**: Métricas relacionadas con asuntos materiales de sostenibilidad, incluyendo "SN 9. Alternative performance measures (p. 202)". 4. **MDR-T**: Seguimiento de la efectividad de políticas y acciones mediante objetivos, también vinculado a "SN 9. Alternative performance measures (p. 202)".
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance": La tabla presenta cinco áreas clave relacionadas con la gestión de riesgos y el cumplimiento: 1. **Inclusive Culture**: Avances en la cultura inclusiva y otras iniciativas como la accesibilidad. 2. **Financial inclusion**: Progresos en los objetivos de inclusión financiera y otras iniciativas clave en la agenda social, como la educación financiera y la inversión comunitaria. 3. **Sustainable finance**: Avances en las finanzas sostenibles y la inversión socialmente responsable. 4. **Climate**: Progresos en el plan de transición y los principales mecanismos para cumplir con la ambición de alcanzar emisiones netas cero. 5. **Governance and cross cutting matters**: Realización de la evaluación de doble materialidad, implementación de políticas de sostenibilidad y mejora de la eficiencia y calidad de los datos.

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur les leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans le plan de transition de l'entreprise avec des détails tels que les noms des actions menées, les métriques, les périmètres des émissions, les années de référence, les objectifs de réduction, ou les années cibles.

  • diversification, competitive advantage and revenue; •lower-emission energy sources that benefit from less exposure to Greenhouse Gases (GHG) emissions, lower costs, policy incentives; and •efficient production and distribution of resources to lower operational costs and raise both production capacity and the value of fixed assets. Transition finance and just transition The regulatory framework must support growth, which is key to a stable and orderly transition. We want to help achieve sustainable development and pledge to play an active role in supporting the green transition. It is vital that the transition is just and inclusive, taking into account regional and sector specificities to avoid isolating communities and stranding assets. We aim to embed and promote the just transition through our engagement approach, our risk management policies and processes, and our sustainable and investment products. We consider this approach when devising our policies and reviewing diversification, competitive advantage and revenue; •lower-emission energy sources that benefit from less exposure to Greenhouse Gases (GHG) emissions, lower costs, policy incentives; and •efficient production and distribution of resources to lower operational costs and raise both production capacity and the value of fixed assets. It is vital that the transition is just and inclusive, taking into account regional and sector specificities to avoid isolating communities and stranding assets. We aim to embed and promote the just transition through our engagement approach, our risk management policies and processes, and our sustainable and investment products.   • Contents Business model Sustainability Corporate Economic and Risk management and strategy statement governance financial review and compliance SN 4. Our transition plan i.Alignment targets details Target types : To help our customers’ transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective.   • Aiming to align our portfolio with the Paris Agreement goals to help limit global warming. We are setting sector portfolio alignment targets for 2030 in high-emissions portfolios. The progress on these targets is expected to reflect the progress of the economies we serve. We currently have seven targets in five sectors and alignment targets for our asset management activity. Meanwhile, we continue to reduce our impact on the environment by implementing efficiency measures in our own operations and sourcing all our electricity from renewable sources by 2025. To achieve this, we engage with our different stakeholders: •Customers and investors: developing products/services adapted to their needs; participating in a collaborative network of institutions to create financing opportunities; and developing assessment tools to better manage performance and monitor progress towards their transition goals. Aiming to align our portfolio with the Paris Agreement goals to help limit global warming. We are setting sector portfolio alignment targets for 2030 in high-emissions portfolios. The progress on these targets is expected to reflect the progress of the economies we serve. We currently have seven targets in five sectors and alignment targets for our asset management activity. Meanwhile, we continue to reduce our impact on the environment by implementing efficiency measures in our own operations and sourcing all our electricity from renewable sources by 2025.   • KPI performance. Contributing to integrity in transition finance We continue to contribute to furthering knowledge of transition finance as a key enabler towards net zero. As part of our long-standing support for education, employability and entrepreneurship, we are collaborating with the University of Oxford to fund the development of a Transition Finance Centre of Excellence. This centre aims to play a prominent role in defining aspects of transition finance, such as best practice sectoral transition plans and new tools and insight for practitioners. Initial research has focused on developing a deeper understanding of assessing companies’ transition plans Sectorial considerations Power generation Sector boundaries: For the power generation sector, we assess the upstream/generation business in the value chain. Our portfolio includes both corporate customers and project finance transactions. Industry dynamics: The industry is reducing carbon intensity by KPI performance. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A.   • sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable. sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable.
  • in ISS. Evol. AA CCCAAA =AA 19.7 100 0 é17.1 A- D- A éA C- 55.6 0 A+ éC+ 58.5 2023 2024 •Regulators: as part of the policy debate we engage with regulators (local and European) and international standard setters on the initiatives that are most important to the bank, our employees, our customers and the communities we serve. Santander works with the Basel Committee, the Financial Stability Board, the European Banking Authority, the European Central Bank, EU institutions, Banco de España, the Bank of England, and other key actors to set out the sustainable financing framework that boosts support for the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris Climate Agreement targets. As part of this engagement, at the corporate level, the Group responded to 53 consultations during 2024. In addition, Brazil’s presidency of the G20 and the COP30 to be held in Belém in 2025 will provide greater opportunity to work with stakeholders on common solutions to ramp up the transition in in ISS. AA CCCAAA =AA 19.7 100 0 é17.1 A- D- A éA C- 55.6 0 A+ éC+ 58.5 2023 2024 •Regulators: as part of the policy debate we engage with regulators (local and European) and international standard setters on the initiatives that are most important to the bank, our employees, our customers and the communities we serve. Santander works with the Basel Committee, the Financial Stability Board, the European Banking Authority, the European Central Bank, EU institutions, Banco de España, the Bank of England, and other key actors to set out the sustainable financing framework that boosts support for the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris Climate Agreement targets. As part of this engagement, at the corporate level, the Group responded to 53 consultations during 2024. In addition, Brazil’s presidency of the G20 and the COP30 to be held in Belém in 2025 will provide greater opportunity to work with stakeholders on common solutions to ramp up the transition in
G1-41

Quelle est la valeur monétaire des contributions politiques, financières et en nature apportées directement et indirectement par l'entreprise ? Distinguer le montant total des contributions financières directes, des contributions financières indirectes et des contributions en nature.

Contexte: Pour cette question, nous analysons les activités et politiques de lobbying de l'entreprise. On entend par « contribution politique », l'aide financière ou en nature apportée directement aux partis politiques, à leurs représentants élus ou aux personnes qui briguent une fonction politique. Les contributions financières incluent les dons, les prêts, les parrainages, les avances pour services, ou l'achat de billets pour des événements de collecte de fonds et d'autres pratiques similaires.
Les contributions en nature incluent la publication, l'utilisation d'installations, la conception et l'impression, le don de matériel, l'adhésion à un conseil d'administration, l'emploi ou le travail de consultance pour des responsables politiques élus ou des candidats à un mandat.
Par « contribution politique indirecte », on entend les contributions politiques apportées par l'intermédiaire d'une organisation (de lobbying ou caritative par exemple) ou l'aide apportée à une organisation, par exemple un groupe de réflexion ou une organisation professionnelle proche de certains partis ou de certaines causes politiques, ou qui soutient ces partis/causes.

Consignes: Distinguer le montant total des contributions financières directes, des contributions financières indirectes et des contributions en nature.
Pour chaque type de contribution, indiquer si les données sont disponibles, ainsi que le pays ou la zone géographique et le bénéficiaire de la contribution.
Présenter les données sous forme de tableau, avec les années et les montants respectifs.
Veuillez noter que si ces valeurs ne sont pas affichées, cela peut être interprété comme un signe que l'entreprise ne verse pas de contributions politiques ou d'autres contributions financières liées à l'influence et aux pratiques de lobbying.

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques concernant la valeur monétaire des contributions politiques, financières ou en nature apportées directement ou indirectement par l'entreprise. Selon le contexte, le Grupo Santander n'autorise le financement de partis politiques qu'exceptionnellement et sous certaines conditions, mais aucune donnée chiffrée n'est disponible. En l'absence de ces informations, cela peut être interprété comme un signe que l'entreprise ne verse pas de contributions politiques ou d'autres contributions financières liées à l'influence et aux pratiques de lobbying.
