Sources LLM :
  • ### Data related to employees training Total investment in training Sum of all expenditures accrued in Learning Activities, during the period, including: Direct costs from trainers who are employed as Employees (i.e. Total Compensation prorated for the dedication to training activities), but not including Salaries of Learning and Development Employees, External suppliers / vendors expenses paid and budgeted by the Learning department (for any type of service: training design, training sessions delivery, communications, consulting), logistic and facilities costs (training rooms, catering, accommodation and travel, materials), Labour cost of employees within the Learning Department (actual amounts accrued during the period, including gross compensation - all items-, plus company taxes - contributions, ), IT costs and licenses plus their applicable services; expenditures in Marketing and Communications paid and budgeted by the Learning Department .; Other expenses ### Data related to employees training Total investment in training Sum of all expenditures accrued in Learning Activities, during the period, including: Direct costs from trainers who are employed as Employees (i.e. Total Compensation prorated for the dedication to training activities), but not including Salaries of Learning and Development Employees, External suppliers / vendors expenses paid and budgeted by the Learning department (for any type of service: training design, training sessions delivery, communications, consulting), logistic and facilities costs (training rooms, catering, accommodation and travel, materials), Labour cost of employees within the Learning Department (actual amounts accrued during the period, including gross compensation - all items-, plus company taxes - contributions, ), IT costs and licenses plus their applicable services; expenditures in Marketing and Communications paid and budgeted by the Learning Department .; Other expenses
  • ## Risk management and compliance We collect data on the Group's ethical channels every quarter in relation to the number and type of reports received, and the measures taken. An external auditor reviews those data regularly to ensure their traceability and integrity. In 2024, 4,437 reports were received, including 216 reports from third parties (163 from customers and 53 from vendors). ## Risk management and compliance We collect data on the Group's ethical channels every quarter in relation to the number and type of reports received, and the measures taken. An external auditor reviews those data regularly to ensure their traceability and integrity. In 2024, 4,437 reports were received, including 216 reports from third parties (163 from customers and 53 from vendors).

  • . The numerator and denominator are not symmetric. While the denominator reflects the balance sheet total, the numerator only includes financing in relation to four portfolios: financial institutions; non-financial institutions subject to the CSRD; households (mortgages, auto and renovations); and local governments. Thus, the numerator does not consider green loans to SMEs or the majority of non-European entities. 88 Estimates of future GHG emissions that could arise during the useful life of a company's key assets. The term "key assets" refers to existing or planned assets that a company owns or controls (e.g. fixed or mobile installations and equipment) and that are direct or indirect energy-related sources of GHG emissions. 89 Estimates of future GHG emissions as the direct GHG emissions from the use of products sold throughout their useful life (category 3.11). . Governance & policies, 4.2.1 Conduct standards, and 4.3.1 Canal Abierto We promote transparency, the fight against corruption and robust governance across our organization. We use reporting channels to raise any conduct contrary to tour policies and codes of conduct regulate our business and behaviour.   • These heatmaps are based on the present day and on scenario analysis methods and models that complement our qualitative methodology and provide a forward-looking and geography-based analysis of portfolios across the medium and long term, considering impacts based on their probability, relevance and duration. Although we illustrate these in the table below according to the statistical classification of economic activities in the European Community at level 1 (NACE 1, from the French 'Nomenclature statistique des Activites economiques dans la Communaute Europeenne'-Statistical classification of economic activities in the European Community) breakdown, our sector analysis in risk management goes up to NACE level 4 to monitor the composition of our portfolios, capturing most of our value chain. These heatmaps are based on the present day and on scenario analysis methods and models that complement our qualitative methodology and provide a forward-looking and geography-based analysis of portfolios across the medium and long term, considering impacts based on their probability, relevance and duration. Although we illustrate these in the table below according to the statistical classification of economic activities in the European Community at level 1 (NACE 1, from the French 'Nomenclature statistique des Activites economiques dans la Communaute Europeenne'-Statistical classification of economic activities in the European Community) breakdown, our sector analysis in risk management goes up to NACE level 4 to monitor the composition of our portfolios, capturing most of our value chain.
  • 2 In line with our principles of transparency, honesty and impartiality, Grupo Santander may only finance political parties on an exceptional and arm's length basis, and with approval from the Group executive committee. These standards prohibit making monetary or in-kind donations and contributions to elections. Total or partial debt cancellation for political parties and their affiliates is strictly prohibited. While Grupo Santander may negotiate the terms of any political party debt, the interest rate charged must never fall below the market rate. Santander Annual report 2024 25 2 In line with our principles of transparency, honesty and impartiality, Grupo Santander may only finance political parties on an exceptional and arm's length basis, and with approval from the Group executive committee. These standards prohibit making monetary or in-kind donations and contributions to elections. Total or partial debt cancellation for political parties and their affiliates is strictly prohibited. While Grupo Santander may negotiate the terms of any political party debt, the interest rate charged must never fall below the market rate. Santander Annual report 2024 25
  • Santander has a sensitive issues policy, integrating the activity of donations, as well as a Guide on Community Support and People Helped, inspired by the Business for Societal impact (B4SI) standards. This Guide sets out the methodology for quantifying the contributions that both the parent company and our subsidiaries make. We also have a humanitarian crisis guide that outlines Santander's response to events or disasters with a social impact. Santander has a sensitive issues policy, integrating the activity of donations, as well as a Guide on Community Support and People Helped, inspired by the Business for Societal impact (B4SI) standards. This Guide sets out the methodology for quantifying the contributions that both the parent company and our subsidiaries make. We also have a humanitarian crisis guide that outlines Santander's response to events or disasters with a social impact.
  • ### i. Our approach We support the communities where we operate by helping them address their social needs. Santander's community support focuses on higher education, employability and entrepreneurship, complemented with the support on financial education and to vulnerable people. Moreover, we have a strong track record in supporting cultural and other social initiatives. We make donations and other contributions to projects and initiatives either autonomously or in cooperation with other non- profit organizations and entities that share similar aims. ### i. Our approach We support the communities where we operate by helping them address their social needs. Santander's community support focuses on higher education, employability and entrepreneurship, complemented with the support on financial education and to vulnerable people. Moreover, we have a strong track record in supporting cultural and other social initiatives. We make donations and other contributions to projects and initiatives either autonomously or in cooperation with other non- profit organizations and entities that share similar aims.

Je suis désolé, mais les informations concernant les contributions politiques, financières et en nature apportées directement ou indirectement par l'entreprise ne sont pas disponibles dans les documents fournis. Par conséquent, je ne peux pas fournir de tableau ou de détails sur les montants respectifs pour chaque type de contribution, ni sur les pays ou zones géographiques concernés. Cela peut être interprété comme un signe que l'entreprise ne verse pas de contributions politiques ou d'autres contributions financières liées à l'influence et aux pratiques de lobbying, ou simplement que ces informations ne sont pas divulguées dans les documents analysés.

This Guide sets out the methodology for quantifying the contributions that both the parent company and our subsidiaries make. We also have a humanitarian crisis guide that outlines Santander's response to events or disasters with a social impact.
  • ### i. Our approach We support the communities where we operate by helping them address their social needs. Santander's community support focuses on higher education, employability and entrepreneurship, complemented with the support on financial education and to vulnerable people. Moreover, we have a strong track record in supporting cultural and other social initiatives. We make donations and other contributions to projects and initiatives either autonomously or in cooperation with other non- profit organizations and entities that share similar aims.

  • employed).B 3206,753 employees. EUR 14.3 billion paid in wages and benefits. 4EUR 11.6 billion paid to suppliers. 89% are local and account for 88% of total procurement turnover. 5EUR 10.9 billion in taxes paid by the Group and EUR 11.5 billion in third party taxes channelled to tax authorities. 6EUR 139 billion in green Finance raised and facilitated since 2019, reaching our EUR 120 billion target 18 months early and maintaining our leadership position in the financing of renewable energy projects. 7Additionally, our credit stock in green mortgages and auto (EU taxonomy aligned) grew 27% year over year, supporting the alignment of our portfolios. 8We continue to make progress towards our target of EUR 100 billion of assets under management in SRI (Socially Responsible Investment), reaching EUR 89 billion in 2024. employed).B 3206,753 employees. EUR 14.3 billion paid in wages and benefits. 4EUR 11.6 billion paid to suppliers. 89% are local and account for 88% of total procurement turnover. 5EUR 10.9 billion in taxes paid by the Group and EUR 11.5 billion in third party taxes channelled to tax authorities. 6EUR 139 billion in green Finance raised and facilitated since 2019, reaching our EUR 120 billion target 18 months early and maintaining our leadership position in the financing of renewable energy projects. 7Additionally, our credit stock in green mortgages and auto (EU taxonomy aligned) grew 27% year over year, supporting the alignment of our portfolios. 8We continue to make progress towards our target of EUR 100 billion of assets under management in SRI (Socially Responsible Investment), reaching EUR 89 billion in 2024.

  • financially vulnerable groups; the ‘Santander Natura’ programme, where employees and their families help preserve the environment; and our Pro Bono volunteer programme, where volunteers’ expertise helps solve the challenges that NGOs face so that they can continue to perform their work. •In Mexico, we run numerous volunteering initiatives with a special focus on reforestation and habitat conservation , such as Rally del Ajolote (sporting events and reforestation) and a beach clean-up programme alongside WWF (World Wildlife Fund) México. •Through Santander Tuiio, we delivered financial education sessions in schools to elementary education children on personal finance basic concepts, as well as delivering the financial health book "My first steps in finance". 64 It includes the social contributions of the foundations linked to the Group. financially vulnerable groups; the ‘Santander Natura’ programme, where employees and their families help preserve the environment; and our Pro Bono volunteer programme, where volunteers’ expertise helps solve the challenges that NGOs face so that they can continue to perform their work. •In Mexico, we run numerous volunteering initiatives with a special focus on reforestation and habitat conservation , such as Rally del Ajolote (sporting events and reforestation) and a beach clean-up programme alongside WWF (World Wildlife Fund) México. •Through Santander Tuiio, we delivered financial education sessions in schools to elementary education children on personal finance basic concepts, as well as delivering the financial health book "My first steps in finance". 64 It includes the social contributions of the foundations linked to the Group.
G1-33

Quelles sont les mesures prises pour remédier au non-respect des procédures et des normes en matière de lutte contre la corruption? Par exemple mesures de détection, mesures de remédiation et à l'engagement continu en matière de lutte anti-corruption.

Toute mesure prise pour remédier au non-respect des procédures et des normes en matière de lutte contre la corruption.

Les mesures prises pour remédier au non-respect des procédures et des normes en matière de lutte contre la corruption comprennent plusieurs actions détaillées dans les documents fournis :

  1. Programme d'Anti-Bribery and Corruption (ABC) : En 2024, l'entreprise a continué à mettre en œuvre son programme ABC, qui est soumis à une révision constante pour s'assurer qu'il reste en ligne avec les autres politiques de l'organisation (Context Num-1).

  2. Systèmes de Détection et Gestion d'Incidents FCC : Les unités de renseignement financier dans tous les marchés de l'entreprise disposent de systèmes robustes pour détecter, enquêter, répondre et informer les autorités des transactions suspectes liées à la corruption. Ces systèmes incluent des contrôles internes et des comités d'enquête indépendants pour garantir une gestion impartiale des incidents (Context Num-2).

  3. Canaux de Signalement et Canal Abierto : L'organisation promeut la transparence et utilise des canaux de signalement pour relever toute conduite contraire aux politiques et codes de conduite. Le Canal Abierto permet de signaler les violations des lois et des règlements internes concernant la lutte contre la criminalité financière (Context Num-3 et Num-7).

  4. Gestion des Risques et Conformité : Des données sont collectées régulièrement sur les canaux éthiques de l'organisation, et un auditeur externe les examine pour en garantir la traçabilité et l'intégrité. En 2024, 4,437 rapports ont été reçus, dont certains concernaient la corruption, menant à des mesures disciplinaires (Context Num-4).

  5. Certification et Évaluation des Fournisseurs : L'organisation dispose d'un outil d'entreprise pour certifier les fournisseurs à risque élevé et évaluer les risques clés, y compris la corruption et la lutte contre la corruption (Context Num-6).

  6. Plans de Remédiation pour les Fournisseurs : Des plans de remédiation sont mis en place pour aider les fournisseurs à se conformer aux cadres réglementaires ESG domestiques, européens et internationaux (Context Num-8).

Ces mesures montrent l'engagement de l'organisation à détecter, gérer et remédier les incidents de corruption de manière proactive et structurée.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • ### Bribery and corruption In 2024, we continued to implement our ABC programme, which is also subject to constant review and update in line with the rest of our policies. We conduct a risk and control self-assessment (RCSA) in all our subsidiaries and units to identify residual risk within the organization. ### Bribery and corruption In 2024, we continued to implement our ABC programme, which is also subject to constant review and update in line with the rest of our policies. We conduct a risk and control self-assessment (RCSA) in all our subsidiaries and units to identify residual risk within the organization.
  • ### Detecting and managing FCC incidents Per FCC laws, the financial intelligence units in all our markets have a robust system to detect, investigate, respond to and inform the authorities of suspicious transactions in terms of FCC (including those with indications of bribery or corruption). This system includes internal controls, lines of action and independent investigation committees that operate outside of the chain of command to preserve impartial incident management. The findings of these investigations are reported regularly to the Group's management and oversight bodies. Highlights of key activities related to detection and cooperation with authorities activities in 2024 include: ### Detecting and managing FCC incidents Per FCC laws, the financial intelligence units in all our markets have a robust system to detect, investigate, respond to and inform the authorities of suspicious transactions in terms of FCC (including those with indications of bribery or corruption). This system includes internal controls, lines of action and independent investigation committees that operate outside of the chain of command to preserve impartial incident management. The findings of these investigations are reported regularly to the Group's management and oversight bodies. Highlights of key activities related to detection and cooperation with authorities activities in 2024 include:

Governance & policies, 4.2.1 Conduct standards, and 4.3.1 Canal Abierto We promote transparency, the fight against corruption and robust governance across our organization. We use reporting channels to raise any conduct contrary to tour policies and codes of conduct regulate our business and behaviour.   • ## Risk management and compliance We collect data on the Group's ethical channels every quarter in relation to the number and type of reports received, and the measures taken. An external auditor reviews those data regularly to ensure their traceability and integrity. In 2024, 4,437 reports were received, including 216 reports from third parties (163 from customers and 53 from vendors). ## Risk management and compliance We collect data on the Group's ethical channels every quarter in relation to the number and type of reports received, and the measures taken. An external auditor reviews those data regularly to ensure their traceability and integrity. In 2024, 4,437 reports were received, including 216 reports from third parties (163 from customers and 53 from vendors).

Los encabezados de las columnas son: "Nuclear energy related activities", "CCM+CCA", "CCM", y "CCA", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%".   • ### Resumen de la tabla "Gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento" del informe anual de Santander 2024: 1. **Etiquetas de columnas**: "Risk type", "Climate1 and environmental drivers", "Time horizon analysed", "Potential Impact of climate and environmental risk factors", "What we're doing to manage climate and environmental risk", "Next steps". 2. **Riesgo de mercado**: Analizado en el corto plazo, incluye impactos como alta volatilidad en factores de mercado, cambios en la percepción del mercado y condiciones climáticas extremas que afectan los planes de negocio. Acciones incluyen revisiones regulares de escenarios de estrés climático y análisis de exposición de la cartera de trading. Próximos pasos: mejorar las pruebas de estrés y adaptarlas a las mejores prácticas del mercado. 3. **Riesgo de liquidez**: Evaluado en el corto plazo, considera impactos como la reducción del valor de activos líquidos de alta calidad (HQLAs) y mayores salidas de efectivo debido a percepciones de mercado. Acciones incluyen análisis cualitativos y cuantitativos de escenarios climáticos. Próximos pasos: incluir nuevos escenarios de liquidez en las pruebas de estrés. 4. **Riesgo operativo**: Analizado en el corto, mediano y largo plazo, abarca eventos climáticos severos que dañan activos y afectan la continuidad del negocio, así como pérdidas por litigios o incumplimientos de estándares ESG. Acciones incluyen controles de autoevaluación de riesgos operativos relacionados con ESG, análisis de escenarios de riesgo extremo y evaluación de amenazas climáticas en la continuidad del negocio. 5. **Próximos pasos en riesgo operativo**: Mejorar los reportes de riesgos operativos relacionados con el clima, promover la cooperación en la industria para compartir datos y mejores prácticas, y trabajar con el equipo de seguros corporativos para analizar la asegurabilidad de las pérdidas relacionadas con el clima. 6. **Otras acciones en riesgo operativo**: Evaluación de materialidad de riesgos operativos relacionados con el clima, actualización de documentación y capacitación sobre factores ESG, e inclusión de una bandera ESG en la base de datos de eventos de riesgo operativo. and

    Risk management and compliance

    - More frequent extreme weather that stifles economic growth in countries susceptible to climate change, causing sovereign debt to rise and limiting access to capital markets. exposed companies. - Analysis of higher outflows due to changes in market perception of corporations in climate-sensitive business activities. them in the exercise. + Adapt stress testing to best market practices, including new liquidity scenarios to measure their impact.
    > Cash outflows from companies trying to boost their reputation in the market or solve problems with climate scenarios. - Extreme weather conditions could cause financial impact on companies operating in the affected sectors impacting the funds deposited in the bank.
    Operational Short - medium - long term + Severe climate events can cause damage to our assets, including branches, data centers, headquarters and other owned or rented properties. Impacts on our own or our suppliers' premises can also affect business continuity. + Conducting operational risk and self- assessment controls that include ESG- related risks to evaluate our exposure. > Conducting mandatory operational risk scenario analysis that cover extreme physical and transition risk events. - Enhance operational risk reporting on climate and environmental - related factors. > Promote cooperation within the industry to
    > Climate and environmental - related factors can also lead to operational risk losses from litigation, claims due to inadequate sales or non-compliance with ESG standards. -> Including an ESG flag in the operational risk events database to identify events and losses from climate-related and environmental risks. > Including an assessment of climate threats in business continuity scenarios. share data, scenarios and best practices on climate-related operational risk management. > Work with the Corporate Insurance team to conduct analyses on the insurability of climate-related losses.
    + Conducting a materiality assessment on climate-related operational risk.
    + Updating documentation and delivering training relating to the embedding of ESG factors across operational risk management, as well as sharing best practices throughout the Group.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla La tabla presenta los "Temas" y el "Alcance de la información" en el informe anual de Santander 2024. Los temas incluyen: 1. **Clima, nuestro plan de transición (Información ambiental)**: - Apoyo a los clientes en la transición verde. - Finanzas verdes: Alcance en Banca Corporativa y de Inversión. - Financiamiento de vehículos eléctricos: Portafolio de préstamos de auto del Banco Digital de Consumo. - Compra de tarjetas de materiales sostenibles e integración de ESG en la gestión de riesgos: Principales empresas del Grupo en Argentina, Brasil, Chile, México, Polonia, Portugal, España, Reino Unido y Uruguay. - Exposición del portafolio a sectores climáticos: Alcance completo del Grupo. - Principios del Ecuador: Alcance en Banca Corporativa y de Inversión. - Alineación con los objetivos del Acuerdo de París. - Alineación climática: Alcance en Banca Corporativa y de Inversión para varios sectores, Banco Digital de Consumo para préstamos de auto, banca comercial en Brasil para el portafolio agro, y banca comercial en España y Reino Unido para hipotecas residenciales y bienes raíces. - Huella ambiental: Alcance completo del Grupo, excepto emisiones de Alcance 3, que incluyen información de las principales empresas en múltiples países y geografías del Banco Digital de Consumo. - Taxonomía de la UE y Ratio de Activos Verdes (GAR): Alcance basado en el grupo consolidado prudencial según la Regulación Delegada de la Comisión (UE) 2021/2178. 2. **Apoyo a empleados, comunidades y clientes (Información social)**: - Actuar responsablemente hacia los empleados. - Plantilla: Alcance completo del Grupo (excepto datos de accidentes en Santander Polska S.A.). - Remuneración: Alcance completo del Grupo. and

    Remuneration Full Group scope
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la proporción de exposiciones alineadas con la Taxonomía y su desglose según diferentes criterios. Je ne dispose pas d'informations spécifiques sur les mesures prises pour remédier au non-respect des procédures et des normes en matière de lutte contre la corruption dans les documents fournis. Les documents mentionnent des programmes de sensibilisation, des formations, des systèmes de détection et des canaux de dénonciation pour lutter contre la corruption, mais ils ne détaillent pas les mesures spécifiques de remédiation en cas de non-respect.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Bribery and corruption In 2024, we continued to implement our ABC programme, which is also subject to constant review and update in line with the rest of our policies. We conduct a risk and control self-assessment (RCSA) in all our subsidiaries and units to identify residual risk within the organization.
  • ### Detecting and managing FCC incidents Per FCC laws, the financial intelligence units in all our markets have a robust system to detect, investigate, respond to and inform the authorities of suspicious transactions in terms of FCC (including those with indications of bribery or corruption). This system includes internal controls, lines of action and independent investigation committees that operate outside of the chain of command to preserve impartial incident management. The findings of these investigations are reported regularly to the Group's management and oversight bodies. Highlights of key activities related to detection and cooperation with authorities activities in 2024 include:
  • ### Principle 10 Businesses should work against corruption in all its forms, including extortion and bribery. 2 For more details, see sections 2.5.2. Governance & policies, 4.2.1 Conduct standards, and 4.3.1 Canal Abierto We promote transparency, the fight against corruption and robust governance across our organization. We use reporting channels to raise any conduct contrary to tour policies and codes of conduct regulate our business and behaviour. Santander Annual report 2024 225
  • ## Risk management and compliance We collect data on the Group's ethical channels every quarter in relation to the number and type of reports received, and the measures taken. An external auditor reviews those data regularly to ensure their traceability and integrity. In 2024, 4,437 reports were received, including 216 reports from third parties (163 from customers and 53 from vendors).

The Group received 14 reports in 2024 regarding corruption, which led to 3 dismissals. D. In accordance with the established criteria", the Group: · has no record of any judicial proceedings in relation to incidents of discrimination or violation of fundamental rights. · has no record of cases involving employees that refer to serious human rights incidents.

  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento" del informe anual de Santander 2024: 1. **Etiquetas de columnas**: "Risk type", "Climate1 and environmental drivers", "Time horizon analysed", "Potential Impact of climate and environmental risk factors", "What we're doing to manage climate and environmental risk", "Next steps". 2. **Riesgo de mercado**: Analizado en el corto plazo, incluye impactos como alta volatilidad en factores de mercado, cambios en la percepción del mercado y condiciones climáticas extremas que afectan los planes de negocio. Acciones incluyen revisiones regulares de escenarios de estrés climático y análisis de exposición de la cartera de trading. Próximos pasos: mejorar las pruebas de estrés y adaptarlas a las mejores prácticas del mercado. 3. **Riesgo de liquidez**: Evaluado en el corto plazo, considera impactos como la reducción del valor de activos líquidos de alta calidad (HQLAs) y mayores salidas de efectivo debido a percepciones de mercado. Acciones incluyen análisis cualitativos y cuantitativos de escenarios climáticos. Próximos pasos: incluir nuevos escenarios de liquidez en las pruebas de estrés. 4. **Riesgo operativo**: Analizado en el corto, mediano y largo plazo, abarca eventos climáticos severos que dañan activos y afectan la continuidad del negocio, así como pérdidas por litigios o incumplimientos de estándares ESG. Acciones incluyen controles de autoevaluación de riesgos operativos relacionados con ESG, análisis de escenarios de riesgo extremo y evaluación de amenazas climáticas en la continuidad del negocio. 5. **Próximos pasos en riesgo operativo**: Mejorar los reportes de riesgos operativos relacionados con el clima, promover la cooperación en la industria para compartir datos y mejores prácticas, y trabajar con el equipo de seguros corporativos para analizar la asegurabilidad de las pérdidas relacionadas con el clima. 6. **Otras acciones en riesgo operativo**: Evaluación de materialidad de riesgos operativos relacionados con el clima, actualización de documentación y capacitación sobre factores ESG, e inclusión de una bandera ESG en la base de datos de eventos de riesgo operativo.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla La tabla presenta los "Temas" y el "Alcance de la información" en el informe anual de Santander 2024. Los temas incluyen: 1. **Clima, nuestro plan de transición (Información ambiental)**: - Apoyo a los clientes en la transición verde. - Finanzas verdes: Alcance en Banca Corporativa y de Inversión. - Financiamiento de vehículos eléctricos: Portafolio de préstamos de auto del Banco Digital de Consumo. - Compra de tarjetas de materiales sostenibles e integración de ESG en la gestión de riesgos: Principales empresas del Grupo en Argentina, Brasil, Chile, México, Polonia, Portugal, España, Reino Unido y Uruguay. - Exposición del portafolio a sectores climáticos: Alcance completo del Grupo. - Principios del Ecuador: Alcance en Banca Corporativa y de Inversión. - Alineación con los objetivos del Acuerdo de París. - Alineación climática: Alcance en Banca Corporativa y de Inversión para varios sectores, Banco Digital de Consumo para préstamos de auto, banca comercial en Brasil para el portafolio agro, y banca comercial en España y Reino Unido para hipotecas residenciales y bienes raíces. - Huella ambiental: Alcance completo del Grupo, excepto emisiones de Alcance 3, que incluyen información de las principales empresas en múltiples países y geografías del Banco Digital de Consumo. - Taxonomía de la UE y Ratio de Activos Verdes (GAR): Alcance basado en el grupo consolidado prudencial según la Regulación Delegada de la Comisión (UE) 2021/2178. 2. **Apoyo a empleados, comunidades y clientes (Información social)**: - Actuar responsablemente hacia los empleados. - Plantilla: Alcance completo del Grupo (excepto datos de accidentes en Santander Polska S.A.). - Remuneración: Alcance completo del Grupo.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la proporción de exposiciones alineadas con la Taxonomía y su desglose según diferentes criterios. Los datos están organizados en columnas y filas con los siguientes detalles: 1. **Proporción de exposiciones alineadas con la Taxonomía**: - **Para empresas no financieras**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: 0.5% (47 millones de euros). - Basado en gastos de capital: 0.9% (74 millones de euros). - **Para empresas financieras**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: 0.9% (78 millones de euros). - Basado en gastos de capital: 1.2% (103 millones de euros). 2. **Proporción de inversiones de aseguradoras o reaseguradoras alineadas con la Taxonomía**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: * (valor no especificado). - Basado en gastos de capital: * (valor no especificado). 3. **Proporción de exposiciones a otros contrapartes y activos**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: 0% (0 millones de euros). - Basado en gastos de capital: 0% (0 millones de euros). 4. **Desglose del numerador del KPI por objetivo ambiental**: - **Actividades alineadas con la Taxonomía**: - Mitigación del cambio climático: volumen de negocios 1.4%, gastos de capital 2.0%. - Adaptación al cambio climático: volumen de negocios 0.0%, gastos de capital 0.0%. - **Actividades transicionales**: - Volumen de negocios: 0.0%. - Gastos de capital: 0.1%. - **Actividades habilitadoras**: - Volumen de negocios: 0.7%. - Gastos de capital: 0.7%.

Les mesures prises pour remédier au non-respect des procédures et des normes en matière de lutte contre la corruption comprennent plusieurs actions détaillées dans les documents fournis :

  1. Programme d'Anti-Bribery and Corruption (ABC) : En 2024, l'entreprise a continué à mettre en œuvre son programme ABC, qui est soumis à une révision constante pour s'assurer qu'il reste en ligne avec les autres politiques de l'organisation (Context Num-1).

  2. Systèmes de Détection et Gestion d'Incidents FCC : Les unités de renseignement financier dans tous les marchés de l'entreprise disposent de systèmes robustes pour détecter, enquêter, répondre et informer les autorités des transactions suspectes liées à la corruption. Ces systèmes incluent des contrôles internes et des comités d'enquête indépendants pour garantir une gestion impartiale des incidents (Context Num-2).

  3. Canaux de Signalement et Canal Abierto : L'organisation promeut la transparence et utilise des canaux de signalement pour relever toute conduite contraire aux politiques et codes de conduite. Le Canal Abierto permet de signaler les violations des lois et des règlements internes concernant la lutte contre la criminalité financière (Context Num-3 et Num-7).

  4. Gestion des Risques et Conformité : Des données sont collectées régulièrement sur les canaux éthiques de l'organisation, et un auditeur externe les examine pour en garantir la traçabilité et l'intégrité. En 2024, 4,437 rapports ont été reçus, dont certains concernaient la corruption, menant à des mesures disciplinaires (Context Num-4).

  5. Certification et Évaluation des Fournisseurs : L'organisation dispose d'un outil d'entreprise pour certifier les fournisseurs à risque élevé et évaluer les risques clés, y compris la corruption et la lutte contre la corruption (Context Num-6).

  6. Plans de Remédiation pour les Fournisseurs : Des plans de remédiation sont mis en place pour aider les fournisseurs à se conformer aux cadres réglementaires ESG domestiques, européens et internationaux (Context Num-8).

Ces mesures montrent l'engagement de l'organisation à détecter, gérer et remédier les incidents de corruption de manière proactive et structurée.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • programmes: the anti-money laundering and terrorism financing prevention programme (AML/CFT); the sanctions programme; and, since 2023, the anti-bribery and anti-corruption programme (ABC). This framework is available to all employees and interested third parties. Moreover, we use information channels to raise awareness of the importance of financial crime compliance. We reach out to all our stakeholders through annual training programmes,communications channels (corporate and subsidiary Intranet sites), awareness campaigns, internal newsletters and best practices so that they can learn about and understand their responsibilities across the Group’s entire operations. The policies that build on this framework (including customer due diligence — CDD — procedures) are designed according to domestic and international financial crime regulation to manage and mitigate the impacts and risks related to FCC and protect the Group’s integrity in all our businesses and operations.   • our policies. We conduct a risk and control self-assessment (RCSA) in all our subsidiaries and units to identify residual risk within the organization. It involves assessing the inherent risks of our business activities in terms of financial crime, with money laundering and terrorism financing key factors and bribery and corruption also factors that we consider. Marketing, Sponsorships, Vendor Management and Human Resources are the areas with the highest exposure to the ABC risk taxonomy. In 2024, we continued to enhance our awareness strategy, which is based on the programmes included under our corporate framework, by combining basic training with customized programmes. Throughout the year, we ran technical sessions, FCC risk awareness workshops, courses on ABC risks for procurement staff, and specialized training for board members. Thus the Group’s annual programmes cover FCC risks sufficiently. Our training plans, which we supplement with compliance our policies. We conduct a risk and control self-assessment (RCSA) in all our subsidiaries and units to identify residual risk within the organization. It involves assessing the inherent risks of our business activities in terms of financial crime, with money laundering and terrorism financing key factors and bribery and corruption also factors that we consider. Marketing, Sponsorships, Vendor Management and Human Resources are the areas with the highest exposure to the ABC risk taxonomy. In 2024, we continued to enhance our awareness strategy, which is based on the programmes included under our corporate framework, by combining basic training with customized programmes. Throughout the year, we ran technical sessions, FCC risk awareness workshops, courses on ABC risks for procurement staff, and specialized training for board members. Thus the Group’s annual programmes cover FCC risks sufficiently. Our training plans, which we supplement with compliance
  • CEO endorsement; communication to employees of the importance of using the channel; information on how incidents have been handled and lessons learned; easy access to the channel and anonymity (if desired); external platforms to receive reports according to best practice; mechanisms to manage conflicts of interest in internal investigations of reports; and regular internal audits. The board of directors approved the Canal Abierto policy and the related usage and operation procedure, and brought the Banco Santander channel under the Chief Compliance Officer's direct remit. These policies and procedures are available to Group employees and stakeholders on our corporate website and the Canal Abierto platform. Canal Abierto is available to employees on Santander Now (Intranet) and to any Banco Santander stakeholder through our corporate website and the Canal Abierto platform. Canal Abierto is mainly set up to receive reports from employees; CEO endorsement; communication to employees of the importance of using the channel; information on how incidents have been handled and lessons learned; easy access to the channel and anonymity (if desired); external platforms to receive reports according to best practice; mechanisms to manage conflicts of interest in internal investigations of reports; and regular internal audits. The board of directors approved the Canal Abierto policy and the related usage and operation procedure, and brought the Banco Santander channel under the Chief Compliance Officer's direct remit. These policies and procedures are available to Group employees and stakeholders on our corporate website and the Canal Abierto platform. Canal Abierto is available to employees on Santander Now (Intranet) and to any Banco Santander stakeholder through our corporate website and the Canal Abierto platform. Canal Abierto is mainly set up to receive reports from employees;

  • Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A. As in the rest of this chapter, we only include information about our employees. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A.   • sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable. sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) .   • shares are meant to help the foundation financially; it can use the dividends to cover some (if not all) of the cost of fulfilling its founding purposes.66 These include managing the bank's art collection and financing numerous literary, educational, social, cultural and environmental productions and activities, in which the remodelling of the Santander's headquarters on Paseo de Pereda in Santander and our relations with universities in Spain will play an important role. For more details, visit the website fundacionbancosantander.com/es/ fundacion/transparencia. We have other Santander foundations in countries where we operate (Argentina, the US, Mexico, Portugal, Poland and the UK), which boost the number of initiatives we run. Their focus varies according to local needs; for instance, in Argentina on art and culture; in Portugal on education, inclusion and culture; and in Poland on education for children and young people. E1-124

Quelles sont les émissions totales du Scope 2, calculées grâce à la méthode "location-based" ?

nan

Les émissions totales du Scope 2, calculées selon la méthode "location-based", sont de 22,000 tCO2e selon le Contexte Num-1, et de 194,276 tCO2e pour l'année 2024 selon le Contexte Num-3.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • ### Resumen de la tabla La tabla presenta datos relacionados con las emisiones de carbono en tres categorías: "Scope 1 (tCO2e)", "Scope 2 location-based (tCO2e)" y "Scope 2 market-based (tCO2e)", organizados por el "Alignment lever". 1. En la categoría "i. Renewable energy and self-production measures", se reportan 2,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 9,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 2. En la categoría "ii. Energy efficiency and consumption reduction measures", se reportan 1,600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 20,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 3,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 3. En la categoría "iii. Direct emissions reduction measure", se reportan 600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", sin datos para las otras dos columnas. 4. El total de emisiones es de 2,200 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 22,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 12,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1 2 3
    Alignment lever Scope 1 (tCO2e) Scope 2 location- based (tCO2e) Scope 2 market- based (tCO2e)
    i. Renewable energy and self-production measures 2,000 9,000
    ii. Energy efficiency and consumption reduction measures 1,600 20,000 3,000
    iii. Direct emissions reduction measure 600
    Total 2,200 22,000 12,000

  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on "Gross scopes 1, 2, 3 and total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions)" across various years and categories. It includes the following labels, columns, and rows: **Labels:** - Retrospective - Milestones and target years - Annual Target % / Base Year **Columns:** - Base year (2020) - Comparative (2023) - N (2024) - % N / N-1 - 2025 2030 - 2050 **Rows:** 1. **Scope 1 GHG emissions A,B:** Gross scope 1 GHG emissions (tCO2e) decreased from 35,962 in 2020 to 25,755 in 2023, with a projected increase to 35,503 in 2024. 2. **Scope 2 GHG emissions A,C:** Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) dropped from 297,621 in 2020 to 205,292 in 2023, with a further decrease to 194,276 in 2024. Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) fell significantly from 144,038 in 2020 to 21,516 in 2023, with a slight increase to 24,350 in 2024. 3. **Significant scope 3 GHG emissions:** Total Gross indirect (Scope 3) GHG emissions (tCO2e) were 125,441 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,116,061 in 2024. Categories include Purchased goods and services (698,768 in 2024), Capital goods (216,388 in 2024), Upstream transportation and distribution (52,835 in 2024), Business travel (50,061 in 2023, 52,150 in 2024), Employee commuting (75,380 in 2023, 82,569 in 2024), and Downstream transportation (13,350 in 2024). 4. **Total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions):** Total GHG emissions (location-based) (tCO2e) were 356,488 in 2023 and are projected to increase to 1,345,841 in 2024. Total GHG emissions (market-based) (tCO2e) were 172,711 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,175,915 in 2024. The table also includes annual target percentages relative to the base year (2020). and

  • C. These emissions include those derived from electricity consumption and the use of district heating and correspond to Scope 2 defined by the GHG Protocol standard. In 2024 they have been calculated with emission factors of the 2024 edition of the IEA, for 2023 the emission factors of the 2023 edition were used. For the calculation of district heating in Poland and Norway, local public emission factors for 2024 different from DEFRA were used. Data on biogenic emissions is not included as information on these emissions is not available in the EIA emission factor database. · Indirect emissions Electricity - market-based: For the calculation of these emissions, only renewable electricity is considered as renewable electricity that can be certified by any type of contract or product recognized as such, but not the share of the country energy mix obtained from IEA data (i.e. where non-renewable electricity is purchased expressly). For the calculation of district heating in Poland and Norway, local public emission factors for 2024 different from DEFRA were used. Data on biogenic emissions is not included as information on these emissions is not available in the EIA emission factor database. · Indirect emissions Electricity - market-based: For the calculation of these emissions, only renewable electricity is considered as renewable electricity that can be certified by any type of contract or product recognized as such, but not the share of the country energy mix obtained from IEA data (i.e. where non-renewable electricity is purchased expressly).

The total absolute financed emissions (scope 3, categories 15 and 13) of this broad scope, including scope 1, 2 and 3 are 283.8 mtCO2e. And the total GHG emissions (market-based) are 285.0 mtCO2e. With this figure, the ratio of "GHG total emissions / Total income" is: 4.6 mtCO2e/bn€ (Total income figure as disclosed in the Consolidated Income Statements). Santander Annual report 2024 136 J.   • Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030.   • D. The assessment we conducted to determine the materiality of indirect GHG emissions (scope 3) found that the only material category under this scope was category 3.15 (financed emissions), with a weighting of 99% of the total .. The other categories are identified as not relevant, given its low representativeness. In addition, the categories disclosed in this table are defined as relevant, and the following categories are identified as not relevant, given their low representativeness: 3.3 - Fuel and energy-related activities (not included in Scope 1 or 2); 3.5 - waste generated in operations; 3.8 - upstream leased assets; 3.10 - processing of sold products; 3.11 - use of sold products; 3.12 - end-of-life treatment of sold products; 3.14 - franchises. Biogenic emissions are not included as information on these emissions is not available in the databases we use to calculate any of the categories. D.   • ### Scope This chapter covers the core activities of Banco Santander and its subsidiaries from 1 January to 31 December 2024 (for more details, see Notes 1, 2, 3 and 53 to the consolidated financial statements and sections 3 and 4 in the 'Economic and financial review' chapter). The scope of information and changes in criteria applied with respect to the 2023 Sustainability Report, when significant, are reflected in each relevant section and generally in the 'Sustainability note 1' of this chapter. ### Scope This chapter covers the core activities of Banco Santander and its subsidiaries from 1 January to 31 December 2024 (for more details, see Notes 1, 2, 3 and 53 to the consolidated financial statements and sections 3 and 4 in the 'Economic and financial review' chapter). The scope of information and changes in criteria applied with respect to the 2023 Sustainability Report, when significant, are reflected in each relevant section and generally in the 'Sustainability note 1' of this chapter.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta datos financieros y de sostenibilidad para el año 2023, expresados en millones de euros. Los activos totales para el cálculo de GAR (Green Asset Ratio) ascienden a 1,288,300 millones EUR, de los cuales 464,201 millones están relacionados con sectores relevantes para la taxonomía (Taxonomy-eligible), y 31,142 millones son ambientalmente sostenibles (Taxonomy-aligned). Los activos no cubiertos para el cálculo de GAR suman 545,242 millones EUR, mientras que los activos totales alcanzan 1,833,542 millones EUR. Se desglosan categorías como "Préstamos y anticipos" (139,095 millones EUR), "Préstamos garantizados por propiedades comerciales" (22,909 millones EUR), "Préstamos para renovación de edificios" (141 millones EUR), "Instrumentos de deuda" (2,140 millones EUR), "Instrumentos de capital" (155 millones EUR), y "Derivados" (5,421 millones EUR). Además, los activos bajo gestión suman 137,531 millones EUR, con 4,302 millones relacionados con sectores relevantes para la taxonomía y 825 millones ambientalmente sostenibles. Los activos de contrapartes de países no pertenecientes a la UE ascienden a 296,567 millones EUR, mientras que las exposiciones fuera de balance incluyen garantías financieras por 15,573 millones EUR y activos bajo gestión por 137,531 millones EUR. Finalmente, los activos totales relacionados con GAR incluyen 464,675 millones EUR hacia sectores relevantes para la taxonomía y 31,151 millones EUR ambientalmente sostenibles. and

Les émissions totales du Scope 2, calculées grâce à la méthode "location-based", sont de 297,621 tCO2e.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Resumen de la tabla La tabla presenta datos relacionados con las emisiones de carbono en tres categorías: "Scope 1 (tCO2e)", "Scope 2 location-based (tCO2e)" y "Scope 2 market-based (tCO2e)", organizados por el "Alignment lever". 1. En la categoría "i. Renewable energy and self-production measures", se reportan 2,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 9,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 2. En la categoría "ii. Energy efficiency and consumption reduction measures", se reportan 1,600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 20,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 3,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 3. En la categoría "iii. Direct emissions reduction measure", se reportan 600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", sin datos para las otras dos columnas. 4. El total de emisiones es de 2,200 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 22,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 12,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based".
  • ### 2024 environmental footprint The table provides data on renewable electricity, energy consumption, and emissions for 2024. It highlights "96% renewable electricity in 10 core countries where we are present" and "1,012,554 MWh energy consumption." Emissions are categorized into "Scope 1" and "Scope 2." Scope 1 includes "35,503 t CO2e direct emissions," while Scope 2 accounts for "24,350 t CO2e indirect emissions from electricity and other (market based)."
  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on "Gross scopes 1, 2, 3 and total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions)" across various years and categories. It includes the following labels, columns, and rows: **Labels:** - Retrospective - Milestones and target years - Annual Target % / Base Year **Columns:** - Base year (2020) - Comparative (2023) - N (2024) - % N / N-1 - 2025 2030 - 2050 **Rows:** 1. **Scope 1 GHG emissions A,B:** Gross scope 1 GHG emissions (tCO2e) decreased from 35,962 in 2020 to 25,755 in 2023, with a projected increase to 35,503 in 2024. 2. **Scope 2 GHG emissions A,C:** Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) dropped from 297,621 in 2020 to 205,292 in 2023, with a further decrease to 194,276 in 2024. Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) fell significantly from 144,038 in 2020 to 21,516 in 2023, with a slight increase to 24,350 in 2024. 3. **Significant scope 3 GHG emissions:** Total Gross indirect (Scope 3) GHG emissions (tCO2e) were 125,441 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,116,061 in 2024. Categories include Purchased goods and services (698,768 in 2024), Capital goods (216,388 in 2024), Upstream transportation and distribution (52,835 in 2024), Business travel (50,061 in 2023, 52,150 in 2024), Employee commuting (75,380 in 2023, 82,569 in 2024), and Downstream transportation (13,350 in 2024). 4. **Total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions):** Total GHG emissions (location-based) (tCO2e) were 356,488 in 2023 and are projected to increase to 1,345,841 in 2024. Total GHG emissions (market-based) (tCO2e) were 172,711 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,175,915 in 2024. The table also includes annual target percentages relative to the base year (2020).
  • C. These emissions include those derived from electricity consumption and the use of district heating and correspond to Scope 2 defined by the GHG Protocol standard. In 2024 they have been calculated with emission factors of the 2024 edition of the IEA, for 2023 the emission factors of the 2023 edition were used. For the calculation of district heating in Poland and Norway, local public emission factors for 2024 different from DEFRA were used. Data on biogenic emissions is not included as information on these emissions is not available in the EIA emission factor database. · Indirect emissions Electricity - market-based: For the calculation of these emissions, only renewable electricity is considered as renewable electricity that can be certified by any type of contract or product recognized as such, but not the share of the country energy mix obtained from IEA data (i.e. where non-renewable electricity is purchased expressly).
  • J. To comply with the regulatory requirements we have extended the financed emissions calculations, in most cases based on factors and other proxies. More details see table below 3.2. The total absolute financed emissions (scope 3, categories 15 and 13) of this broad scope, including scope 1, 2 and 3 are 283.8 mtCO2e. And the total GHG emissions (market-based) are 285.0 mtCO2e. With this figure, the ratio of "GHG total emissions / Total income" is: 4.6 mtCO2e/bn€ (Total income figure as disclosed in the Consolidated Income Statements). Santander Annual report 2024 136
  • Indirect Emissions Electricity - location-based: The IEA emission factor for each country has been applied for all electricity purchased, regardless of its source of origin (renewable or non-renewable). The indirect emissions in tCO2e disaggregated by country are: · Market-based: Argentina 441, Brazil 115, Chile 44, Germany 2,008, Mexico 1,613, Nordics 8, Poland 12,021, Portugal 309, Spain 1,371, UK 1,103, USA 0, Others 5,316. · Location-based: Argentina 12,444, Brazil 17,577, Chile 7,350, Germany 5,824, Mexico 51,629, Nordics 36, Poland 26,826, Portugal 3,041, Spain 29,338, UK 16,408, USA 18,486, Others 5,316.
  • Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected.
  • D. The assessment we conducted to determine the materiality of indirect GHG emissions (scope 3) found that the only material category under this scope was category 3.15 (financed emissions), with a weighting of 99% of the total .. The other categories are identified as not relevant, given its low representativeness. In addition, the categories disclosed in this table are defined as relevant, and the following categories are identified as not relevant, given their low representativeness: 3.3 - Fuel and energy-related activities (not included in Scope 1 or 2); 3.5 - waste generated in operations; 3.8 - upstream leased assets; 3.10 - processing of sold products; 3.11 - use of sold products; 3.12 - end-of-life treatment of sold products; 3.14 - franchises. Biogenic emissions are not included as information on these emissions is not available in the databases we use to calculate any of the categories.

Las columnas incluyen los valores "CCM+CCA", "CCM", y "CCA", cada una con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". En las filas 1, 2, 4, 5 y 6, los montos y proporciones son "0" y "0.0%".   • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: 1. La tabla presenta datos en porcentaje (%), comparados con el total de activos cubiertos en el denominador, para el año 2024. 2. Las categorías principales son "Climate Change Mitigation (CCM)", "Climate Change Adaptation (CCA)" y "TOTAL (CCM + CCA)". 3. Se desglosan sectores relevantes según la taxonomía: "Taxonomy-eligible" y "Taxonomy-aligned", incluyendo subcategorías como "Of which Use of Proceeds", "Of which transitional" y "Of which enabling". 4. Para "Local governments financing", el porcentaje total es 83.4%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.1% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 5. En "Housing financing", el porcentaje total es 99.1%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.0% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 6. "Other local government financing" tiene un porcentaje total de 81.0%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.1% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 7. Los "Collateral obtained by taking possession: residential and commercial immovable properties" tienen un 0.0% en todas las categorías, con un 0.3% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 8. "Total GAR assets" presenta un 34.2% total, con un 3.3% "Taxonomy-aligned", desglosado en 2.8% "Use of Proceeds", 0.7% "transitional" y 0.2% "enabling", y un 69.8% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos.
  • ### Scope This chapter covers the core activities of Banco Santander and its subsidiaries from 1 January to 31 December 2024 (for more details, see Notes 1, 2, 3 and 53 to the consolidated financial statements and sections 3 and 4 in the 'Economic and financial review' chapter). The scope of information and changes in criteria applied with respect to the 2023 Sustainability Report, when significant, are reflected in each relevant section and generally in the 'Sustainability note 1' of this chapter.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta datos financieros y de sostenibilidad para el año 2023, expresados en millones de euros. Los activos totales para el cálculo de GAR (Green Asset Ratio) ascienden a 1,288,300 millones EUR, de los cuales 464,201 millones están relacionados con sectores relevantes para la taxonomía (Taxonomy-eligible), y 31,142 millones son ambientalmente sostenibles (Taxonomy-aligned). Los activos no cubiertos para el cálculo de GAR suman 545,242 millones EUR, mientras que los activos totales alcanzan 1,833,542 millones EUR. Se desglosan categorías como "Préstamos y anticipos" (139,095 millones EUR), "Préstamos garantizados por propiedades comerciales" (22,909 millones EUR), "Préstamos para renovación de edificios" (141 millones EUR), "Instrumentos de deuda" (2,140 millones EUR), "Instrumentos de capital" (155 millones EUR), y "Derivados" (5,421 millones EUR). Además, los activos bajo gestión suman 137,531 millones EUR, con 4,302 millones relacionados con sectores relevantes para la taxonomía y 825 millones ambientalmente sostenibles. Los activos de contrapartes de países no pertenecientes a la UE ascienden a 296,567 millones EUR, mientras que las exposiciones fuera de balance incluyen garantías financieras por 15,573 millones EUR y activos bajo gestión por 137,531 millones EUR. Finalmente, los activos totales relacionados con GAR incluyen 464,675 millones EUR hacia sectores relevantes para la taxonomía y 31,151 millones EUR ambientalmente sostenibles.

Les émissions totales du Scope 2, calculées selon la méthode "location-based", sont de 22,000 tCO2e selon le Contexte Num-1, et de 194,276 tCO2e pour l'année 2024 selon le Contexte Num-3.

Biogenic emissions are not included as information on these emissions is not available in the databases we use to calculate any of the categories. E. Supply chain emissions are calculated using a spend-based approach considering the payments to our suppliers in the current year. For that non primary data obtained from suppliers has been used. These are calculated using the Supply Chain Greenhouse Gas Emission Factors v1.3 from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Our supplier taxonomies are mapped to the sectors considered in the database and then converted into emissions through spend-based emissions factors. The total absolute financed emissions (scope 3, categories 15 and 13) of this broad scope, including scope 1, 2 and 3 are 283.8 mtCO2e. And the total GHG emissions (market-based) are 285.0 mtCO2e. With this figure, the ratio of "GHG total emissions / Total income" is: 4.6 mtCO2e/bn€ (Total income figure as disclosed in the Consolidated Income Statements). E1-125

Quelles sont les émissions totales du Scope 2, calculées grâce à la méthode "market-based" ?

nan

Les émissions totales du Scope 2, calculées selon la méthode "market-based", sont de 12,000 tCO2e d'après le Context Num-1.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • ### Resumen de la tabla La tabla presenta datos relacionados con las emisiones de carbono en tres categorías: "Scope 1 (tCO2e)", "Scope 2 location-based (tCO2e)" y "Scope 2 market-based (tCO2e)", organizados por el "Alignment lever". 1. En la categoría "i. Renewable energy and self-production measures", se reportan 2,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 9,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 2. En la categoría "ii. Energy efficiency and consumption reduction measures", se reportan 1,600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 20,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 3,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 3. En la categoría "iii. Direct emissions reduction measure", se reportan 600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", sin datos para las otras dos columnas. 4. El total de emisiones es de 2,200 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 22,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 12,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1 2 3

    i. Renewable energy and self-production measures 2,000 9,000
    ii. Energy efficiency and consumption reduction measures 1,600 20,000 3,000
    iii. Direct emissions reduction measure 600
    Total 2,200 22,000 12,000
  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on "Gross scopes 1, 2, 3 and total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions)" across various years and categories. It includes the following labels, columns, and rows: **Labels:** - Retrospective - Milestones and target years - Annual Target % / Base Year **Columns:** - Base year (2020) - Comparative (2023) - N (2024) - % N / N-1 - 2025 2030 - 2050 **Rows:** 1. **Scope 1 GHG emissions A,B:** Gross scope 1 GHG emissions (tCO2e) decreased from 35,962 in 2020 to 25,755 in 2023, with a projected increase to 35,503 in 2024. 2. **Scope 2 GHG emissions A,C:** Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) dropped from 297,621 in 2020 to 205,292 in 2023, with a further decrease to 194,276 in 2024. Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) fell significantly from 144,038 in 2020 to 21,516 in 2023, with a slight increase to 24,350 in 2024. 3. **Significant scope 3 GHG emissions:** Total Gross indirect (Scope 3) GHG emissions (tCO2e) were 125,441 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,116,061 in 2024. Categories include Purchased goods and services (698,768 in 2024), Capital goods (216,388 in 2024), Upstream transportation and distribution (52,835 in 2024), Business travel (50,061 in 2023, 52,150 in 2024), Employee commuting (75,380 in 2023, 82,569 in 2024), and Downstream transportation (13,350 in 2024). 4. **Total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions):** Total GHG emissions (location-based) (tCO2e) were 356,488 in 2023 and are projected to increase to 1,345,841 in 2024. Total GHG emissions (market-based) (tCO2e) were 172,711 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,175,915 in 2024. The table also includes annual target percentages relative to the base year (2020). and

  • C. These emissions include those derived from electricity consumption and the use of district heating and correspond to Scope 2 defined by the GHG Protocol standard. In 2024 they have been calculated with emission factors of the 2024 edition of the IEA, for 2023 the emission factors of the 2023 edition were used. For the calculation of district heating in Poland and Norway, local public emission factors for 2024 different from DEFRA were used. Data on biogenic emissions is not included as information on these emissions is not available in the EIA emission factor database. · Indirect emissions Electricity - market-based: For the calculation of these emissions, only renewable electricity is considered as renewable electricity that can be certified by any type of contract or product recognized as such, but not the share of the country energy mix obtained from IEA data (i.e. where non-renewable electricity is purchased expressly). C. These emissions include those derived from electricity consumption and the use of district heating and correspond to Scope 2 defined by the GHG Protocol standard. In 2024 they have been calculated with emission factors of the 2024 edition of the IEA, for 2023 the emission factors of the 2023 edition were used. For the calculation of district heating in Poland and Norway, local public emission factors for 2024 different from DEFRA were used. Data on biogenic emissions is not included as information on these emissions is not available in the EIA emission factor database. · Indirect emissions Electricity - market-based: For the calculation of these emissions, only renewable electricity is considered as renewable electricity that can be certified by any type of contract or product recognized as such, but not the share of the country energy mix obtained from IEA data (i.e. where non-renewable electricity is purchased expressly).

The total absolute financed emissions (scope 3, categories 15 and 13) of this broad scope, including scope 1, 2 and 3 are 283.8 mtCO2e. And the total GHG emissions (market-based) are 285.0 mtCO2e.   • Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected. Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected.
  • Regarding our own operations, we disclose our direct and indirect emissions (scopes 1, 2 and 3) data as well as other climate- relevant metrics such as energy consumption. We report on our 17 targets for renewable electricity"and the compensation of our scope 1 and scope 2 emissions. Since 2021, we have also been disclosing financed scope 3 emissions (category 15) related to our alignment objectives. We announced our ambition to work to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050 in February 2021. We are constantly reviewing our strategy and targets to incorporate the latest science insights and changes in local regulation.   • D. The assessment we conducted to determine the materiality of indirect GHG emissions (scope 3) found that the only material category under this scope was category 3.15 (financed emissions), with a weighting of 99% of the total .. The other categories are identified as not relevant, given its low representativeness. In addition, the categories disclosed in this table are defined as relevant, and the following categories are identified as not relevant, given their low representativeness: 3.3 - Fuel and energy-related activities (not included in Scope 1 or 2); 3.5 - waste generated in operations; 3.8 - upstream leased assets; 3.10 - processing of sold products; 3.11 - use of sold products; 3.12 - end-of-life treatment of sold products; 3.14 - franchises. Biogenic emissions are not included as information on these emissions is not available in the databases we use to calculate any of the categories. D.   • ### Scope This chapter covers the core activities of Banco Santander and its subsidiaries from 1 January to 31 December 2024 (for more details, see Notes 1, 2, 3 and 53 to the consolidated financial statements and sections 3 and 4 in the 'Economic and financial review' chapter). The scope of information and changes in criteria applied with respect to the 2023 Sustainability Report, when significant, are reflected in each relevant section and generally in the 'Sustainability note 1' of this chapter. ### Scope This chapter covers the core activities of Banco Santander and its subsidiaries from 1 January to 31 December 2024 (for more details, see Notes 1, 2, 3 and 53 to the consolidated financial statements and sections 3 and 4 in the 'Economic and financial review' chapter). The scope of information and changes in criteria applied with respect to the 2023 Sustainability Report, when significant, are reflected in each relevant section and generally in the 'Sustainability note 1' of this chapter.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta datos financieros y de sostenibilidad para el año 2023, expresados en millones de euros. Los activos totales para el cálculo de GAR (Green Asset Ratio) ascienden a 1,288,300 millones EUR, de los cuales 464,201 millones están relacionados con sectores relevantes para la taxonomía (Taxonomy-eligible), y 31,142 millones son ambientalmente sostenibles (Taxonomy-aligned). Los activos no cubiertos para el cálculo de GAR suman 545,242 millones EUR, mientras que los activos totales alcanzan 1,833,542 millones EUR. Se desglosan categorías como "Préstamos y anticipos" (139,095 millones EUR), "Préstamos garantizados por propiedades comerciales" (22,909 millones EUR), "Préstamos para renovación de edificios" (141 millones EUR), "Instrumentos de deuda" (2,140 millones EUR), "Instrumentos de capital" (155 millones EUR), y "Derivados" (5,421 millones EUR). Además, los activos bajo gestión suman 137,531 millones EUR, con 4,302 millones relacionados con sectores relevantes para la taxonomía y 825 millones ambientalmente sostenibles. Los activos de contrapartes de países no pertenecientes a la UE ascienden a 296,567 millones EUR, mientras que las exposiciones fuera de balance incluyen garantías financieras por 15,573 millones EUR y activos bajo gestión por 137,531 millones EUR. Finalmente, los activos totales relacionados con GAR incluyen 464,675 millones EUR hacia sectores relevantes para la taxonomía y 31,151 millones EUR ambientalmente sostenibles. and
