Les émissions totales de gaz à effet de serre du Scope 2, calculées grâce à la méthode "market-based", sont de 144,038 tCO2e.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Resumen de la tabla La tabla presenta datos relacionados con las emisiones de carbono en tres categorías: "Scope 1 (tCO2e)", "Scope 2 location-based (tCO2e)" y "Scope 2 market-based (tCO2e)", organizados por el "Alignment lever". 1. En la categoría "i. Renewable energy and self-production measures", se reportan 2,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 9,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 2. En la categoría "ii. Energy efficiency and consumption reduction measures", se reportan 1,600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 20,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 3,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 3. En la categoría "iii. Direct emissions reduction measure", se reportan 600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", sin datos para las otras dos columnas. 4. El total de emisiones es de 2,200 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 22,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 12,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based".
  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on "Gross scopes 1, 2, 3 and total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions)" across various years and categories. It includes the following labels, columns, and rows: **Labels:** - Retrospective - Milestones and target years - Annual Target % / Base Year **Columns:** - Base year (2020) - Comparative (2023) - N (2024) - % N / N-1 - 2025 2030 - 2050 **Rows:** 1. **Scope 1 GHG emissions A,B:** Gross scope 1 GHG emissions (tCO2e) decreased from 35,962 in 2020 to 25,755 in 2023, with a projected increase to 35,503 in 2024. 2. **Scope 2 GHG emissions A,C:** Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) dropped from 297,621 in 2020 to 205,292 in 2023, with a further decrease to 194,276 in 2024. Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) fell significantly from 144,038 in 2020 to 21,516 in 2023, with a slight increase to 24,350 in 2024. 3. **Significant scope 3 GHG emissions:** Total Gross indirect (Scope 3) GHG emissions (tCO2e) were 125,441 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,116,061 in 2024. Categories include Purchased goods and services (698,768 in 2024), Capital goods (216,388 in 2024), Upstream transportation and distribution (52,835 in 2024), Business travel (50,061 in 2023, 52,150 in 2024), Employee commuting (75,380 in 2023, 82,569 in 2024), and Downstream transportation (13,350 in 2024). 4. **Total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions):** Total GHG emissions (location-based) (tCO2e) were 356,488 in 2023 and are projected to increase to 1,345,841 in 2024. Total GHG emissions (market-based) (tCO2e) were 172,711 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,175,915 in 2024. The table also includes annual target percentages relative to the base year (2020).
  • ### 2024 environmental footprint The table provides data on renewable electricity, energy consumption, and emissions for 2024. It highlights "96% renewable electricity in 10 core countries where we are present" and "1,012,554 MWh energy consumption." Emissions are categorized into "Scope 1" and "Scope 2." Scope 1 includes "35,503 t CO2e direct emissions," while Scope 2 accounts for "24,350 t CO2e indirect emissions from electricity and other (market based)."
  • C. These emissions include those derived from electricity consumption and the use of district heating and correspond to Scope 2 defined by the GHG Protocol standard. In 2024 they have been calculated with emission factors of the 2024 edition of the IEA, for 2023 the emission factors of the 2023 edition were used. For the calculation of district heating in Poland and Norway, local public emission factors for 2024 different from DEFRA were used. Data on biogenic emissions is not included as information on these emissions is not available in the EIA emission factor database. · Indirect emissions Electricity - market-based: For the calculation of these emissions, only renewable electricity is considered as renewable electricity that can be certified by any type of contract or product recognized as such, but not the share of the country energy mix obtained from IEA data (i.e. where non-renewable electricity is purchased expressly).
  • J. To comply with the regulatory requirements we have extended the financed emissions calculations, in most cases based on factors and other proxies. More details see table below 3.2. The total absolute financed emissions (scope 3, categories 15 and 13) of this broad scope, including scope 1, 2 and 3 are 283.8 mtCO2e. And the total GHG emissions (market-based) are 285.0 mtCO2e. With this figure, the ratio of "GHG total emissions / Total income" is: 4.6 mtCO2e/bn€ (Total income figure as disclosed in the Consolidated Income Statements). Santander Annual report 2024 136
  • Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected.
  • Regarding our own operations, we disclose our direct and indirect emissions (scopes 1, 2 and 3) data as well as other climate- relevant metrics such as energy consumption. We report on our 17 targets for renewable electricity"and the compensation of our scope 1 and scope 2 emissions. Since 2021, we have also been disclosing financed scope 3 emissions (category 15) related to our alignment objectives. We announced our ambition to work to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050 in February 2021. We are constantly reviewing our strategy and targets to incorporate the latest science insights and changes in local regulation.
  • D. The assessment we conducted to determine the materiality of indirect GHG emissions (scope 3) found that the only material category under this scope was category 3.15 (financed emissions), with a weighting of 99% of the total .. The other categories are identified as not relevant, given its low representativeness. In addition, the categories disclosed in this table are defined as relevant, and the following categories are identified as not relevant, given their low representativeness: 3.3 - Fuel and energy-related activities (not included in Scope 1 or 2); 3.5 - waste generated in operations; 3.8 - upstream leased assets; 3.10 - processing of sold products; 3.11 - use of sold products; 3.12 - end-of-life treatment of sold products; 3.14 - franchises. Biogenic emissions are not included as information on these emissions is not available in the databases we use to calculate any of the categories.

  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: 1. La tabla presenta datos en porcentaje (%), comparados con el total de activos cubiertos en el denominador, para el año 2024. 2. Las categorías principales son "Climate Change Mitigation (CCM)", "Climate Change Adaptation (CCA)" y "TOTAL (CCM + CCA)". 3. Se desglosan sectores relevantes según la taxonomía: "Taxonomy-eligible" y "Taxonomy-aligned", incluyendo subcategorías como "Of which Use of Proceeds", "Of which transitional" y "Of which enabling". 4. Para "Local governments financing", el porcentaje total es 83.4%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.1% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 5. En "Housing financing", el porcentaje total es 99.1%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.0% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 6. "Other local government financing" tiene un porcentaje total de 81.0%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.1% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 7. Los "Collateral obtained by taking possession: residential and commercial immovable properties" tienen un 0.0% en todas las categorías, con un 0.3% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 8. "Total GAR assets" presenta un 34.2% total, con un 3.3% "Taxonomy-aligned", desglosado en 2.8% "Use of Proceeds", 0.7% "transitional" y 0.2% "enabling", y un 69.8% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos.
  • ### Scope This chapter covers the core activities of Banco Santander and its subsidiaries from 1 January to 31 December 2024 (for more details, see Notes 1, 2, 3 and 53 to the consolidated financial statements and sections 3 and 4 in the 'Economic and financial review' chapter). The scope of information and changes in criteria applied with respect to the 2023 Sustainability Report, when significant, are reflected in each relevant section and generally in the 'Sustainability note 1' of this chapter.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta datos financieros y de sostenibilidad para el año 2023, expresados en millones de euros. Los activos totales para el cálculo de GAR (Green Asset Ratio) ascienden a 1,288,300 millones EUR, de los cuales 464,201 millones están relacionados con sectores relevantes para la taxonomía (Taxonomy-eligible), y 31,142 millones son ambientalmente sostenibles (Taxonomy-aligned). Los activos no cubiertos para el cálculo de GAR suman 545,242 millones EUR, mientras que los activos totales alcanzan 1,833,542 millones EUR. Se desglosan categorías como "Préstamos y anticipos" (139,095 millones EUR), "Préstamos garantizados por propiedades comerciales" (22,909 millones EUR), "Préstamos para renovación de edificios" (141 millones EUR), "Instrumentos de deuda" (2,140 millones EUR), "Instrumentos de capital" (155 millones EUR), y "Derivados" (5,421 millones EUR). Además, los activos bajo gestión suman 137,531 millones EUR, con 4,302 millones relacionados con sectores relevantes para la taxonomía y 825 millones ambientalmente sostenibles. Los activos de contrapartes de países no pertenecientes a la UE ascienden a 296,567 millones EUR, mientras que las exposiciones fuera de balance incluyen garantías financieras por 15,573 millones EUR y activos bajo gestión por 137,531 millones EUR. Finalmente, los activos totales relacionados con GAR incluyen 464,675 millones EUR hacia sectores relevantes para la taxonomía y 31,151 millones EUR ambientalmente sostenibles.

Biogenic emissions are not included as information on these emissions is not available in the databases we use to calculate any of the categories. E. Supply chain emissions are calculated using a spend-based approach considering the payments to our suppliers in the current year. For that non primary data obtained from suppliers has been used. These are calculated using the Supply Chain Greenhouse Gas Emission Factors v1.3 from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Our supplier taxonomies are mapped to the sectors considered in the database and then converted into emissions through spend-based emissions factors. The other categories are identified as not relevant, given its low representativeness. E1-133

Intensité des émissions totales du groupe :
Calculez l'intensité des émissions de gaz à effet total dans l'année 2024.

Le calcul consiste à diviser les émissions totales par le chiffre d'affaires.
Le calcul consiste à diviser les émissions totales par le chiffre d'affaires.
L'unité est tCO2e/€m.
Il faut présenter le total de chiffres d'affaires utilisé pour calculer l'intensité en GES.


Privilégier l'utilisation d'un tableau pour présenter les résultats.
Donner les années précédentes si l'information est disponible.

Je suis désolé, mais je ne dispose pas des informations nécessaires pour calculer l'intensité des émissions de gaz à effet de serre pour l'année 2024, car le chiffre d'affaires total utilisé pour ce calcul n'est pas fourni dans les contextes disponibles.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Portfolio evolution: The emission intensity improved from 138 gCO2e/vkm in 2021 to 133 in 2022, mainly due to an overall average reduction in the emissions intensity of our customers during this period. This reduction continued in 2023, although the emissions intensity increased slightly to 134 gCO2e/vkm due to minor portfolio exposure changes. Portfolio evolution: The emission intensity improved from 138 gCO2e/vkm in 2021 to 133 in 2022, mainly due to an overall average reduction in the emissions intensity of our customers during this period. This reduction continued in 2023, although the emissions intensity increased slightly to 134 gCO2e/vkm due to minor portfolio exposure changes.
  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on "Gross scopes 1, 2, 3 and total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions)" across various years and categories. It includes the following labels, columns, and rows: **Labels:** - Retrospective - Milestones and target years - Annual Target % / Base Year **Columns:** - Base year (2020) - Comparative (2023) - N (2024) - % N / N-1 - 2025 2030 - 2050 **Rows:** 1. **Scope 1 GHG emissions A,B:** Gross scope 1 GHG emissions (tCO2e) decreased from 35,962 in 2020 to 25,755 in 2023, with a projected increase to 35,503 in 2024. 2. **Scope 2 GHG emissions A,C:** Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) dropped from 297,621 in 2020 to 205,292 in 2023, with a further decrease to 194,276 in 2024. Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) fell significantly from 144,038 in 2020 to 21,516 in 2023, with a slight increase to 24,350 in 2024. 3. **Significant scope 3 GHG emissions:** Total Gross indirect (Scope 3) GHG emissions (tCO2e) were 125,441 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,116,061 in 2024. Categories include Purchased goods and services (698,768 in 2024), Capital goods (216,388 in 2024), Upstream transportation and distribution (52,835 in 2024), Business travel (50,061 in 2023, 52,150 in 2024), Employee commuting (75,380 in 2023, 82,569 in 2024), and Downstream transportation (13,350 in 2024). 4. **Total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions):** Total GHG emissions (location-based) (tCO2e) were 356,488 in 2023 and are projected to increase to 1,345,841 in 2024. Total GHG emissions (market-based) (tCO2e) were 172,711 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,175,915 in 2024. The table also includes annual target percentages relative to the base year (2020). and

  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on the "Steel" sector across the years 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, and 2023, with various metrics and targets. The columns include "Exposure (drawn amount EUR bn)," "Absolute emissions (MtCO2e)," "Physical emissions intensity (tCO2e/tS)," "Financial emissions intensity (MtCO2e/ EUR bn lent)," "PCAF score," and "2030 target." In 2019, the exposure was 1.51 EUR bn, absolute emissions were 2.62 MtCO2e, physical emissions intensity was 1.58 tCO2e/tS, financial emissions intensity was 1.74 MtCO2e/EUR bn lent, and the PCAF score was 3.0, with a 2030 target of 1.07 tCO2e/tS. In 2020, exposure decreased to 1.31 EUR bn, absolute emissions to 2.14 MtCO2e, physical emissions intensity to 1.40 tCO2e/tS, financial emissions intensity to 1.63 MtCO2e/EUR bn lent, and the PCAF score increased to 3.1. In 2021, exposure rose to 1.42 EUR bn, absolute emissions dropped to 1.90 MtCO2e, physical emissions intensity decreased to 1.36 tCO2e/tS, financial emissions intensity fell to 1.33 MtCO2e/EUR bn lent, and the PCAF score remained at 3.1. In 2022, exposure increased to 1.96 EUR bn, absolute emissions slightly decreased to 1.88 MtCO2e, physical emissions intensity dropped to 1.24 tCO2e/tS, financial emissions intensity fell further to 0.96 MtCO2e/EUR bn lent, and the PCAF score stayed at 3.1. In 2023, exposure rose to 2.04 EUR bn, absolute emissions decreased to 1.84 MtCO2e, physical emissions intensity increased to 1.38 tCO2e/tS, financial emissions intensity dropped to 0.90 MtCO2e/EUR bn lent, and the PCAF score increased to 3.3. The 2030 target for physical emissions intensity is set at 1.07 tCO2e/tS. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7
    Sector Year Exposure (drawn amount EUR bn) Absolute emissions (MtCO2e) Physical emissions intensity (tCO2e/tS) Financial emissions intensity (MtCO2e/ EUR bn lent) PCAF score 2030 target

  • by repayments from better climate tiered customers. Current exposure is significantly below the initial level at the time of target setting, and is very much concentrated in a small number of customers and long-term asset financing. Portfolio evolution: Emissions intensity decreased from 97.21 grCO2/RPK in 2021 to 81.09 in 2022 due to COVID-19 recovery and increased to 82.99 in 2023 driven by changes in the portfolio composition (repayments from less carbon-intensive clients). The emission intensities of individual airlines continue to decline as airlines improve their efficiency, in addition to a normalization effect post-COVID in 2022. It is worth noting that absolute financed emissions have reduced by almost 70% since the baseline year 2019. by repayments from better climate tiered customers. Current exposure is significantly below the initial level at the time of target setting, and is very much concentrated in a small number of customers and long-term asset financing. Portfolio evolution: Emissions intensity decreased from 97.21 grCO2/RPK in 2021 to 81.09 in 2022 due to COVID-19 recovery and increased to 82.99 in 2023 driven by changes in the portfolio composition (repayments from less carbon-intensive clients). The emission intensities of individual airlines continue to decline as airlines improve their efficiency, in addition to a normalization effect post-COVID in 2022. It is worth noting that absolute financed emissions have reduced by almost 70% since the baseline year 2019.

Emissions disclosed that year were reviewed to consider the same circumstances as the disclosed in this report 2024: equal perimeter (all countries and businesses that have employees, formerly G10) and considering fugitive emissions equivalent to current emissions (recently included in emissions footprint).   • Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected. Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected.

La tabla presenta datos en porcentaje (%), comparados con el total de activos cubiertos en el denominador, para el año 2024. 2. Las categorías principales son "Climate Change Mitigation (CCM)", "Climate Change Adaptation (CCA)" y "TOTAL (CCM + CCA)". 3. Se desglosan sectores relevantes según la taxonomía: "Taxonomy-eligible" y "Taxonomy-aligned", incluyendo subcategorías como "Of which Use of Proceeds", "Of which transitional" y "Of which enabling". 4. Para "Local governments financing", el porcentaje total es 83.4%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.1% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 5. En "Housing financing", el porcentaje total es 99.1%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.0% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 6. "Other local government financing" tiene un porcentaje total de 81.0%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.1% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 7. Los "Collateral obtained by taking possession: residential and commercial immovable properties" tienen un 0.0% en todas las categorías, con un 0.3% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 8. "Total GAR assets" presenta un 34.2% total, con un 3.3% "Taxonomy-aligned", desglosado en 2.8% "Use of Proceeds", 0.7% "transitional" y 0.2% "enabling", y un 69.8% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta datos sobre la proporción de activos cubiertos en términos de sostenibilidad ambiental para el año 2024, expresados como porcentaje del total de activos cubiertos en el denominador. Las categorías principales incluyen "Climate Change Mitigation (CCM)", "Climate Change Adaptation (CCA)" y el total combinado ("TOTAL (CCM + CCA)"). Además, se desglosan los sectores relevantes según la taxonomía ("Taxonomy-eligible") y los activos ambientalmente sostenibles ("Taxonomy-aligned"). 1. **"Local governments financing"**: 83.4% del total de activos cubiertos, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes ni activos sostenibles. 2. **"Housing financing"**: 99.1% del total de activos cubiertos, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes ni activos sostenibles. 3. **"Other local government financing"**: 81.0% del total de activos cubiertos, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes ni activos sostenibles. 4. **"Collateral obtained by taking possession: residential and commercial immovable properties"**: 0.0% en todas las categorías. 5. **"Total GAR assets"**: 34.0% del total de activos cubiertos, con 3.0% ambientalmente sostenibles, 2.8% destinados al uso de ingresos, 0.7% transicionales y 0.1% habilitadores. La proporción de activos totales cubiertos es del 69.8%. and

    Risk management and compliance

  • La tabla presenta los datos de "GAR KPI stock (Turnover) - 2023" en el contexto de gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento. Los encabezados incluyen "% (comparado con el total de activos cubiertos en el denominador)", "2023", "Mitigación del Cambio Climático (CCM)", "Adaptación al Cambio Climático (CCA)", "TOTAL (CCM + CCA)", "Proporción de activos totales cubiertos", y varias subcategorías como "ambientalmente sostenible (alineado con la taxonomía)", "Uso de Proceeds", "transicional", y "habilitador". Las filas abarcan diferentes tipos de activos y sectores, como "Préstamos y avances, valores de deuda e instrumentos de capital no HfT elegibles para el cálculo de GAR", "Empresas financieras", "Instituciones de crédito", "Corporaciones financieras", "Empresas no financieras", y "Hogares". También se incluyen subcategorías como "préstamos garantizados por propiedad residencial", "préstamos para renovación de edificios", y "préstamos para vehículos motorizados". Los datos de 2023 muestran porcentajes y valores específicos para cada categoría, destacando la proporción de activos cubiertos y su alineación con objetivos de sostenibilidad. Por ejemplo, los hogares tienen un porcentaje de activos cubiertos del 73.7%, con un 33.1% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. Los préstamos garantizados por propiedad residencial alcanzan un 97.4%, mientras que los préstamos para vehículos motorizados llegan al 100%. La tabla también detalla la contribución de sectores elegibles para la taxonomía y aquellos alineados con la taxonomía, como los sectores transicionales y habilitadores. and

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations suffisantes pour calculer l'intensité des émissions de gaz à effet de serre du groupe pour 2024, car le chiffre d'affaires total nécessaire pour ce calcul n'est pas précisé dans les contextes fournis.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • Portfolio evolution: The emission intensity improved from 138 gCO2e/vkm in 2021 to 133 in 2022, mainly due to an overall average reduction in the emissions intensity of our customers during this period. This reduction continued in 2023, although the emissions intensity increased slightly to 134 gCO2e/vkm due to minor portfolio exposure changes.
  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on "Gross scopes 1, 2, 3 and total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions)" across various years and categories. It includes the following labels, columns, and rows: **Labels:** - Retrospective - Milestones and target years - Annual Target % / Base Year **Columns:** - Base year (2020) - Comparative (2023) - N (2024) - % N / N-1 - 2025 2030 - 2050 **Rows:** 1. **Scope 1 GHG emissions A,B:** Gross scope 1 GHG emissions (tCO2e) decreased from 35,962 in 2020 to 25,755 in 2023, with a projected increase to 35,503 in 2024. 2. **Scope 2 GHG emissions A,C:** Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) dropped from 297,621 in 2020 to 205,292 in 2023, with a further decrease to 194,276 in 2024. Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) fell significantly from 144,038 in 2020 to 21,516 in 2023, with a slight increase to 24,350 in 2024. 3. **Significant scope 3 GHG emissions:** Total Gross indirect (Scope 3) GHG emissions (tCO2e) were 125,441 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,116,061 in 2024. Categories include Purchased goods and services (698,768 in 2024), Capital goods (216,388 in 2024), Upstream transportation and distribution (52,835 in 2024), Business travel (50,061 in 2023, 52,150 in 2024), Employee commuting (75,380 in 2023, 82,569 in 2024), and Downstream transportation (13,350 in 2024). 4. **Total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions):** Total GHG emissions (location-based) (tCO2e) were 356,488 in 2023 and are projected to increase to 1,345,841 in 2024. Total GHG emissions (market-based) (tCO2e) were 172,711 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,175,915 in 2024. The table also includes annual target percentages relative to the base year (2020).
  • J. To comply with the regulatory requirements we have extended the financed emissions calculations, in most cases based on factors and other proxies. More details see table below 3.2. The total absolute financed emissions (scope 3, categories 15 and 13) of this broad scope, including scope 1, 2 and 3 are 283.8 mtCO2e. And the total GHG emissions (market-based) are 285.0 mtCO2e. With this figure, the ratio of "GHG total emissions / Total income" is: 4.6 mtCO2e/bn€ (Total income figure as disclosed in the Consolidated Income Statements). Santander Annual report 2024 136
  • ### 2024 environmental footprint The table provides data on renewable electricity, energy consumption, and emissions for 2024. It highlights "96% renewable electricity in 10 core countries where we are present" and "1,012,554 MWh energy consumption." Emissions are categorized into "Scope 1" and "Scope 2." Scope 1 includes "35,503 t CO2e direct emissions," while Scope 2 accounts for "24,350 t CO2e indirect emissions from electricity and other (market based)."
  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on the "Steel" sector across the years 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, and 2023, with various metrics and targets. The columns include "Exposure (drawn amount EUR bn)," "Absolute emissions (MtCO2e)," "Physical emissions intensity (tCO2e/tS)," "Financial emissions intensity (MtCO2e/ EUR bn lent)," "PCAF score," and "2030 target." In 2019, the exposure was 1.51 EUR bn, absolute emissions were 2.62 MtCO2e, physical emissions intensity was 1.58 tCO2e/tS, financial emissions intensity was 1.74 MtCO2e/EUR bn lent, and the PCAF score was 3.0, with a 2030 target of 1.07 tCO2e/tS. In 2020, exposure decreased to 1.31 EUR bn, absolute emissions to 2.14 MtCO2e, physical emissions intensity to 1.40 tCO2e/tS, financial emissions intensity to 1.63 MtCO2e/EUR bn lent, and the PCAF score increased to 3.1. In 2021, exposure rose to 1.42 EUR bn, absolute emissions dropped to 1.90 MtCO2e, physical emissions intensity decreased to 1.36 tCO2e/tS, financial emissions intensity fell to 1.33 MtCO2e/EUR bn lent, and the PCAF score remained at 3.1. In 2022, exposure increased to 1.96 EUR bn, absolute emissions slightly decreased to 1.88 MtCO2e, physical emissions intensity dropped to 1.24 tCO2e/tS, financial emissions intensity fell further to 0.96 MtCO2e/EUR bn lent, and the PCAF score stayed at 3.1. In 2023, exposure rose to 2.04 EUR bn, absolute emissions decreased to 1.84 MtCO2e, physical emissions intensity increased to 1.38 tCO2e/tS, financial emissions intensity dropped to 0.90 MtCO2e/EUR bn lent, and the PCAF score increased to 3.3. The 2030 target for physical emissions intensity is set at 1.07 tCO2e/tS.
  • by repayments from better climate tiered customers. Current exposure is significantly below the initial level at the time of target setting, and is very much concentrated in a small number of customers and long-term asset financing. Portfolio evolution: Emissions intensity decreased from 97.21 grCO2/RPK in 2021 to 81.09 in 2022 due to COVID-19 recovery and increased to 82.99 in 2023 driven by changes in the portfolio composition (repayments from less carbon-intensive clients). The emission intensities of individual airlines continue to decline as airlines improve their efficiency, in addition to a normalization effect post-COVID in 2022. It is worth noting that absolute financed emissions have reduced by almost 70% since the baseline year 2019.
  • G. Base year is 2020. Emissions disclosed that year were reviewed to consider the same circumstances as the disclosed in this report 2024: equal perimeter (all countries and businesses that have employees, formerly G10) and considering fugitive emissions equivalent to current emissions (recently included in emissions footprint). H. Data with no information for 2023 are first reported in 2024. I. Our reduction objectives have been externally assured only in the verification process of the present report.
  • Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: 1. La tabla presenta datos en porcentaje (%), comparados con el total de activos cubiertos en el denominador, para el año 2024. 2. Las categorías principales son "Climate Change Mitigation (CCM)", "Climate Change Adaptation (CCA)" y "TOTAL (CCM + CCA)". 3. Se desglosan sectores relevantes según la taxonomía: "Taxonomy-eligible" y "Taxonomy-aligned", incluyendo subcategorías como "Of which Use of Proceeds", "Of which transitional" y "Of which enabling". 4. Para "Local governments financing", el porcentaje total es 83.4%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.1% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 5. En "Housing financing", el porcentaje total es 99.1%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.0% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 6. "Other local government financing" tiene un porcentaje total de 81.0%, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes o sostenibles, y con un 0.1% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 7. Los "Collateral obtained by taking possession: residential and commercial immovable properties" tienen un 0.0% en todas las categorías, con un 0.3% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos. 8. "Total GAR assets" presenta un 34.2% total, con un 3.3% "Taxonomy-aligned", desglosado en 2.8% "Use of Proceeds", 0.7% "transitional" y 0.2% "enabling", y un 69.8% de proporción de activos totales cubiertos.

Países destacados: - **Estados Unidos**: 4,473,683 (2024) vs. 4,510,043 (2023), variación de (1)%. - **México**: 21,288,536 (2024) vs. 20,517,259 (2023), variación de 4%. 4. **Banca Digital**: - **Banco de Consumidores Digital**: 19,549,525 (2024) vs. 20,192,858 (2023), variación de (3)%. - **Banco de Consumidores Santander**: 16,953,371 (2024) vs. 17,665,556 (2023), variación de (4)%. - **Santander Digital**: 2,596,154 (2024) vs. 2,527,302 (2023), variación de 3%. 5. **Total**: Clientes totales en 2024 son 172,537,332 frente a 164,542,034 en 2023, con una variación de 5%.

  • J.To comply with the regulatory requirements we have extended the financed emissions calculations, in most cases based on factors and other proxies. More details see table below 3.2. With this figure, the ratio of "GHG total emissions / Total income" is: 4.6 mtCO2e/bn€ (Total income figure as disclosed in the Consolidated Income Statements).   • Total GHG emissions (market-based) (tCO2e)- 172,711 1,175,915 580.9 % - - - - A. For 2024, information is included for 100% of the Group’s average employees in all the countries we operate. The entities listed under ESRS Requirement E1, paragraph 50.b) (investees with operational control), are not material to Santander. B. These emissions include those derived from direct energy consumption: Natural gas, diesel as well as the fuel consumption of the fleets where it is applicable (Argentina, Mexico, Brazil, Chile and Poland this year) and fugitive emissions of refrigerant gases according to the GHG Protocol standard. These emissions include those derived from direct energy consumption: Natural gas, diesel as well as the fuel consumption of the fleets where it is applicable (Argentina, Mexico, Brazil, Chile and Poland this year) and fugitive emissions of refrigerant gases according to the GHG Protocol standard. For the calculation of these emissions, emission factors from DEFRA (Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs) 2024 for the financial year 2024 and DEFRA 2023 for the financial year 2023 have been

  • under construction. Portfolio evolution: Since 2022, we observe a downward trend in the physical emission intensity of our portfolio, going from 0.19 tCO2e/MWh in 2021 to 0.16 in 2022 and 0.15 in 2023. One of the main drivers is an overall improvement in the average emissions intensities of our corporate portfolio customers during this period. Supporting our clients in their alignment journey implies investing in both renewable technologies and transition technologies, which may still lead to temporary increases in physical emission intensity in the future.   • mtCO 2e 2023 6.82 20.27 72.97 2.97 3.0 Note on data quality: To improve the quality of timely available data, the data source for this sector has been replaced by Wood Mackenzie for figures from 2022 onwards, allowing us to analyse upstream companies and their assets in a more granular way and avoid uncertainties related to public company disclosures. Our methodology has been updated to incorporate this refinement19 . 19 Scope 1 and 2 are directly retrieved from Wood Mackenzie. Scope 3 is calculated based on Wood Mackenzie production data and combustion emission factors. Although we illustrate these in the table below according to the statistical classification of economic activities in the European Community at level 1 (NACE 1, from the French 'Nomenclature statistique des Activites economiques dans la Communaute Europeenne'-Statistical classification of economic activities in the European Community) breakdown, our sector analysis in risk management goes up to NACE level 4 to monitor the composition of our portfolios, capturing most of our value chain.   • sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable. sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable.
  • Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A. As in the rest of this chapter, we only include information about our employees. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A. As in the rest of this chapter, we only include information about our employees. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional
E1-64

Quelles sont les valeurs liées aux objectifs de réduction du plan de transition. Plusieurs types de réponses sont possibles :

La valeur brute de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES), séparée par Scope (1, 2 et 3).
Les cibles de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES), exprimées en pourcentage par rapport à une année de référence, séparées par Scope (1, 2 et 3).
Les cibles de réduction en intensité monétaire, séparées par Scope (1, 2 et 3).
Il est important de distinguer les cibles par secteur d'activité.
Si les objectifs concernent les émissions financées, il est important de préciser le périmètre concerné (Scope 1, 2 ou 3).


Si possible, préciser la méthodologie utilisée pour fixer l'objectif de référence.
Si possible, préciser si l'objectif est conforme à un scénario de réduction aligné avec l'Accord de Paris.
Merci de bien indiquer les années de référence ainsi que les années cibles pour chaque objectif présenté.

Je ne dispose pas de toutes les informations nécessaires pour répondre de manière exhaustive à votre question, mais je peux vous fournir une synthèse des données disponibles dans les contextes fournis.

Valeurs liées aux objectifs de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES) :

Valeur brute de réduction des GES :

  1. Scope 1 GHG emissions :

    • Réduites de 35,962 tCO2e en 2020 à 25,755 tCO2e en 2023.
    • Prévision pour 2024 : 35,503 tCO2e.

  2. Scope 2 GHG emissions :

    • Location-based : Réduites de 297,621 tCO2e en 2020 à 205,292 tCO2e en 2023.
    • Market-based : Réduites de 144,038 tCO2e en 2020 à 21,516 tCO2e en 2023.

  3. Scope 3 GHG emissions :

    • Total des émissions indirectes (Scope 3) : 125,441 tCO2e en 2023.

Cibles de réduction des GES exprimées en pourcentage :

  1. Scope 1 :

    • Objectif de réduction annuelle de 0.7% par rapport à 2020, avec une perspective pour 2030.

  2. Scope 2 :

    • Réduction annuelle de 4.2% pour les émissions location-based et de 9.1% pour les emissions market-based, comparée à l'année de référence 2020.

  3. Scope 3 :

    • Pas de détails précis sur les pourcentages de réduction dans les contextes fournis.

Cibles par secteur d'activité :

  1. Power generation : Objectif de réduction de 46% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2019.
  2. Oil & gas : Objectif de réduction de 29% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2019.
  3. Aviation : Objectif de réduction de 33% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2019.
  4. Steel : Objectif de réduction de 32% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2019.
  5. Auto manufacturing : Objectif de réduction de 31% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2020.
  6. Auto lending Europe : Objectif de réduction de 35-45% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2022.

Méthodologie et alignement avec l'Accord de Paris :

  • La méthodologie utilisée pour fixer les objectifs est basée sur le scénario "International Energy Agency - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario" (IEA-NZE), qui vise à limiter l'augmentation de température à 1,5°C conformément à l'Accord de Paris.

Années de référence et cibles :

  • Année de référence pour la plupart des secteurs : 2019, sauf pour l'auto manufacturing (2020) et l'auto lending en Europe (2022).
  • Année cible pour l'ensemble des secteurs : 2030.

Emissions financées et périmètre concerné:

  • Les émissions financées incluent les Scopes 1 et 2 pour les entreprises non financières, les prêts hypothécaires, les prêts pour véhicules à moteur, les dettes souveraines, les obligations d'entreprise, les instruments de fonds propres, et les investissements dans des coentreprises et associés.

Je n'ai pas trouvé de cibles de réduction en intensité monétaire spécifiques dans les contextes fournis. Pour une réponse plus complète, il faudrait accéder à des documents supplémentaires ou à des sources internes de l'organisation concernée.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines alignment targets across various sectors, scenarios, metrics, baselines, years (2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, and 2030 targets), scopes of emissions, and value chains in scope. 1. **Sector**: "S Power generation" follows the "IEA Net Zero 2050" scenario with the metric "tCO2e/MWh" and a baseline of "0.21 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "0.17" in 2020 to "0.15" in 2023, targeting "0.11 (-46%)" by 2030. Scope is "1," covering "Upstream / Generation," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / End product." 2. **Sector**: "B Oil & gas" uses the metric "mtCO2e" with a baseline of "23.84 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions range from "22.58" in 2020 to "20.27" in 2023, targeting "16.98 (-29%)" by 2030. Scope is "1 + 2 + 34," covering "Integrated / Diversified," "Upstream / Extraction," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / Trading." 3. **Sector**: "ET Aviation" uses the metric "gCO2e/RPK" with a baseline of "92.47 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions fluctuate from "93.05" in 2020 to "82.99" in 2023, targeting "61.71 (-33%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Suppliers," "Midstream / Manufacturing," and "Downstream / Airliners." 4. **Sector**: "Steel" uses the metric "tCO2e/ts" with a baseline of "1.58 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "1.40" in 2020 to "1.38" in 2023, targeting "1.07 (-32%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Materials extraction," "Manufacturing," and "Downstream / End product." 5. **Sector**: "Auto manufacturing" uses the metric "gCO2/vkm" with a baseline of "149 (2020 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "149" in 2020 to "134" in 2023, targeting "103 (-31%)" by 2030. Scope is "3A," covering "Upstream / Suppliers-Materials," "Midstream Manufacturing Dealers," and "Downstream / End product." 6. **Sector**: "Auto lending Europe" uses the metric "gCO2e/vkm" with a baseline of "137 (2022 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "137" in 2022 to "133" in 2023, targeting "75-89 (-35-45%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Downstream / End users." The table provides detailed emissions metrics, baselines, and reduction targets for each sector, along with their respective scopes and value chains. and

  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on "Gross scopes 1, 2, 3 and total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions)" across various years and categories. It includes the following labels, columns, and rows: **Labels:** - Retrospective - Milestones and target years - Annual Target % / Base Year **Columns:** - Base year (2020) - Comparative (2023) - N (2024) - % N / N-1 - 2025 2030 - 2050 **Rows:** 1. **Scope 1 GHG emissions A,B:** Gross scope 1 GHG emissions (tCO2e) decreased from 35,962 in 2020 to 25,755 in 2023, with a projected increase to 35,503 in 2024. 2. **Scope 2 GHG emissions A,C:** Gross location-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) dropped from 297,621 in 2020 to 205,292 in 2023, with a further decrease to 194,276 in 2024. Gross market-based Scope 2 GHG emissions (tCO2e) fell significantly from 144,038 in 2020 to 21,516 in 2023, with a slight increase to 24,350 in 2024. 3. **Significant scope 3 GHG emissions:** Total Gross indirect (Scope 3) GHG emissions (tCO2e) were 125,441 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,116,061 in 2024. Categories include Purchased goods and services (698,768 in 2024), Capital goods (216,388 in 2024), Upstream transportation and distribution (52,835 in 2024), Business travel (50,061 in 2023, 52,150 in 2024), Employee commuting (75,380 in 2023, 82,569 in 2024), and Downstream transportation (13,350 in 2024). 4. **Total GHG emissions (excluding financed emissions):** Total GHG emissions (location-based) (tCO2e) were 356,488 in 2023 and are projected to increase to 1,345,841 in 2024. Total GHG emissions (market-based) (tCO2e) were 172,711 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,175,915 in 2024. The table also includes annual target percentages relative to the base year (2020). and

  • Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected. Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: · Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. · Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected.

  • Regarding our own operations, we disclose our direct and indirect emissions (scopes 1, 2 and 3) data as well as other climate- relevant metrics such as energy consumption. We report on our 17 targets for renewable electricity"and the compensation of our scope 1 and scope 2 emissions. Since 2021, we have also been disclosing financed scope 3 emissions (category 15) related to our alignment objectives. We announced our ambition to work to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050 in February 2021. We are constantly reviewing our strategy and targets to incorporate the latest science insights and changes in local regulation. Regarding our own operations, we disclose our direct and indirect emissions (scopes 1, 2 and 3) data as well as other climate- relevant metrics such as energy consumption. We report on our 17 targets for renewable electricity"and the compensation of our scope 1 and scope 2 emissions. Since 2021, we have also been disclosing financed scope 3 emissions (category 15) related to our alignment objectives. We announced our ambition to work to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050 in February 2021. We are constantly reviewing our strategy and targets to incorporate the latest science insights and changes in local regulation.
  • ### Summary of the Table The table outlines various metrics and targets related to sustainability and green finance from 2019 to 2025/2030. The columns represent years: 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, and the 2025/2030 target. The rows include: 1. **Green finance raised and facilitated (accumulated EUR bn)**: Progressing from 19.0 in 2019 to 139.4 in 2024, with targets of 120 bn by 2025 and 220 bn by 2030. 2. **AuM in Socially Responsible Investments (accumulated EUR bn)**: Starting at 27.1 in 2021 and reaching 88.8 in 2024, with a target of 100 bn by 2025. 3. **Thermal coal-related power & mining phase out (EUR bn)**: Declining from 7.0 in 2021 to 4.8 in 2024, aiming for 0 by 2030. 4. **Emissions intensity of power generation portfolio**: Decreasing from 0.21 tCO2e/MWh in 2019 to 0.15 in 2023, with a target of 0.11 in 2030. 5. **Absolute emissions of oil & gas portfolio**: Fluctuating from 23.84 mtCO2e in 2019 to 20.27 in 2023, targeting 16.98 in 2030. 6. **Emissions intensity of aviation portfolio®**: Ranging from 92.47 grCO2e/RPK in 2019 to 82.99 in 2023, with a target of 61.71 in 2030. 7. **Emissions intensity of steel portfolio**: Declining from 1.58 tCO2e/tS in 2019 to 1.38 in 2023, targeting 1.07 in 2030. 8. **Emissions intensity of auto-manufacturing portfolio**: Starting at 149 gCO2/vkm in 2020 and reaching 134 in 2023, with a target of 103 in 2030. 9. **Emissions intensity of auto-lending portfolioB,C**: Recorded at 137 gCO2e/vkm in 2022 and 133 in 2023, targeting 75-89 in 2030. 10. **Electricity from renewable sources**: Increasing from 50% in 2019 to 97% in 2023, with a target of 100% by 2025. and

  • Scenarios:85 To set 2030 science-based alignment targets for our financed sectors, we choose a credible scenario that draws a pathway to reach net zero emissions by 2050 and will limit temperature increase to 1.5 ℃ in line with the Paris Agreement. The scenario we have chosen for the sectors for which we have released alignment targets is the "International Energy Agency - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario" (IEA-NZE). Our aviation target is consistent with the expected adoption of current technologies. This scenario takes into account the technological, regulatory and market changes that need to take place. Regarding our scope 1 and 2 own emission reduction objective by 2030, it is aligned with the cross-sector absolute reduction method considered by SBTi, going beyond the minimum ambition of a linear annual reduction of a 4.2% linear annual reduction between the base year and target year. Scenarios:85 To set 2030 science-based alignment targets for our financed sectors, we choose a credible scenario that draws a pathway to reach net zero emissions by 2050 and will limit temperature increase to 1.5 ℃ in line with the Paris Agreement. The scenario we have chosen for the sectors for which we have released alignment targets is the "International Energy Agency - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario" (IEA-NZE). Our aviation target is consistent with the expected adoption of current technologies. This scenario takes into account the technological, regulatory and market changes that need to take place. Regarding our scope 1 and 2 own emission reduction objective by 2030, it is aligned with the cross-sector absolute reduction method considered by SBTi, going beyond the minimum ambition of a linear annual reduction of a 4.2% linear annual reduction between the base year and target year.
  • Target coverage:86 All CIB portfolio targets and metrics are global and include our core subsidiaries. SCF's target is European and includes its passenger car portfolio (including loans and leasing) in 16 units (13 countries in Europe). This is the same scope we use to measure emissions performance and progress with our targets, though we are working on obtaining information and tracking emissions for other vehicle types. Baseline years: We use 2019 as the baseline year for the four initial sectors and 2020 and 2022 for auto manufacturing and auto lending in Europe, respectively. We chose those years to be representative of our portfolios at that time. For our own operations emissions (Scopes 1 & 2) reduction objectives, we use 2020 as the baseline considering the deadline of the plan set to 2030, and the guidelines criteria for setting science-based targets. Target coverage:86 All CIB portfolio targets and metrics are global and include our core subsidiaries. SCF's target is European and includes its passenger car portfolio (including loans and leasing) in 16 units (13 countries in Europe). This is the same scope we use to measure emissions performance and progress with our targets, though we are working on obtaining information and tracking emissions for other vehicle types. Baseline years: We use 2019 as the baseline year for the four initial sectors and 2020 and 2022 for auto manufacturing and auto lending in Europe, respectively. We chose those years to be representative of our portfolios at that time. For our own operations emissions (Scopes 1 & 2) reduction objectives, we use 2020 as the baseline considering the deadline of the plan set to 2030, and the guidelines criteria for setting science-based targets.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento" La tabla presenta información sobre la gestión de impactos, riesgos y oportunidades, así como métricas y objetivos relacionados con el cambio climático. Los encabezados y etiquetas citados son los siguientes: 1. **Gestión de impactos, riesgos y oportunidades**: - **ESRS 2 IRO-1**: Descripción de los procesos para identificar y evaluar impactos, riesgos y oportunidades materiales relacionados con el clima. Referencias: IFRS S1.23, IFRS S1.B42(c), IFRS S2.22(b)(i)(1-6), IFRS S2.22(b)(ii), IFRS S2.25(a), IFRS S2.25(a)(ii), IFRS S2.10(d), IFRS S2.25(b). - **E1-2**: Políticas relacionadas con la mitigación y adaptación al cambio climático. - **E1-3**: Acciones y recursos en relación con las políticas climáticas. Referencias: IFRS S2.29(a)(i)(1-3), IFRS S2.B38-B57, IFRS S2.29(a)(ii-v), IFRS S2.B30-B34, IFRS S2.B56(a-b). - **E1-7**: Proyectos de mitigación de GEI financiados mediante créditos de carbono. Referencias: IFRS S2.36(e)(i-iv). - **E1-8**: Precio interno del carbono.   • ### Resumen de la tabla La tabla presenta datos relacionados con las emisiones de carbono en tres categorías: "Scope 1 (tCO2e)", "Scope 2 location-based (tCO2e)" y "Scope 2 market-based (tCO2e)", organizados por el "Alignment lever". 1. En la categoría "i. Renewable energy and self-production measures", se reportan 2,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 9,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 2. En la categoría "ii. Energy efficiency and consumption reduction measures", se reportan 1,600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 20,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 3,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 3. En la categoría "iii. Direct emissions reduction measure", se reportan 600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", sin datos para las otras dos columnas. 4. El total de emisiones es de 2,200 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 22,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 12,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". and

  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on "Asset," "Gross carrying amount assessed (EUR bn)," "GHG financed emissions (scope 1 and scope 2) (mtCO2e)," "GHG Scope 1 and 2 mtCO2e/ exposure (EUR bn)," "GHG financed emissions (scope 3) (mtCO2e)," "GHG Scope 3 mtCO2e/ exposure (EUR bn)," and "PCAF Score" for various asset categories as of 2023 and 2024. 1. **Non-financial corporations (Pillar 3)**: Gross carrying amount is 338.5 EUR bn, with 58.6 mtCO2e (scope 1 and 2) and 159.3 mtCO2e (scope 3). Emissions per exposure are 0.18 (scope 1 and 2) and 0.66 (scope 3), with a PCAF Score of 4.8. 2. **Mortgages**: Gross carrying amount is 350.5 EUR bn, with 3.6 mtCO2e (scope 1 and 2) and 0.0 mtCO2e (scope 3). Emissions per exposure are 0.01 for both scopes, with a PCAF Score of 3.8. 3. **Motor vehicle loans**: Gross carrying amount is 170.2 EUR bn, with 27.0 mtCO2e (scope 1 and 2) and 0.0 mtCO2e (scope 3). Emissions per exposure are 0.16 for both scopes, with a PCAF Score of 4.2. 4. **Sovereign debt**: Gross carrying amount is 155.2 EUR bn, with 33.9 mtCO2e (scope 1 and 2) and 0.0 mtCO2e (scope 3). Emissions per exposure are 0.22 for both scopes, with a PCAF Score of 2.2. 5. **Corporate bonds**: Gross carrying amount is 45.7 EUR bn, with 0.3 mtCO2e (scope 1 and 2) and 0.7 mtCO2e (scope 3). Emissions per exposure are 0.006 (scope 1 and 2) and 0.02 (scope 3), with a PCAF Score of 5.0. 6. **Equity instruments**: Gross carrying amount is 6.8 EUR bn, with 0.01 mtCO2e (scope 1 and 2) and 0.1 mtCO2e (scope 3). Emissions per exposure are 0.002 (scope 1 and 2) and 0.01 (scope 3), with a PCAF Score of 5.0. 7. **Investments: joint ventures and associated**: Gross carrying amount is 7.3 EUR bn, with 0.02 mtCO2e (scope 1 and 2) and 0.2 mtCO2e (scope 3). Emissions per exposure are 0.003 (scope 1 and 2) and 0.03 (scope 3), with a PCAF Score of 4.0. 8. **TOTAL**: Gross carrying amount is 1,065.6 EUR bn, with 123.5 mtCO2e (scope 1 and 2) and 160.3 mtCO2e (scope 3). Emissions per exposure are 0.12 (scope 1 and 2) and 0.27 (scope 3). and

Je ne dispose pas de toutes les informations nécessaires pour répondre précisément à votre question. Cependant, voici ce que je peux extraire des contextes fournis :

  1. Objectifs de Réduction des Émissions de GES par Secteur d'Activité :

    • Génération d'électricité : Basé sur un scénario de réduction aligné avec l'Accord de Paris (IEA Net Zero 2050), l'objectif est une réduction de 46% des émissions (tCO2e/MWh) par rapport à l'année de référence 2019.
    • Pétrole et gaz : Une réduction de 29% des émissions totales (mtCO2e) par rapport à l'année de référence 2019.
    • Aviation : Une réduction de 33% des émissions (gCO2e/RPK) par rapport à l'année de référence 2019.
    • Acier : Une réduction de 32% des émissions (tCO2e/tS) par rapport à l'année de référence 2019.
    • Fabrication automobile : Une réduction de 31% des émissions (gCO2/vkm) par rapport à l'année de référence 2020.

  2. Méthodologie et Conformité :

    • Les objectifs de réduction pour les émissions de Scope 1 et 2 sont alignés avec la méthodologie de réduction absolue transsectorielle considérée par SBTi, allant au-delà de la réduction annuelle linéaire minimale de 4,2%.
    • Les cibles sont également alignées avec les objectifs de l'Accord de Paris, visant une transition vers une économie à faible émission de carbone.

  3. Années de Référence et Années Cibles :

    • Les années de référence varient selon le secteur : 2019 pour la plupart des secteurs, 2020 pour la fabrication automobile.
    • Les objectifs sont fixés pour être atteints d'ici 2030.

Je n'ai pas trouvé de détails spécifiques sur les objectifs de réduction en intensité monétaire ou de distinction claire entre les Scopes 1, 2 et 3 pour chaque secteur dans les documents fournis. Si vous avez besoin d'informations supplémentaires, je vous recommande de consulter les rapports annuels complets des entreprises concernées.

  • ### Summary of the Table: The table outlines alignment targets across various sectors, scenarios, metrics, baselines, years (2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, and 2030 targets), scopes of emissions, and value chains in scope. 1. **Sector**: "S Power generation" follows the "IEA Net Zero 2050" scenario with the metric "tCO2e/MWh" and a baseline of "0.21 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "0.17" in 2020 to "0.15" in 2023, targeting "0.11 (-46%)" by 2030. Scope is "1," covering "Upstream / Generation," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / End product." 2. **Sector**: "B Oil & gas" uses the metric "mtCO2e" with a baseline of "23.84 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions range from "22.58" in 2020 to "20.27" in 2023, targeting "16.98 (-29%)" by 2030. Scope is "1 + 2 + 34," covering "Integrated / Diversified," "Upstream / Extraction," "Midstream / Distribution," and "Downstream / Trading." 3. **Sector**: "ET Aviation" uses the metric "gCO2e/RPK" with a baseline of "92.47 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions fluctuate from "93.05" in 2020 to "82.99" in 2023, targeting "61.71 (-33%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Suppliers," "Midstream / Manufacturing," and "Downstream / Airliners." 4. **Sector**: "Steel" uses the metric "tCO2e/ts" with a baseline of "1.58 (2019 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "1.40" in 2020 to "1.38" in 2023, targeting "1.07 (-32%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Upstream / Materials extraction," "Manufacturing," and "Downstream / End product." 5. **Sector**: "Auto manufacturing" uses the metric "gCO2/vkm" with a baseline of "149 (2020 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "149" in 2020 to "134" in 2023, targeting "103 (-31%)" by 2030. Scope is "3A," covering "Upstream / Suppliers-Materials," "Midstream Manufacturing Dealers," and "Downstream / End product." 6. **Sector**: "Auto lending Europe" uses the metric "gCO2e/vkm" with a baseline of "137 (2022 baseline year)." Emissions decrease from "137" in 2022 to "133" in 2023, targeting "75-89 (-35-45%)" by 2030. Scope is "1+ 2," covering "Downstream / End users." Total GHG emissions (market-based) (tCO2e) were 172,711 in 2023 and are projected to rise to 1,175,915 in 2024. The table also includes annual target percentages relative to the base year (2020).

At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected.

  • Regarding our own operations, we disclose our direct and indirect emissions (scopes 1, 2 and 3) data as well as other climate- relevant metrics such as energy consumption. We report on our 17 targets for renewable electricity"and the compensation of our scope 1 and scope 2 emissions. Since 2021, we have also been disclosing financed scope 3 emissions (category 15) related to our alignment objectives. We announced our ambition to work to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050 in February 2021. We are constantly reviewing our strategy and targets to incorporate the latest science insights and changes in local regulation.

The columns represent years: 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, and the 2025/2030 target. The rows include: 1. **Green finance raised and facilitated (accumulated EUR bn)**: Progressing from 19.0 in 2019 to 139.4 in 2024, with targets of 120 bn by 2025 and 220 bn by 2030. 2. **AuM in Socially Responsible Investments (accumulated EUR bn)**: Starting at 27.1 in 2021 and reaching 88.8 in 2024, with a target of 100 bn by 2025. 3. **Thermal coal-related power & mining phase out (EUR bn)**: Declining from 7.0 in 2021 to 4.8 in 2024, aiming for 0 by 2030. 4. **Emissions intensity of power generation portfolio**: Decreasing from 0.21 tCO2e/MWh in 2019 to 0.15 in 2023, with a target of 0.11 in 2030. 5. **Absolute emissions of oil & gas portfolio**: Fluctuating from 23.84 mtCO2e in 2019 to 20.27 in 2023, targeting 16.98 in 2030. 6. **Emissions intensity of aviation portfolio®**: Ranging from 92.47 grCO2e/RPK in 2019 to 82.99 in 2023, with a target of 61.71 in 2030. 7. **Emissions intensity of steel portfolio**: Declining from 1.58 tCO2e/tS in 2019 to 1.38 in 2023, targeting 1.07 in 2030. 8. **Emissions intensity of auto-manufacturing portfolio**: Starting at 149 gCO2/vkm in 2020 and reaching 134 in 2023, with a target of 103 in 2030. 9. **Emissions intensity of auto-lending portfolioB,C**: Recorded at 137 gCO2e/vkm in 2022 and 133 in 2023, targeting 75-89 in 2030. 10. **Electricity from renewable sources**: Increasing from 50% in 2019 to 97% in 2023, with a target of 100% by 2025.
  • Scenarios:85 To set 2030 science-based alignment targets for our financed sectors, we choose a credible scenario that draws a pathway to reach net zero emissions by 2050 and will limit temperature increase to 1.5 ℃ in line with the Paris Agreement. The scenario we have chosen for the sectors for which we have released alignment targets is the "International Energy Agency - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario" (IEA-NZE). Our aviation target is consistent with the expected adoption of current technologies. This scenario takes into account the technological, regulatory and market changes that need to take place. Regarding our scope 1 and 2 own emission reduction objective by 2030, it is aligned with the cross-sector absolute reduction method considered by SBTi, going beyond the minimum ambition of a linear annual reduction of a 4.2% linear annual reduction between the base year and target year.
  • Target coverage:86 All CIB portfolio targets and metrics are global and include our core subsidiaries. SCF's target is European and includes its passenger car portfolio (including loans and leasing) in 16 units (13 countries in Europe). This is the same scope we use to measure emissions performance and progress with our targets, though we are working on obtaining information and tracking emissions for other vehicle types. Baseline years: We use 2019 as the baseline year for the four initial sectors and 2020 and 2022 for auto manufacturing and auto lending in Europe, respectively. We chose those years to be representative of our portfolios at that time. For our own operations emissions (Scopes 1 & 2) reduction objectives, we use 2020 as the baseline considering the deadline of the plan set to 2030, and the guidelines criteria for setting science-based targets.

En la categoría "i. Renewable energy and self-production measures", se reportan 2,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 9,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 2. En la categoría "ii. Energy efficiency and consumption reduction measures", se reportan 1,600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 20,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 3,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based". 3. En la categoría "iii. Direct emissions reduction measure", se reportan 600 tCO2e para "Scope 1", sin datos para las otras dos columnas. 4. El total de emisiones es de 2,200 tCO2e para "Scope 1", 22,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 location-based" y 12,000 tCO2e para "Scope 2 market-based".

Je ne dispose pas de toutes les informations nécessaires pour répondre de manière exhaustive à votre question, mais je peux vous fournir une synthèse des données disponibles dans les contextes fournis.

Valeurs liées aux objectifs de réduction des gaz à effet de serre (GES) :

Valeur brute de réduction des GES :

  1. Scope 1 GHG emissions :

    • Réduites de 35,962 tCO2e en 2020 à 25,755 tCO2e en 2023.
    • Prévision pour 2024 : 35,503 tCO2e.

  2. Scope 2 GHG emissions :

    • Location-based : Réduites de 297,621 tCO2e en 2020 à 205,292 tCO2e en 2023.
    • Market-based : Réduites de 144,038 tCO2e en 2020 à 21,516 tCO2e en 2023.

  3. Scope 3 GHG emissions :

    • Total des émissions indirectes (Scope 3) : 125,441 tCO2e en 2023.

Cibles de réduction des GES exprimées en pourcentage :

  1. Scope 1 :

    • Objectif de réduction annuelle de 0.7% par rapport à 2020, avec une perspective pour 2030.

  2. Scope 2 :

    • Réduction annuelle de 4.2% pour les émissions location-based et de 9.1% pour les emissions market-based, comparée à l'année de référence 2020.

  3. Scope 3 :

    • Pas de détails précis sur les pourcentages de réduction dans les contextes fournis.

Cibles par secteur d'activité :

  1. Power generation : Objectif de réduction de 46% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2019.
  2. Oil & gas : Objectif de réduction de 29% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2019.
  3. Aviation : Objectif de réduction de 33% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2019.
  4. Steel : Objectif de réduction de 32% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2019.
  5. Auto manufacturing : Objectif de réduction de 31% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2020.
  6. Auto lending Europe : Objectif de réduction de 35-45% des émissions d'ici 2030 par rapport à 2022.

Méthodologie et alignement avec l'Accord de Paris :

  • La méthodologie utilisée pour fixer les objectifs est basée sur le scénario "International Energy Agency - Net Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario" (IEA-NZE), qui vise à limiter l'augmentation de température à 1,5°C conformément à l'Accord de Paris.

Années de référence et cibles :

  • Année de référence pour la plupart des secteurs : 2019, sauf pour l'auto manufacturing (2020) et l'auto lending en Europe (2022).
  • Année cible pour l'ensemble des secteurs : 2030.

Emissions financées et périmètre concerné:

  • Les émissions financées incluent les Scopes 1 et 2 pour les entreprises non financières, les prêts hypothécaires, les prêts pour véhicules à moteur, les dettes souveraines, les obligations d'entreprise, les instruments de fonds propres, et les investissements dans des coentreprises et associés.

Je n'ai pas trouvé de cibles de réduction en intensité monétaire spécifiques dans les contextes fournis. Pour une réponse plus complète, il faudrait accéder à des documents supplémentaires ou à des sources internes de l'organisation concernée.

  • technologies. This scenario takes into account the technological, regulatory and market changes that need to take place. Regarding our scope 1 and 2 own emission reduction objective by 2030, it is aligned with the cross-sector absolute reduction method considered by SBTi, going beyond the minimum ambition of a linear annual reduction of a 4.2% linear annual reduction between the base year and target year. Target coverage:86 All CIB portfolio targets and metrics are global and include our core subsidiaries. SCF's target is European and includes its passenger car portfolio (including loans and leasing) in16 units (13 countries in Europe). This is the same scope we use to measure emissions performance and progress with our targets, though we are working on obtaining information and tracking emissions for other vehicle types. Baseline years: We use 2019 as the baseline year for the four initial sectors and 2020 and 2022 for auto manufacturing and auto technologies.   • Contents Business model Sustainability Corporate Economic and Risk management and strategy statement governance financial review and compliance SN 4. Our transition plan i.Alignment targets details Target types : To help our customers’ transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective. Contents Business model Sustainability Corporate Economic and Risk management and strategy statement governance financial review and compliance SN 4. Our transition plan i.Alignment targets details Target types : To help our customers’ transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective.
  • We set our alignment targets and monitor the most crucial part of each sector’s value chain, focusing on those that are most emissions-intensive, actionable and where progress can be measured as well as considering the availability of quality data and market practices. A. Use of sold products. B. Target reduction is -25% vs. 2021 reference. C. Consumer lending for acquisition of passenger cars, covering a significant majority of the exposure in Europe. D. Financed emissions of the UK and Spain CRE portfolios. E. Financed emissions of the UK and Spain mortgage portfolios. F. Financed emissions of part of the Brazil agriculture portfolio. For more details on our alignment targets, see note SN 4. 'Our transition plan '.   • •Scope 1 emissions. Emissions derived from refrigerant gas leaks are included for the first time. Additionally, the reporting scope that applies to the related metrics has been modified: •Internal consumption. The reporting scope is expanded with information from all subsidiaries. Now covering 100% of the Group's consolidated scope. •Footprint compensation. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected. h)Incorporation by reference This report includes all the information necessary to comply with the requirements established in the ESRS, except in those cases in which such information is already included in the Group's audit •Scope 1 emissions. Starting this year "2024", the Group compensates scopes 1 and 2 of 100% of the Group. Finally, scope 1 and 2 emission reduction targets have been reviewed, based on the targets defined in the previous 2022-2025 plan. These targets are based on 2020 and have a horizon of 2030. At the date of publication of this report, no material misstatements of information disclosed in prior periods have been detected. h)Incorporation by reference This report includes all the information necessary to comply with the requirements established in the ESRS, except in those cases in which such information is already included in the Group's audit

  • Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A. As in the rest of this chapter, we only include information about our employees. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A.   • shares are meant to help the foundation financially; it can use the dividends to cover some (if not all) of the cost of fulfilling its founding purposes.66 These include managing the bank's art collection and financing numerous literary, educational, social, cultural and environmental productions and activities, in which the remodelling of the Santander's headquarters on Paseo de Pereda in Santander and our relations with universities in Spain will play an important role. For more details, visit the website fundacionbancosantander.com/es/ fundacion/transparencia. We have other Santander foundations in countries where we operate (Argentina, the US, Mexico, Portugal, Poland and the UK), which boost the number of initiatives we run. Their focus varies according to local needs; for instance, in Argentina on art and culture; in Portugal on education, inclusion and culture; and in Poland on education for children and young people.
