The second step assesses the quality of each customer's transition plan. Our transition plan assessment methodology focuses on four pillars: 1. Targets: it focuses on the quality and ambition of the customer's quantitative GHG emissions targets. Where possible, we assess short- and long-term, as well as absolute and intensity reduction targets. 2. Action plan: it considers the credibility of the customer's alignment strategy. We assess the business strategy integration of climate change risks and opportunities; the existence of climate scenario planning; as well as time-bound action plans to achieve alignment targets.
  • ### 2.1.1 Our approach Santander considers climate a material topic, having identified impacts, risks and opportunities in the double materiality assessment. Per legal requirements, below we disclose our transition plan, based on three pillars. The purpose of each pillar is to support our customers and the communities we serve in their transition objectives; assess our customers' climate-related risks to manage the impact on their business and on our operations; and make progress with the alignment of our portfolios: 1 Supporting our customers in their transition goals ### 2.1.1 Our approach Santander considers climate a material topic, having identified impacts, risks and opportunities in the double materiality assessment. Per legal requirements, below we disclose our transition plan, based on three pillars. The purpose of each pillar is to support our customers and the communities we serve in their transition objectives; assess our customers' climate-related risks to manage the impact on their business and on our operations; and make progress with the alignment of our portfolios: 1 Supporting our customers in their transition goals
  • ## Risk management and compliance ### CIB implementation strategy As part of supporting our customers in their climate objectives and to achieve our sectoral alignment targets we undertake several actions. These actions include an assessment of the transition plans of our customers, customer engagement, and dedicated portfolio steering governance. We also leverage on data collection as part of the risk analysis process; as well as conducting ESCC exclusion policy reviews. Given our actions directly relate to the activity of our customers, it is not practical to make quantitative estimates for how each action contributes to achieving each of our targets. All actions described below cover the CIB business globally. ## Risk management and compliance ### CIB implementation strategy As part of supporting our customers in their climate objectives and to achieve our sectoral alignment targets we undertake several actions. These actions include an assessment of the transition plans of our customers, customer engagement, and dedicated portfolio steering governance. We also leverage on data collection as part of the risk analysis process; as well as conducting ESCC exclusion policy reviews. Given our actions directly relate to the activity of our customers, it is not practical to make quantitative estimates for how each action contributes to achieving each of our targets. All actions described below cover the CIB business globally.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" La tabla detalla la información no financiera que debe divulgarse, organizada en tres columnas: "Non-financial information to be disclosed", "Chapter/section of the annual report" y "Correspondence with CSRD/other regulations". Los temas abordados incluyen: 1. **Efectos ambientales y riesgos**: Información sobre los efectos actuales y previsibles de las actividades de la empresa en el medio ambiente, incluyendo riesgos ambientales y provisiones, se encuentra en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y corresponde a regulaciones como SBM-3, IRO-1, MDR-A, MDR-M, E1, entre otras. 2. **Contaminación**: Medidas para prevenir, reducir o reparar emisiones de CO2 y otras formas de contaminación están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a MDR-A, E1-3, E1-7. 3. **Economía circular y gestión de residuos**: Acciones como prevención, reciclaje y reutilización de residuos se encuentran en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a E5, IRO-1. 4. **Uso sostenible de recursos**: Incluye el uso de agua y materias primas, con medidas para mejorar la eficiencia, en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135) [Table 2. Environmental footprint]", correspondiendo a E3, E5, IRO-1. 5. **Energía**: Consumo directo e indirecto, eficiencia energética y uso de energías renovables están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-A, MDR-M, E1-3, E1-5. 6. **Cambio climático**: Emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, medidas de adaptación y objetivos de reducción están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-M, E1-6, MDR-T, E1-4. 7. **Biodiversidad**: Medidas para preservar o restaurar la biodiversidad están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.3.5 Our approach to nature and biodiversity]" y corresponden a E4, IRO-1. and

    0 1
    Inclusive Culture Progress with inclusive culture and other initiatives such as accessibility.
    Financial inclusion Progress with financial inclusion targets and other key initiatives in the social agenda (financial education, community investment, etc.).
    Sustainable finance Progress with sustainable finance and socially responsible investment.
    Climate Progress with our transition plan and the key levers to fulfil our net zero ambition.
    Governance and cross cutting matters Conducting our double materiality assessment, implementing sustainability policies, and enhancing data efficiency and quality.

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas suffisamment d'informations pour décrire précisément comment le plan de transition pour l'atténuation des risques climatiques est intégré dans la stratégie commerciale globale et la planification financière de l'entreprise.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### 2.3.1 Resilience of our strategy and business model to climate change Managing climate and environmental risk factors is key to continue strengthening the resilience of the Group's strategy and business model for climate change. To enhance such resilience, we embed climate and environmental risk factors in each stage of the risk management cycle through which we analyse our own facilities and customer's financing process. The risks derived from these factors is also included in our policies, procedures, tools, metrics, governance and culture. Embedding climate and environmental factors in our risk management includes the identification, planning, assessment, monitoring, mitigation and reporting, across different climate scenarios and time horizons defined, see further detail in the next section. Additionally, the risk function works to strengthen our strategy via the following processes:
  • ## Risk management and compliance E1-2 - Policies related to climate change mitigation and adaptation 2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)
  • Our approach aims to facilitate the achievement of our emissions targets and to develop a strong understanding of our customers' transition strategies towards low-carbon business models. This approach is supported by governance processes, involving various internal stakeholders, such as front office teams, risk reporting functions, and senior management to guide the potential portfolio steering actions (for more details, see the Portfolio Steering section below). It is structured around four main iterative steps: Collect, Assess, Engage and Review. We have used various internationally recognized references and the Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership (CISL) 'Let's Discuss Climate' guide as inputs and adapted them to our requirements and objectives.
  • ## Risk management and compliance ### Main areas involved in implementing our climate change strategy In 2024 we continued to embed climate management in business- as-usual across CIB, Risk and Sustainability. For instance, CIB strengthened its corresponding governance. And Wealth continued to reinforce and update the working groups and policies that oversee and coordinate its SRI strategy, described in section 3.2.2 'Responsible investment and social finance'. Consumer has different working groups that meet monthly to address sustainability projects and issues, and quarterly to review progress in the sustainability agenda. Beyond global businesses, a number of local units are engaged in a process coordinated by Group Responsible Banking. The objective is to progress the alignment agenda, promote knowledge and expertise sharing by local teams and seek synergy in the design of reliable transition plans.
  • ## Risk management and compliance 2. OUR CLIMATE TRANSITION PLAN (Environmental information)
  • The first step involves assessing how our customers' emissions trajectory aligns with our current sectoral portfolio baseline and future sectoral portfolio targets. The second step assesses the quality of each customer's transition plan. Our transition plan assessment methodology focuses on four pillars: 1. Targets: it focuses on the quality and ambition of the customer's quantitative GHG emissions targets. Where possible, we assess short- and long-term, as well as absolute and intensity reduction targets. 2. Action plan: it considers the credibility of the customer's alignment strategy. We assess the business strategy integration of climate change risks and opportunities; the existence of climate scenario planning; as well as time-bound action plans to achieve alignment targets.
  • ### 2.1.1 Our approach Santander considers climate a material topic, having identified impacts, risks and opportunities in the double materiality assessment. Per legal requirements, below we disclose our transition plan, based on three pillars. The purpose of each pillar is to support our customers and the communities we serve in their transition objectives; assess our customers' climate-related risks to manage the impact on their business and on our operations; and make progress with the alignment of our portfolios: 1 Supporting our customers in their transition goals
  • ## Risk management and compliance ### CIB implementation strategy As part of supporting our customers in their climate objectives and to achieve our sectoral alignment targets we undertake several actions. These actions include an assessment of the transition plans of our customers, customer engagement, and dedicated portfolio steering governance. We also leverage on data collection as part of the risk analysis process; as well as conducting ESCC exclusion policy reviews. Given our actions directly relate to the activity of our customers, it is not practical to make quantitative estimates for how each action contributes to achieving each of our targets. All actions described below cover the CIB business globally.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" La tabla detalla la información no financiera que debe divulgarse, organizada en tres columnas: "Non-financial information to be disclosed", "Chapter/section of the annual report" y "Correspondence with CSRD/other regulations". Los temas abordados incluyen: 1. **Efectos ambientales y riesgos**: Información sobre los efectos actuales y previsibles de las actividades de la empresa en el medio ambiente, incluyendo riesgos ambientales y provisiones, se encuentra en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y corresponde a regulaciones como SBM-3, IRO-1, MDR-A, MDR-M, E1, entre otras. 2. **Contaminación**: Medidas para prevenir, reducir o reparar emisiones de CO2 y otras formas de contaminación están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a MDR-A, E1-3, E1-7. 3. **Economía circular y gestión de residuos**: Acciones como prevención, reciclaje y reutilización de residuos se encuentran en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.4.5 Our environmental footprint]" y corresponden a E5, IRO-1. 4. **Uso sostenible de recursos**: Incluye el uso de agua y materias primas, con medidas para mejorar la eficiencia, en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135) [Table 2. Environmental footprint]", correspondiendo a E3, E5, IRO-1. 5. **Energía**: Consumo directo e indirecto, eficiencia energética y uso de energías renovables están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-A, MDR-M, E1-3, E1-5. 6. **Cambio climático**: Emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, medidas de adaptación y objetivos de reducción están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)" y "SN 7.1 Green transition (p. 135)", con regulaciones MDR-M, E1-6, MDR-T, E1-4. 7. **Biodiversidad**: Medidas para preservar o restaurar la biodiversidad están en "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32) [2.3.5 Our approach to nature and biodiversity]" y corresponden a E4, IRO-1.

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta información sobre la gestión de impactos, riesgos y oportunidades en el contexto del informe anual de Santander 2024. Contiene cinco columnas: "Impact, risk and opportunity management", "Section", "Sub-section", "Sub-sub-section" y "Comments". En la fila principal, se describe el proceso para identificar y evaluar impactos, riesgos y oportunidades climáticos materiales, etiquetado como "ESRS 2 IRO-1". Este proceso está vinculado a la sección "2. Our climate transition plan (p. 32)", la sub-sección "2.3 Embedding ESG in risk management (p. 40)" y la sub-sub-sección "2.3.2 Risk management cycle". La columna "Comments" no contiene información adicional.

Le plan de transition pour l'atténuation des risques climatiques est intégré dans la stratégie commerciale globale et la planification financière de l'entreprise à travers plusieurs éléments clés. Tout d'abord, la gestion des risques climatiques et environnementaux est incorporée à chaque étape du cycle de gestion des risques, comprenant l'identification, la planification, l'évaluation, le suivi, la mitigation et le reporting. Cela permet d'analyser les installations de l'entreprise et les processus de financement des clients sous différents scénarios climatiques et horizons temporels.

Ensuite, le plan de transition climatique s'articule autour de l'accompagnement des clients dans leurs objectifs de transition vers des modèles économiques bas-carbone. Cela implique une compréhension approfondie des stratégies de transition des clients, soutenue par des processus de gouvernance impliquant diverses parties prenantes internes telles que les équipes de front office, les fonctions de reporting des risques, et la direction générale.

De plus, l'entreprise a mis en place un processus structuré en quatre étapes itératives : Collecter, Évaluer, Engager et Réviser, en utilisant des références internationalement reconnues comme le guide "Let's Discuss Climate" du Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership (CISL).

Enfin, la stratégie de transition climatique est soutenue par un ensemble de politiques et de gouvernance renforcées, ainsi que par des groupes de travail dédiés aux enjeux de durabilité, qui se réunissent régulièrement pour coordonner et superviser les projets de durabilité et évaluer les progrès réalisés dans l'agenda de durabilité.

  • In 2024, we focused our customer engagement efforts on oil & gas as well as lower-tiered customers in other sectors. We developed internal transition assessment dashboards for relationship managers, designed to aid the identification of customer-level priority areas, industry benchmarking, and opportunities to support our customers in financing their transition. Of the customers that are in scope of our targets, approximately three quarters included sustainability-related discussions in 2024. In addition, on a wider scope of climate-related topics, we are engaging with various public and private organizations (for more details, see section 1.2 ‘Stakeholder engagement’). Review : The customer transition plan assessment is performed by relationship managers, in cooperation with ESCC risk analysts, followed by portfolio level reviews by Sustainability Solutions and Portfolio Alignment teams to determine final tierings. The portfolio In 2024, we focused our customer engagement efforts on oil & gas as well as lower-tiered customers in other sectors. We developed internal transition assessment dashboards for relationship managers, designed to aid the identification of customer-level priority areas, industry benchmarking, and opportunities to support our customers in financing their transition. Of the customers that are in scope of our targets, approximately three quarters included sustainability-related discussions in 2024. In addition, on a wider scope of climate-related topics, we are engaging with various public and private organizations (for more details, see section 1.2 ‘Stakeholder engagement’). Review : The customer transition plan assessment is performed by relationship managers, in cooperation with ESCC risk analysts, followed by portfolio level reviews by Sustainability Solutions and Portfolio Alignment teams to determine final tierings. The portfolio
  • Contents Business model Sustainability Corporate Economic and Risk management and strategy statement governance financial review and compliance SN 4. Our transition plan i.Alignment targets details Target types : To help our customers’ transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective. Contents Business model Sustainability Corporate Economic and Risk management and strategy statement governance financial review and compliance SN 4. Our transition plan i.Alignment targets details Target types : To help our customers’ transition to a low-carbon economy, we employ physical emissions intensity for setting targets in the power generation, steel, aviation and auto sectors. For the oil & gas sector, we choose the absolute emissions metric. We prioritize engagement over divestment. We recognize that in certain situations, establishing alignment targets may inadvertently discourage the transition. For example, when they increase their leverage to undertake significant capex programs to align their operations, while the alignment benefits will only materialise over the medium term. To prevent undesirable outcomes like the one described, we evaluate each case individually and base our decisions on a long-term perspective.
  • to support homogeneous implementation and provides a clear governance structure and allocation of responsibilities. For more details, see the following chart: 5.Mitigation We have various internal policies and frameworks that integrate climate and environmental factors into our risk management processes. These elements are key to mitigating and adapting climatic and environmental factors. Our ESCC risk management policy establishes the standards for investing, and providing financial products and services to companies and customers in oil & gas, power generation and distribution, mining and metals, and soft commodities (especially retail customers dedicated to farming and ranching in the Amazon). It dictates prohibited activities and those that require special attention for the aforementioned sectors6. Our credit granting policies consider climate and environmental factors such as, among others, our internal taxonomy (SFICS), to support homogeneous implementation and provides a clear governance structure and allocation of responsibilities. For more details, see the following chart: 5.Mitigation We have various internal policies and frameworks that integrate climate and environmental factors into our risk management processes. These elements are key to mitigating and adapting climatic and environmental factors. Our ESCC risk management policy establishes the standards for investing, and providing financial products and services to companies and customers in oil & gas, power generation and distribution, mining and metals, and soft commodities (especially retail customers dedicated to farming and ranching in the Amazon). It dictates prohibited activities and those that require special attention for the aforementioned sectors6. Our credit granting policies consider climate and environmental factors such as, among others, our internal taxonomy (SFICS),
  • change mitigation and adaptation plan (p. 32) E1-3 – Actions and resources in 2.   • GHG emissions reduction targets Transparency on GHG emissions reporting across relevant scopes Management oversight and governance of transition strategy Internally organized training sessions were delivered to sector- specific relationship managers and Environmental Social Climate Change Risk (ESCC) analysts. These focused on gathering information to complete the transition plan quality assessment (the second step in our customer climate tiering system). These sessions were delivered by senior experts from our ESCC, Portfolio Alignment and Sustainability Solutions teams. Expert resources from our global Sustainability Solutions team are made available for further education and advice on customers' transition plans assessment.Engage with customers: Our customer climate tiering system seeks to facilitate tailored transition dialogue to help lower-tiered customers move up to higher tiers over time. In 2024, we focused our customer engagement efforts on oil & gas GHG emissions reduction targets Transparency on GHG emissions reporting across relevant scopes Management oversight and governance of transition strategy Internally organized training sessions were delivered to sector- specific relationship managers and Environmental Social Climate Change Risk (ESCC) analysts.   • and wind energy projects in Spain and Portugal; and Santander Innoenergy Climate Fund, a venture capital strategy that invests in climate technology startups that work on renewable energy, smart grids, energy efficiency, storage systems, green energy batteries, mobility and the circular economy. SAM has an advisory mandate for LA Green, a blended finance fund to boost the SME green bond market in Latin America, mobilize large-scale capital and make a positive contribution to society and the environment. Moreover, SAM’s SRI products include solidarity funds that donate a portion of their fees to NGOs. In 2024, we boosted our proposition by making changes to two equity funds: Santander Sostenible Bonos and Santander Sostenible Renta Fija Ahorro, and two profiled funds: Santander Sostenible Crecimiento andSantander Sostenible Evolución a solidarios. These funds donated to several NGOs to educate young people at risk of exclusion and and wind energy projects in Spain and Portugal; and Santander Innoenergy Climate Fund, a venture capital strategy that invests in climate technology startups that work on renewable energy, smart grids, energy efficiency, storage systems, green energy batteries, mobility and the circular economy. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A. S1-121

Quelle est la répartition par sexe, exprimée en pourcentage, au niveau de l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise ?

Pour répondre à cette question, merci de fournir :
Le pourcentage de femmes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur.
Le pourcentage d'hommes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur.


Si possible, inclure des données comparatives sur l'évolution de cette répartition au fil des années.

La répartition par sexe au niveau de l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise pour les années 2024 et 2023 est la suivante :

Pourcentage de femmes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur : - En 2024, 38.4% des postes d'encadrement supérieur (Senior Executives et autres cadres) sont occupés par des femmes. Cette statistique exclut les coentreprises. - Pour 2023, la répartition précise pour les femmes n'est pas spécifiée directement dans les documents fournis.

Pourcentage d'hommes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur : - En 2024, 61.6% des postes d'encadrement supérieur sont occupés par des hommes (complémentaire aux 38.4% de femmes). - Pour 2023, la répartition précise pour les hommes n'est pas spécifiée directement dans les documents fournis.

Il n'y a pas d'autres données comparatives disponibles dans les documents pour l'évolution de cette répartition au fil des années.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta una visión general de los pilares de transición relacionados con la reducción de emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero (GEI). Los pilares son: 1. **Targets**: Evalúa la calidad y ambición de los objetivos cuantitativos para reducir las emisiones de GEI. 2. **Action plan**: Examina la profundidad de la estrategia de alineación para alcanzar los objetivos de reducción de emisiones de GEI. 3. **Disclosure**: Analiza la transparencia en la presentación de informes sobre emisiones de GEI en los ámbitos relevantes. 4. **Governance**: Considera la supervisión y gobernanza de la estrategia de transición por parte de la gestión. ### END TABLE and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1
    Transition Pillar Overview
    1. Targets Quality and ambition of quantitative targets to reduce GHG emissions
    2. Action plan Depth of alignment strategy to achieve GHG emissions reduction targets
    3. Disclosure Transparency on GHG emissions reporting across relevant scopes
    4. Governance of transition strategy Management oversight and governance
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento" del informe anual de Santander 2024: 1. **Etiquetas de columnas**: "Risk type", "Climate1 and environmental drivers", "Time horizon analysed", "Potential Impact of climate and environmental risk factors", "What we're doing to manage climate and environmental risk", "Next steps". 2. **Riesgo de mercado**: Analizado en el corto plazo, incluye impactos como alta volatilidad en factores de mercado, cambios en la percepción del mercado y condiciones climáticas extremas que afectan los planes de negocio. Acciones incluyen revisiones regulares de escenarios de estrés climático y análisis de exposición de la cartera de trading. Próximos pasos: mejorar las pruebas de estrés y adaptarlas a las mejores prácticas del mercado. 3. **Riesgo de liquidez**: Evaluado en el corto plazo, considera impactos como la reducción del valor de activos líquidos de alta calidad (HQLAs) y mayores salidas de efectivo debido a percepciones de mercado. Acciones incluyen análisis cualitativos y cuantitativos de escenarios climáticos. Próximos pasos: incluir nuevos escenarios de liquidez en las pruebas de estrés. 4. **Riesgo operativo**: Analizado en el corto, mediano y largo plazo, abarca eventos climáticos severos que dañan activos y afectan la continuidad del negocio, así como pérdidas por litigios o incumplimientos de estándares ESG. Acciones incluyen controles de autoevaluación de riesgos operativos relacionados con ESG, análisis de escenarios de riesgo extremo y evaluación de amenazas climáticas en la continuidad del negocio. 5. **Próximos pasos en riesgo operativo**: Mejorar los reportes de riesgos operativos relacionados con el clima, promover la cooperación en la industria para compartir datos y mejores prácticas, y trabajar con el equipo de seguros corporativos para analizar la asegurabilidad de las pérdidas relacionadas con el clima. 6. **Otras acciones en riesgo operativo**: Evaluación de materialidad de riesgos operativos relacionados con el clima, actualización de documentación y capacitación sobre factores ESG, e inclusión de una bandera ESG en la base de datos de eventos de riesgo operativo. and

    Risk management and compliance

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1 2 3 4 5
    Risk type Climate1 and environmental drivers Time horizon analysed Potential Impact of climate and environmental risk factors What we're doing to manage climate and environmental risk Next steps
    Market Short term + High volatility in market factors under stress scenarios. + Regular reviews of climate stress scenarios and the subsidiaries that + Enhance stress testing by reviewing new
    + Changes in market perception leading to wider credit spreads for business in impacted sectors. apply them. + Stress testing using physical and transition risk scenarios. scenarios to include in the exercise. + Adapt stress testing to
    > Extreme weather conditions could raise concerns about the business plans of companies operating in the impacted sectors and widen their credit spreads. + Trading portfolio analysis of current exposure to climate-sensitive business activities. market practices.
    Liquidity Short term > Market impacts on the value of high quality liquid assets in Santander's liquidity buffer. > Qualitative and quantitative climate scenario analyses of impacts on highly liquid assets (HQLAs) and financing of + Enhance stress testing and reviewing new scenarios to include
    - More frequent extreme weather that stifles economic growth in countries susceptible to climate change, causing sovereign debt to rise and limiting access to capital markets. exposed companies. - Analysis of higher outflows due to changes in market perception of corporations in climate-sensitive business activities. them in the exercise. + Adapt stress testing to best market practices, including new liquidity scenarios to measure their impact.
    > Cash outflows from companies trying to boost their reputation in the market or solve problems with climate scenarios. - Extreme weather conditions could cause financial impact on companies operating in the affected sectors impacting the funds deposited in the bank.
    Operational Short - medium - long term + Severe climate events can cause damage to our assets, including branches, data centers, headquarters and other owned or rented properties. Impacts on our own or our suppliers' premises can also affect business continuity. + Conducting operational risk and self- assessment controls that include ESG- related risks to evaluate our exposure. > Conducting mandatory operational risk scenario analysis that cover extreme physical and transition risk events. - Enhance operational risk reporting on climate and environmental - related factors. > Promote cooperation within the industry to
    > Climate and environmental - related factors can also lead to operational risk losses from litigation, claims due to inadequate sales or non-compliance with ESG standards. -> Including an ESG flag in the operational risk events database to identify events and losses from climate-related and environmental risks. > Including an assessment of climate threats in business continuity scenarios. share data, scenarios and best practices on climate-related operational risk management. > Work with the Corporate Insurance team to conduct analyses on the insurability of climate-related losses.
    + Conducting a materiality assessment on climate-related operational risk.
    + Updating documentation and delivering training relating to the embedding of ESG factors across operational risk management, as well as sharing best practices throughout the Group.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la proporción de exposiciones alineadas con la Taxonomía y su desglose según diferentes criterios. Los datos están organizados en columnas y filas con los siguientes detalles: 1. **Proporción de exposiciones alineadas con la Taxonomía**: - **Para empresas no financieras**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: 0.5% (47 millones de euros). - Basado en gastos de capital: 0.9% (74 millones de euros). - **Para empresas financieras**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: 0.9% (78 millones de euros). - Basado en gastos de capital: 1.2% (103 millones de euros). 2. **Proporción de inversiones de aseguradoras o reaseguradoras alineadas con la Taxonomía**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: * (valor no especificado). - Basado en gastos de capital: * (valor no especificado). 3. **Proporción de exposiciones a otros contrapartes y activos**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: 0% (0 millones de euros). - Basado en gastos de capital: 0% (0 millones de euros). 4. **Desglose del numerador del KPI por objetivo ambiental**: - **Actividades alineadas con la Taxonomía**: - Mitigación del cambio climático: volumen de negocios 1.4%, gastos de capital 2.0%. - Adaptación al cambio climático: volumen de negocios 0.0%, gastos de capital 0.0%. - **Actividades transicionales**: - Volumen de negocios: 0.0%. - Gastos de capital: 0.1%. - **Actividades habilitadoras**: - Volumen de negocios: 0.7%. - Gastos de capital: 0.7%. and

La répartition par sexe au niveau de l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise en 2024 est la suivante :

  • Le pourcentage de femmes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur est de 31,2 %.
  • Le pourcentage d'hommes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur est de 68,8 %.

En termes d'évolution au fil des années, le pourcentage de femmes dans des postes d'encadrement supérieur a augmenté de 22,7 % en 2019 à 31,2 % en 2024.

  • ### BEGIN TABLE La tabla presenta una visión general de los pilares de transición relacionados con la reducción de emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero (GEI). Los pilares son: 1. **Targets**: Evalúa la calidad y ambición de los objetivos cuantitativos para reducir las emisiones de GEI. 2. **Action plan**: Examina la profundidad de la estrategia de alineación para alcanzar los objetivos de reducción de emisiones de GEI. 3. **Disclosure**: Analiza la transparencia en la presentación de informes sobre emisiones de GEI en los ámbitos relevantes. 4. **Governance**: Considera la supervisión y gobernanza de la estrategia de transición por parte de la gestión. ### END TABLE
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento" del informe anual de Santander 2024: 1. **Etiquetas de columnas**: "Risk type", "Climate1 and environmental drivers", "Time horizon analysed", "Potential Impact of climate and environmental risk factors", "What we're doing to manage climate and environmental risk", "Next steps". 2. **Riesgo de mercado**: Analizado en el corto plazo, incluye impactos como alta volatilidad en factores de mercado, cambios en la percepción del mercado y condiciones climáticas extremas que afectan los planes de negocio. Acciones incluyen revisiones regulares de escenarios de estrés climático y análisis de exposición de la cartera de trading. Próximos pasos: mejorar las pruebas de estrés y adaptarlas a las mejores prácticas del mercado. 3. **Riesgo de liquidez**: Evaluado en el corto plazo, considera impactos como la reducción del valor de activos líquidos de alta calidad (HQLAs) y mayores salidas de efectivo debido a percepciones de mercado. Acciones incluyen análisis cualitativos y cuantitativos de escenarios climáticos. Próximos pasos: incluir nuevos escenarios de liquidez en las pruebas de estrés. 4. **Riesgo operativo**: Analizado en el corto, mediano y largo plazo, abarca eventos climáticos severos que dañan activos y afectan la continuidad del negocio, así como pérdidas por litigios o incumplimientos de estándares ESG. Acciones incluyen controles de autoevaluación de riesgos operativos relacionados con ESG, análisis de escenarios de riesgo extremo y evaluación de amenazas climáticas en la continuidad del negocio. 5. **Próximos pasos en riesgo operativo**: Mejorar los reportes de riesgos operativos relacionados con el clima, promover la cooperación en la industria para compartir datos y mejores prácticas, y trabajar con el equipo de seguros corporativos para analizar la asegurabilidad de las pérdidas relacionadas con el clima. 6. **Otras acciones en riesgo operativo**: Evaluación de materialidad de riesgos operativos relacionados con el clima, actualización de documentación y capacitación sobre factores ESG, e inclusión de una bandera ESG en la base de datos de eventos de riesgo operativo.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la proporción de exposiciones alineadas con la Taxonomía y su desglose según diferentes criterios. Los datos están organizados en columnas y filas con los siguientes detalles: 1. **Proporción de exposiciones alineadas con la Taxonomía**: - **Para empresas no financieras**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: 0.5% (47 millones de euros). - Basado en gastos de capital: 0.9% (74 millones de euros). - **Para empresas financieras**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: 0.9% (78 millones de euros). - Basado en gastos de capital: 1.2% (103 millones de euros). 2. **Proporción de inversiones de aseguradoras o reaseguradoras alineadas con la Taxonomía**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: * (valor no especificado). - Basado en gastos de capital: * (valor no especificado). 3. **Proporción de exposiciones a otros contrapartes y activos**: - Basado en el volumen de negocios: 0% (0 millones de euros). - Basado en gastos de capital: 0% (0 millones de euros). 4. **Desglose del numerador del KPI por objetivo ambiental**: - **Actividades alineadas con la Taxonomía**: - Mitigación del cambio climático: volumen de negocios 1.4%, gastos de capital 2.0%. - Adaptación al cambio climático: volumen de negocios 0.0%, gastos de capital 0.0%. - **Actividades transicionales**: - Volumen de negocios: 0.0%. - Gastos de capital: 0.1%. - **Actividades habilitadoras**: - Volumen de negocios: 0.7%. - Gastos de capital: 0.7%.

La répartition par sexe au niveau de l'encadrement supérieur de l'entreprise pour les années 2024 et 2023 est la suivante :

Pourcentage de femmes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur : - En 2024, 38.4% des postes d'encadrement supérieur (Senior Executives et autres cadres) sont occupés par des femmes. Cette statistique exclut les coentreprises. - Pour 2023, la répartition précise pour les femmes n'est pas spécifiée directement dans les documents fournis.

Pourcentage d'hommes occupant des postes d'encadrement supérieur : - En 2024, 61.6% des postes d'encadrement supérieur sont occupés par des hommes (complémentaire aux 38.4% de femmes). - Pour 2023, la répartition précise pour les hommes n'est pas spécifiée directement dans les documents fournis.

Il n'y a pas d'autres données comparatives disponibles dans les documents pour l'évolution de cette répartition au fil des années.

  • and strategy statement governance financial review and compliance Gender We promote career development based on merit and support our high potential employees at every level to foster variety of leadership47 . 40% of our board members are women, which meets our goal for women to make up 40% to 60% of our directors. This goal will become a legal obligation in some jurisdictions from 2026. Over the past five years, we have increased the number of women in or senior executive positions from 22.7% in 2019 to 31.2% in 2024 — reaching 34.4% in our core Retail & Commercial business48 . This indicator used as reference the senior executives with the highest ranking in the organisation, representing 1% of the total workforce. Therefore, we agreed to expand the base reference49 , a move that is possible thanks to more quality data and greater analytical capacity, with common management and development programmes across the Group, which also responds to stakeholder and strategy statement governance financial review and compliance Gender We promote career development based on merit and support our high potential employees at every level to foster variety of leadership47 . 40% of our board members are women, which meets our goal for women to make up 40% to 60% of our directors. This goal will become a legal obligation in some jurisdictions from 2026. Over the past five years, we have increased the number of women in or senior executive positions from 22.7% in 2019 to 31.2% in 2024 — reaching 34.4% in our core Retail & Commercial business48 . This indicator used as reference the senior executives with the highest ranking in the organisation, representing 1% of the total workforce. Therefore, we agreed to expand the base reference49 , a move that is possible thanks to more quality data and greater analytical capacity, with common management and development programmes across the Group, which also responds to stakeholder
  • 2024 2023 Argentina 2 1 Brazil 5 4 Chile 1 1 Uruguay 1 2 Spain 3 3 Poland 3 3 Portugal 3 2 UK 4 5 Mexico 3 2 USA 6 9 NPS to measure customer satisfaction, audited by Stiga/Deloitte.   • Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A. As in the rest of this chapter, we only include information about our employees. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A. As in the rest of this chapter, we only include information about our employees. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional
  • sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable. sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable.
  • inputs81 that we use for the development and marketing of products and services. This includes companies with which the bank has a direct and indirect commercial relationship. •Financial institution s: Monetary institution and public entity responsible for setting monetary policy that will impact on Banco Santander; regulating currency circulation; supervising the interbank market in which the bank operates; and providing liquidity, where required, for solvency purposes. For instance, the European Central Bank, Banco de España, Bundesbank, Narodowy Bank Polski, etc. •Product and service providers : Companies that provide products and services that are subsequently marketed in later phases of the bank’s value chain or that the bank uses to carry out its operations. For instance, insurance companies (e.g. suppliers of products that are marketed in the bank’s downstream phase), technology providers, external audit and consulting service providers, materials suppliers and office inputs81 that we use for the development and marketing of products and services. S1-145

Renseignez le pourcentage total de salariés en situation de handicap.

Si possible, donnez des informations sur l'évolution de ce pourcentage au fil des années.

Je suis désolé, mais les informations sur le pourcentage total de salariés en situation de handicap, ainsi que son évolution au fil des années, ne sont pas présentes dans les documents fournis.


Afficher les sourcesLLM

  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta datos financieros en millones de euros para el año 2024, desglosados en categorías relacionadas con la mitigación del cambio climático (CCM), la adaptación al cambio climático (CCA) y el total combinado (CCM + CCA). Las columnas incluyen información sobre sectores relevantes para la taxonomía (Taxonomy-eligible), sostenibilidad ambiental (Taxonomy-aligned), y detalles como el uso de los ingresos (Use of Proceeds), actividades transicionales (transitional) y habilitadoras (enabling). 1. **Trading book (52)**: Total bruto de 230,185 millones EUR sin desglose adicional. 2. **Total assets (53)**: Total de 1,872,390 millones EUR, con 447,158 millones EUR destinados a CCM y 101 millones EUR a CCA. De estos, 42,818 millones EUR son relevantes para la taxonomía en CCM y 17 millones EUR en CCA. 3. **Financial guarantees (54)**: Total de 16,898 millones EUR, con 1,282 millones EUR para CCM y 39 millones EUR para CCA. De estos, 570 millones EUR son relevantes para la taxonomía en CCM y 15 millones EUR en CCA. 4. **Assets under management (55)**: Total de 156,908 millones EUR, con 13,238 millones EUR para CCM y 348 millones EUR para CCA. De estos, 3,345 millones EUR son relevantes para la taxonomía en CCM y 15 millones EUR en CCA. 5. **Of which debt securities (56)**: Total de 71,062 millones EUR, con 8,288 millones EUR para CCM y 292 millones EUR para CCA. De estos, 1,665 millones EUR son relevantes para la taxonomía en CCM y 2 millones EUR en CCA. 6. **Of which equity instruments (57)**: Total de 63,320 millones EUR, con 4,744 millones EUR para CCM y 54 millones EUR para CCA. De estos, 1,616 millones EUR son relevantes para la taxonomía en CCM y 12 millones EUR en CCA. Los datos reflejan el compromiso del Grupo Santander con la sostenibilidad y la alineación con la taxonomía ambiental en sus activos y exposiciones fuera de balance. and

    Risk management and compliance

  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta un desglose por sector según el nivel NACE de 4 dígitos (código y etiqueta) para el año 2024, destacando los montos brutos en millones de euros (Mn EUR) relacionados con la mitigación del cambio climático (CCM) y la adaptación al cambio climático (CCA), tanto para corporaciones no financieras sujetas a NFRD como para PYMEs y otras NFC no sujetas a NFRD. También se incluye un total combinado (CCM + CCA). 1. En el sector "F4299 - Construction of other civil engineering projects n.e.c.", el monto bruto total es de 90 Mn EUR, de los cuales 10 Mn EUR son sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM). 2. En "F4312 - Site preparation", el monto bruto total es de 390 Mn EUR, con solo 2 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM). 3. En "G4511 - Sale of cars and light motor vehicles", el monto bruto total es de 552 Mn EUR, con 81 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM). 4. En "H4950 - Transport via pipeline", el monto bruto total es de 148 Mn EUR, con 134 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM). 5. En "J6120 - Wireless telecommunications activities", el monto bruto total es de 379 Mn EUR, con 31 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM y CCA combinados). 6. En "L6810 - Buying and selling of own real estate", el monto bruto total es de 148 Mn EUR, con 73 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM). 7. En "M7010 - Activities of head offices", el monto bruto total es de 937 Mn EUR, con 562 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM y CCA combinados). 8. Los sectores "G4641 - Wholesale of textiles", "I5510 - Hotels and similar accommodation" y "L Real estate activities" no presentan montos sostenibles ambientalmente. 9. En general, los sectores con mayores montos sostenibles ambientalmente son "M7010 - Activities of head offices" y "H4950 - Transport via pipeline". 10. La tabla destaca la importancia de la sostenibilidad ambiental en sectores clave, aunque algunos sectores no muestran contribuciones significativas en términos de sostenibilidad. and

    Risk management and compliance

Je suis désolé, mais les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations sur le pourcentage total de salariés en situation de handicap ni sur l'évolution de ce pourcentage au fil des années.

Sources Pypdf :
  • ### END TABLE A. Percentage of employees covered by collective agreement, as defined by CSRD. The aggregate average is 74%, among main entities in our 16 relevant countries that aggregately represent 98% of our global headcount, that aggregate average is similar to previous period.
  • ### END TABLE A. Average headcount throughout the year. We reclassified genders according to CSRD definitions. The breakdown remains stable, with an average 52% women employees against 53% in 2023. The breakdown by contract type also remains similar: The average headcount with a permanent contract is 98%, while the average headcount with a full-time contract is 96.5%, the same figures as in 2023.
  • ### Summary of the Table (2024) The table titled "Employees by employment contract" provides data for the year 2024, categorized by gender (Men, Women, Other, Not declared) and totals. It includes the following labels and rows: 1. **Number of employees**: 98,377 Men, 108,319 Women, 6 Other, 51 Not declared, totaling 206,753. 2. **Number of permanent employees**: 96,541 Men, 105,942 Women, 6 Other, 13 Not declared, totaling 202,502. 3. **Number of temporary employees**: 1,836 Men, 2,377 Women, 0 Other, 38 Not declared, totaling 4,251. 4. **Number of full-time employees**: 97,163 Men, 102,740 Women, 5 Other, 50 Not declared, totaling 199,958. 5. **Number of part-time employees**: 1,214 Men, 5,579 Women, 1 Other, 1 Not declared, totaling 6,795. 6. **Number of non-guaranteed hours employees**: 0 across all categories, totaling 0. The table highlights employment contract types and gender distribution for the year 2024.
  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data for the year 2024, categorized by regions (Europe, North America, South America, and Group total) and age brackets (aged < 30, aged 30 - 50, and age over 50). - **Europe**: 11,842 employees aged < 30 (13.57%), 54,262 aged 30 - 50 (62.19%), and 21,147 aged over 50 (24.24%). - **North America**: 10,485 employees aged < 30 (25.33%), 25,239 aged 30 - 50 (60.97%), and 5,675 aged over 50 (13.71%). - **South America**: 22,372 employees aged < 30 (28.64%), 49,183 aged 30 - 50 (62.97%), and 6,548 aged over 50 (8.38%). - **Group total**: 44,699 employees aged < 30 (21.62%), 128,684 aged 30 - 50 (62.24%), and 33,370 aged over 50 (16.14%). The percentages represent the proportion of employees in each age bracket relative to the total workforce in the respective region or group.
  • ### END TABLE A. At year end. 98% of employees in Santander have a permanent employment contract and 97% have full-time contract, as in 2023. For additional definitions see 7. Employees by gender.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos sobre el promedio de empleados en 2024, desglosados por tipo de contrato y rango de edad. Las etiquetas de las columnas son: "Under 30", "30-50", "Over 50" y "Total". Las filas incluyen: 1. **Average employees**: 46,556 empleados menores de 30 años, 129,728 entre 30-50 años, 32,828 mayores de 50 años, totalizando 209,112. 2. **Average permanent employees**: 44,748 menores de 30 años, 127,682 entre 30-50 años, 32,531 mayores de 50 años, totalizando 204,960. 3. **Average temporary employees**: 1,808 menores de 30 años, 2,046 entre 30-50 años, 297 mayores de 50 años, totalizando 4,151. 4. **Average full-time employees**: 45,412 menores de 30 años, 125,537 entre 30-50 años, 30,999 mayores de 50 años, totalizando 201,949. 5. **Average part-time employees**: 1,143 menores de 30 años, 4,191 entre 30-50 años, 1,829 mayores de 50 años, totalizando 7,163. Los datos reflejan el desglose de empleados según la Ley 11/2018.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos de empleados promedio en 2024, desglosados por tipo de contrato y género. Las etiquetas de las columnas son: "Women", "Men", "Other", "Not declared" y "Total". Las filas incluyen: 1. **Average employees**: 109,762 mujeres, 99,257 hombres, 6 en "Other", 86 en "Not declared", totalizando 209,112 empleados. 2. **Average permanent employees**: 107,404 mujeres, 97,487 hombres, 6 en "Other", 64 en "Not declared", con un total de 204,960 empleados. 3. **Average temporary employees**: 2,358 mujeres, 1,771 hombres, 0 en "Other", 22 en "Not declared", sumando 4,151 empleados. 4. **Average full-time employees**: 103,837 mujeres, 98,023 hombres, 6 en "Other", 83 en "Not declared", totalizando 201,949 empleados. 5. **Average part-time employees**: 5,925 mujeres, 1,234 hombres, 0 en "Other", 3 en "Not declared", con un total de 7,163 empleados. Los datos reflejan la distribución de empleados promedio por género y tipo de contrato en el año 2024.

  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos sobre "Other executives C" en los años 2024 y 2023, desglosados por género y región. Las etiquetas de las columnas son: "Men", "Women", "Others", "Not declared", y "Total". Las filas incluyen las regiones "Europe", "North America", "South America", y "Group total". En Europa, en 2024, hubo 8,850 hombres, 5,096 mujeres, 1 persona en "Others", y 6 en "Not declared", sumando un total de 13,953. En 2023, hubo 10,704 hombres, 7,629 mujeres, y ningún dato en "Others" ni "Not declared", con un total de 18,333. En Norteamérica, en 2024, hubo 3,881 hombres, 2,622 mujeres, 0 en "Others", y 3 en "Not declared", sumando 6,506. En 2023, hubo 3,778 hombres, 2,522 mujeres, y ningún dato en "Others" ni "Not declared", con un total de 6,300. En Sudamérica, en 2024, hubo 3,982 hombres, 2,996 mujeres, 0 en "Others", y 1 en "Not declared", sumando 6,979. En 2023, hubo 3,878 hombres, 2,708 mujeres, y ningún dato en "Others" ni "Not declared", con un total de 6,586. El total del grupo en 2024 fue de 16,713 hombres, 10,714 mujeres, 1 en "Others", y 10 en "Not declared", sumando 27,438. En 2023, el total fue de 18,360 hombres, 12,859 mujeres, y ningún dato en "Others" ni "Not declared", con un total de 31,219.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta datos financieros en millones de euros para el año 2024, desglosados en categorías relacionadas con la mitigación del cambio climático (CCM), la adaptación al cambio climático (CCA) y el total combinado (CCM + CCA). Las columnas incluyen información sobre sectores relevantes para la taxonomía (Taxonomy-eligible), sostenibilidad ambiental (Taxonomy-aligned), y detalles como el uso de los ingresos (Use of Proceeds), actividades transicionales (transitional) y habilitadoras (enabling). 1. **Trading book (52)**: Total bruto de 230,185 millones EUR sin desglose adicional. 2. **Total assets (53)**: Total de 1,872,390 millones EUR, con 447,158 millones EUR destinados a CCM y 101 millones EUR a CCA. De estos, 42,818 millones EUR son relevantes para la taxonomía en CCM y 17 millones EUR en CCA. 3. **Financial guarantees (54)**: Total de 16,898 millones EUR, con 1,282 millones EUR para CCM y 39 millones EUR para CCA. De estos, 570 millones EUR son relevantes para la taxonomía en CCM y 15 millones EUR en CCA. 4. **Assets under management (55)**: Total de 156,908 millones EUR, con 13,238 millones EUR para CCM y 348 millones EUR para CCA. De estos, 3,345 millones EUR son relevantes para la taxonomía en CCM y 15 millones EUR en CCA. 5. **Of which debt securities (56)**: Total de 71,062 millones EUR, con 8,288 millones EUR para CCM y 292 millones EUR para CCA. De estos, 1,665 millones EUR son relevantes para la taxonomía en CCM y 2 millones EUR en CCA. 6. **Of which equity instruments (57)**: Total de 63,320 millones EUR, con 4,744 millones EUR para CCM y 54 millones EUR para CCA. De estos, 1,616 millones EUR son relevantes para la taxonomía en CCM y 12 millones EUR en CCA. Los datos reflejan el compromiso del Grupo Santander con la sostenibilidad y la alineación con la taxonomía ambiental en sus activos y exposiciones fuera de balance.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta un desglose por sector según el nivel NACE de 4 dígitos (código y etiqueta) para el año 2024, destacando los montos brutos en millones de euros (Mn EUR) relacionados con la mitigación del cambio climático (CCM) y la adaptación al cambio climático (CCA), tanto para corporaciones no financieras sujetas a NFRD como para PYMEs y otras NFC no sujetas a NFRD. También se incluye un total combinado (CCM + CCA). 1. En el sector "F4299 - Construction of other civil engineering projects n.e.c.", el monto bruto total es de 90 Mn EUR, de los cuales 10 Mn EUR son sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM). 2. En "F4312 - Site preparation", el monto bruto total es de 390 Mn EUR, con solo 2 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM). 3. En "G4511 - Sale of cars and light motor vehicles", el monto bruto total es de 552 Mn EUR, con 81 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM). 4. En "H4950 - Transport via pipeline", el monto bruto total es de 148 Mn EUR, con 134 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM). 5. En "J6120 - Wireless telecommunications activities", el monto bruto total es de 379 Mn EUR, con 31 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM y CCA combinados). 6. En "L6810 - Buying and selling of own real estate", el monto bruto total es de 148 Mn EUR, con 73 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM). 7. En "M7010 - Activities of head offices", el monto bruto total es de 937 Mn EUR, con 562 Mn EUR sostenibles ambientalmente (CCM y CCA combinados). 8. Los sectores "G4641 - Wholesale of textiles", "I5510 - Hotels and similar accommodation" y "L Real estate activities" no presentan montos sostenibles ambientalmente. 9. En general, los sectores con mayores montos sostenibles ambientalmente son "M7010 - Activities of head offices" y "H4950 - Transport via pipeline". 10. La tabla destaca la importancia de la sostenibilidad ambiental en sectores clave, aunque algunos sectores no muestran contribuciones significativas en términos de sostenibilidad.

Je suis désolé, mais les informations sur le pourcentage total de salariés en situation de handicap, ainsi que son évolution au fil des années, ne sont pas présentes dans les documents fournis.

  • Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A. As in the rest of this chapter, we only include information about our employees. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A. As in the rest of this chapter, we only include information about our employees. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional

Annual report 2024 196
  • sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable. sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable.
  • shares are meant to help the foundation financially; it can use the dividends to cover some (if not all) of the cost of fulfilling its founding purposes.66 These include managing the bank's art collection and financing numerous literary, educational, social, cultural and environmental productions and activities, in which the remodelling of the Santander's headquarters on Paseo de Pereda in Santander and our relations with universities in Spain will play an important role. For more details, visit the website fundacionbancosantander.com/es/ fundacion/transparencia. We have other Santander foundations in countries where we operate (Argentina, the US, Mexico, Portugal, Poland and the UK), which boost the number of initiatives we run. Their focus varies according to local needs; for instance, in Argentina on art and culture; in Portugal on education, inclusion and culture; and in Poland on education for children and young people. Activities from shares are meant to help the foundation financially; it can use the dividends to cover some (if not all) of the cost of fulfilling its founding purposes.66 These include managing the bank's art collection and financing numerous literary, educational, social, cultural and environmental productions and activities, in which the remodelling of the Santander's headquarters on Paseo de Pereda in Santander and our relations with universities in Spain will play an important role. For more details, visit the website fundacionbancosantander.com/es/ fundacion/transparencia. We have other Santander foundations in countries where we operate (Argentina, the US, Mexico, Portugal, Poland and the UK), which boost the number of initiatives we run. Their focus varies according to local needs; for instance, in Argentina on art and culture; in Portugal on education, inclusion and culture; and in Poland on education for children and young people. Activities from
S1-147

L'entreprise communique-t-elle toutes les informations contextuelles nécessaires pour comprendre les données relatives aux salariés en situation de handicap et la manière dont elles ont été compilées ?

nan

Je ne sais pas si l'entreprise communique toutes les informations contextuelles nécessaires pour comprendre les données relatives aux salariés en situation de handicap et la manière dont elles ont été compilées.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento" La tabla presenta información no financiera que debe ser divulgada, organizada en tres columnas: "Información no financiera a divulgar", "Capítulo/sección del informe anual" y "Correspondencia con CSRD/otras regulaciones". Los temas abordados incluyen: 1. **Empleo**: Datos sobre el número total y distribución de empleados por género, edad, país y clasificación profesional; modalidades de contrato; despidos; remuneración promedio y su evolución; brecha salarial; políticas de desconexión laboral; y empleados con discapacidades. Referencias: SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191), 3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p.75), y regulaciones MDR-M, MDR-P y GOV-3. 2. **Organización del trabajo**: Tiempo de trabajo, horas de ausencia, medidas para el equilibrio entre vida laboral y personal. Referencias: SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191), 3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p.75), y regulaciones MDR-P, MDR-A. 3. **Salud y seguridad**: Condiciones de seguridad en el lugar de trabajo, accidentes laborales y enfermedades ocupacionales. Referencias: SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191), 3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p.75), y regulaciones MDR-A, MDR-M. 4. **Relaciones sociales**: Diálogo social, acuerdos colectivos, y mecanismos para la participación de los trabajadores en la gestión empresarial. Referencias: SN 7. Our progress in figures (p. 134), 3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p.75), 4. Business conduct (p. 100), y regulaciones MDR-A, MDR-M. 5. **Formación**: Políticas de formación y número total de horas de capacitación por categorías profesionales. Referencias: SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191), 3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p.75), y regulaciones MDR-P, MDR-M. and

  • ### SN 7. Our progress in figures The table summarizes progress in risk management and compliance across various categories. **SN 7.1 Green transition** includes data on **Table 1. GHG mitigation projects financed through carbon credits**, and **Table 5 Equator principles**, spanning pages 135–139. **SN 7.2 EU taxonomy tables** are detailed on page 140. **SN 7.3 Employees** covers **Table 6. Employees by region**, **Table 7. Employees by gender**, **Table 8. Employees by management group and gender**, **Table 9. Employees by age bracket**, **Table 10. Employees by employment contract**, **Table 11. Collective bargaining coverage and social dialogue**, and **Table 12. Turnover by region**, spanning pages 191–193. Further employee-related data includes **Table 13. Average remuneration by management group, gender and age bracket**, **Table 14. Remuneration ratios**, **Table 15. Average remuneration of senior management**, **Table 16. Average remuneration of senior management linked to long-term objectives**, and **Table 17. Senior management composition**, on pages 194–195. Training and safety are covered in **Table 18. Training**, **Table 19. Hours of training by gender and management group**, and **Table 20. Occupational health and safety**, all on page 195. and

Supporting employees, communities and customers (p. 75)" y "3.1 Our employees (p. 75)", bajo el tema "3.1.3 Inclusive culture". 2. **S1-13 - Métricas de formación y desarrollo de habilidades**: Asociado con "3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p. 75)", "Sustainability notes (p. 107)", "3.1 Our employees (p. 75)", y "SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191)", bajo "3.1.1 Talent and skills development". Incluye "Table 20. Training" y "Table 21. Hours of training by gender and management group". 3. **S1-14 - Métricas de salud y seguridad**: Relacionado con "3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p. 75)", "Sustainability notes (p. 107)", "3.1 Our employees (p. 75)", y "SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191)", bajo "3.1.2 Working conditions". Incluye "Table 22. Occupational health and safety". Se menciona el uso de la fase de implementación del ESRS para información específica de no empleados (ESRS S1, S1-14, para. 89). 4. **S1-16 - Métricas de compensación (brecha salarial y compensación total)**: Asociado con "3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p. 75)", "Sustainability notes (p. 107)", "3.1 Our employees (p. 75)", y "SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191)", bajo "3.1.2 Working conditions". Incluye "Table 16. Remuneration ratios". 5. **S1-17 - Incidentes, quejas e impactos graves en derechos humanos**: Relacionado con "3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p. 75)", "4. Business conduct (p. 75)", "3.1 Our employees (p. 75)", y "4.3 Ethical channels (p. 104)", bajo "3.1.3 Inclusive culture". and

  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on "Collective Bargaining Coverage" and "Social Dialogue" for employees in different regions, categorized by coverage rates. 1. **Labels and Columns**: The table includes the following labels: "Collective Bargaining Coverage" and "Social Dialogue." The columns are "Coverage Rate," "Employees - EEA (European Economic Area) (for countries with >50 employees representing >10% total employees)," "Employees - Non-EEA (estimate for regions with >50 employees representing >10% total employees)," and "Workplace representation (EEA only) (for countries with >50 employees representing >10% total employees)." 2. **Coverage Rate 0-19%**: Poland is listed under "Employees - EEA," the United States under "Employees - Non-EEA," and no data is provided for "Workplace representation." 3. **Coverage Rate 20-39%**: No EEA countries are listed, Mexico is listed under "Employees - Non-EEA," and no data is provided for "Workplace representation." 4. **Coverage Rate 40-59%**: No data is provided for any column. 5. **Coverage Rate 60-79%**: No data is provided for any column. 6. **Coverage Rate 80-100%**: Portugal and Spain are listed under "Employees - EEA," Argentina, Brazil, Chile, and the United Kingdom under "Employees - Non-EEA," and Spain, Poland, and Portugal under "Workplace representation." and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información no financiera que debe divulgarse, organizada en tres columnas: "Non-financial information to be disclosed", "Chapter/section of the annual report" y "Correspondence with CSRD/other regulations". Los temas incluyen: 1. **Compromisos de la empresa con el desarrollo sostenible**: Impacto en empleo y desarrollo local (capítulo "Sustainability at Santander in 2024", p. 75), impacto en localidades y países (p. 75), relaciones con comunidades locales (p. 22), y acciones de asociación o patrocinio (ej. AEB en España). Correspondencias: MDR-A, MDR-T, MDR-M, S3-4, S3-5, S3-2. 2. **Subcontratación y proveedores**: Inclusión de temas sociales, igualdad de género y medio ambiente en la política de compras, relaciones con proveedores y subcontratistas, y sistemas de supervisión y auditoría (capítulo "Business conduct", p. 100). Correspondencias: MDR-P, MDR-A, MDR-M, G1-2. 3. **Consumidores**: Medidas de salud y seguridad, y sistemas de quejas y resolución (capítulo "Supporting employees, communities and customers", p. 75; capítulo "Risk, compliance and conduct management", p. 505). Correspondencias: MDR-A, MDR-M, S4-4. 4. **Información fiscal**: Beneficios obtenidos por país (informes de auditoría 2023 y 2024), impuestos pagados (p. 199), y subvenciones públicas recibidas (sin subsidios significativos en 2023 y 2024, p. 864). 5. **Taxonomía de la UE**: Información relacionada con el artículo 8 de la Taxonomía de la UE (p. 75, p. 131). Correspondencias: Regulación UE 2020/852 y regulaciones delegadas enmendadas. and

    0 1 2
    Non-financial information to be disclosed Chapter/section of the annual report Correspondence with CSRD/other regulations

  • ### Summary of the Table (2024) The table titled "Employees by employment contract" provides data for the year 2024, categorized by gender (Men, Women, Other, Not declared) and totals.   • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta los "Disclosure Requirement and related datapoint" relacionados con referencias normativas y su materialidad en el informe. Las columnas incluyen: "Disclosure Requirement and related datapoint", "SFDR (1) reference", "Pillar 3 (2) reference", "Benchmark Regulation (3) reference", "EU Climate Law (4) reference" y "Materiality of the data point and location in the report". Los años no están explícitamente mencionados en la tabla. 1. Los puntos relacionados con ESRS E4-2 (prácticas sostenibles en océanos y políticas contra la deforestación) y ESRS E5-5 (residuos no reciclados y peligrosos) se consideran "Not material". 2. Los riesgos de incidentes de trabajo forzado y trabajo infantil (ESRS 2-SBM3-S1) también son "Not material". 3. Los compromisos de políticas de derechos humanos (ESRS S1-1) están vinculados a "Sustainability at Grupo Santander (1.4.2 Human rights due diligence)". 4. Las políticas de diligencia debida sobre temas de la OIT (ESRS S1-1) se cruzan con el "Delegated Regulation (EU) 2020/1816, Annex II". 5. Los procesos para prevenir la trata de personas (ESRS S1-1) son "Not material". 6. La política de prevención de accidentes laborales (ESRS S1-1) se relaciona con "3.1 Our employees 3.1.2 Working conditions (i. Employee health and well-being)". 7. Los mecanismos de manejo de quejas (ESRS S1-3) están vinculados a "3.1 Our employees 3.1.4 Employee feedback and experience". 8. Los datos sobre accidentes laborales (ESRS S1-14) se cruzan con "Sustainability notes 7.3 Employees (Table 22. Occupational health & safety)". 9. La brecha salarial de género y la proporción de pago excesivo del CEO (ESRS S1-16) están vinculadas a "Sustainability notes 7.3 Employees (Table 16. Remuneration ratios)". and
