  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance": La tabla presenta cinco áreas clave relacionadas con la gestión de riesgos y el cumplimiento: 1. **Inclusive Culture**: Avances en la cultura inclusiva y otras iniciativas como la accesibilidad. 2. **Financial inclusion**: Progresos en los objetivos de inclusión financiera y otras iniciativas clave en la agenda social, como la educación financiera y la inversión comunitaria. 3. **Sustainable finance**: Avances en las finanzas sostenibles y la inversión socialmente responsable. 4. **Climate**: Progresos en el plan de transición y los principales mecanismos para cumplir con la ambición de alcanzar emisiones netas cero. 5. **Governance and cross cutting matters**: Realización de la evaluación de doble materialidad, implementación de políticas de sostenibilidad y mejora de la eficiencia y calidad de los datos. and

    Risk management and compliance

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1
    Inclusive Culture Progress with inclusive culture and other initiatives such as accessibility.
    Financial inclusion Progress with financial inclusion targets and other key initiatives in the social agenda (financial education, community investment, etc.).
    Sustainable finance Progress with sustainable finance and socially responsible investment.
    Climate Progress with our transition plan and the key levers to fulfil our net zero ambition.
    Governance and cross cutting matters Conducting our double materiality assessment, implementing sustainability policies, and enhancing data efficiency and quality.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento en el contexto de la estrategia, modelo de negocio y cadena de valor (SBM-1), los intereses y opiniones de las partes interesadas (SBM-2), y los impactos materiales, riesgos y oportunidades en interacción con la estrategia y el modelo de negocio (SBM-3). En SBM-1, se destacan sub-secciones como "Sustainability strategy" (p. 22), "Supporting our customers in their transition goals" (p. 35), y "Communities' sustainable development" (p. 83), entre otras. Se menciona que los ingresos de sectores relevantes representan solo el 1.46% de los ingresos totales del Grupo. En SBM-2, se incluyen sub-secciones como "Stakeholder engagement" (p. 24) y "Our employees" (p. 75), con énfasis en la evaluación de materialidad y la retroalimentación de los empleados. En SBM-3, se aborda la evaluación de materialidad (p. 27) y el impacto financiero de riesgos y oportunidades, como los activos alineados con la Taxonomía de la UE y el financiamiento verde. También se mencionan posibles pérdidas financieras derivadas de reclamaciones legales y sanciones, según las notas 25.d) y 25.e) de las cuentas anuales. Finalmente, en la sección "Disclosures on the materiality assessment process", se detalla el proceso de identificación y evaluación de impactos materiales, riesgos y oportunidades, incluyendo la metodología de evaluación de materialidad (p. 121). and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre el apoyo comunitario en tres áreas principales: 1. **Apoyo a la educación, empleo y emprendimiento**: Se detalla el monto total invertido en estas áreas, con datos disponibles en la sección 3.2.4 "Apoyo comunitario" y en SN 7.6 "Apoyo comunitario" (tabla 27). Este apoyo refleja la ambición de Santander de contribuir al progreso y crecimiento inclusivo y sostenible de las comunidades donde opera. 2. **Apoyo a otras iniciativas locales**: Incluye el monto total invertido en iniciativas locales para promover la educación infantil, el bienestar social (especialmente entre grupos vulnerables), el arte y la cultura. Los datos también están disponibles en la sección 3.2.4 "Apoyo comunitario" y en SN 7.6 "Apoyo comunitario" (tabla 27). 3. **Apoyo comunitario total**: Representa la suma de las inversiones en educación, empleabilidad y emprendimiento, junto con las inversiones en otros programas de apoyo comunitario. Los datos están disponibles en la misma sección y tabla mencionadas anteriormente. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1 2
    Support for education, employment and entrepreneurship Total amount invested to support education, employment and entrepreneurship. See data in section 3.2.4 Community support and SN 7.6 Community support (table 27. Community support) of this chapter. It reflects Santander's ambition and contribution to promoting (beyond our business operations) the progress and inclusive and sustainable growth of the communities where we are present.
    Support for other local initiatives Total amount invested through local initiatives to promote childhood education, social welfare (especially among vulnerable groups), art and culture.
    See data in section 3.2.4 Community support and SN 7.6 Community support (table 27. Community support) of this chapter.
    Total community support Sum of investment in education, employability and entrepreneurship, plus investment in other community support programmes. See data in section 3.2.4 Community support and SN 7.6 Community support (table 27. Community support)of this chapter.

L'information contextuelle sur les salariés en situation de handicap est partiellement disponible. L'entreprise mentionne qu'elle s'efforce d'inclure avec succès 4,828 employés en situation de handicap, représentant plus de 2.3 % de sa main-d'œuvre mondiale. Il est également précisé qu'il existe une obligation légale d'inclusion des personnes handicapées dans la main-d'œuvre dans au moins 7 pays avec plus de 1,000 employés. De plus, un réseau global nommé "Enable" a été formé en 2022 pour promouvoir l'inclusion, avec plus de 2,700 membres dans 10 pays. Cependant, il n'est pas clairement indiqué comment les données ont été compilées ou si toutes les informations nécessaires pour comprendre pleinement ces données sont communiquées.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento" La tabla presenta información no financiera que debe ser divulgada, organizada en tres columnas: "Información no financiera a divulgar", "Capítulo/sección del informe anual" y "Correspondencia con CSRD/otras regulaciones". Los temas abordados incluyen: 1. **Empleo**: Datos sobre el número total y distribución de empleados por género, edad, país y clasificación profesional; modalidades de contrato; despidos; remuneración promedio y su evolución; brecha salarial; políticas de desconexión laboral; y empleados con discapacidades. Referencias: SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191), 3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p.75), y regulaciones MDR-M, MDR-P y GOV-3. 2. **Organización del trabajo**: Tiempo de trabajo, horas de ausencia, medidas para el equilibrio entre vida laboral y personal. Referencias: SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191), 3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p.75), y regulaciones MDR-P, MDR-A. 3. **Salud y seguridad**: Condiciones de seguridad en el lugar de trabajo, accidentes laborales y enfermedades ocupacionales. Referencias: SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191), 3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p.75), y regulaciones MDR-A, MDR-M. 4. **Relaciones sociales**: Diálogo social, acuerdos colectivos, y mecanismos para la participación de los trabajadores en la gestión empresarial. Referencias: SN 7. Our progress in figures (p. 134), 3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p.75), 4. Business conduct (p. 100), y regulaciones MDR-A, MDR-M. 5. **Formación**: Políticas de formación y número total de horas de capacitación por categorías profesionales. Referencias: SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191), 3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p.75), y regulaciones MDR-P, MDR-M.
  • ### SN 7. Our progress in figures The table summarizes progress in risk management and compliance across various categories. **SN 7.1 Green transition** includes data on **Table 1. Green finance**, **Table 2. Environmental footprint**, **Table 3. Gross scopes 1, 2, 3 and total GHG emissions**, **Table 4. GHG mitigation projects financed through carbon credits**, and **Table 5 Equator principles**, spanning pages 135–139. **SN 7.2 EU taxonomy tables** are detailed on page 140. **SN 7.3 Employees** covers **Table 6. Employees by region**, **Table 7. Employees by gender**, **Table 8. Employees by management group and gender**, **Table 9. Employees by age bracket**, **Table 10. Employees by employment contract**, **Table 11. Collective bargaining coverage and social dialogue**, and **Table 12. Turnover by region**, spanning pages 191–193. Further employee-related data includes **Table 13. Average remuneration by management group, gender and age bracket**, **Table 14. Remuneration ratios**, **Table 15. Average remuneration of senior management**, **Table 16. Average remuneration of senior management linked to long-term objectives**, and **Table 17. Senior management composition**, on pages 194–195. Training and safety are covered in **Table 18. Training**, **Table 19. Hours of training by gender and management group**, and **Table 20. Occupational health and safety**, all on page 195.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" La tabla presenta métricas relacionadas con la gestión de riesgos y el cumplimiento, organizadas por secciones y temas específicos: 1. **S1-12 - Personas con discapacidades**: Relacionado con "3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p. 75)" y "3.1 Our employees (p. 75)", bajo el tema "3.1.3 Inclusive culture". 2. **S1-13 - Métricas de formación y desarrollo de habilidades**: Asociado con "3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p. 75)", "Sustainability notes (p. 107)", "3.1 Our employees (p. 75)", y "SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191)", bajo "3.1.1 Talent and skills development". Incluye "Table 20. Training" y "Table 21. Hours of training by gender and management group". 3. **S1-14 - Métricas de salud y seguridad**: Relacionado con "3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p. 75)", "Sustainability notes (p. 107)", "3.1 Our employees (p. 75)", y "SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191)", bajo "3.1.2 Working conditions". Incluye "Table 22. Occupational health and safety". Se menciona el uso de la fase de implementación del ESRS para información específica de no empleados (ESRS S1, S1-14, para. 89). 4. **S1-16 - Métricas de compensación (brecha salarial y compensación total)**: Asociado con "3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p. 75)", "Sustainability notes (p. 107)", "3.1 Our employees (p. 75)", y "SN 7.3 Employees (p. 191)", bajo "3.1.2 Working conditions". Incluye "Table 16. Remuneration ratios". 5. **S1-17 - Incidentes, quejas e impactos graves en derechos humanos**: Relacionado con "3. Supporting employees, communities and customers (p. 75)", "4. Business conduct (p. 75)", "3.1 Our employees (p. 75)", y "4.3 Ethical channels (p. 104)", bajo "3.1.3 Inclusive culture".
  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents data on "Collective Bargaining Coverage" and "Social Dialogue" for employees in different regions, categorized by coverage rates. 1. **Labels and Columns**: The table includes the following labels: "Collective Bargaining Coverage" and "Social Dialogue." The columns are "Coverage Rate," "Employees - EEA (European Economic Area) (for countries with >50 employees representing >10% total employees)," "Employees - Non-EEA (estimate for regions with >50 employees representing >10% total employees)," and "Workplace representation (EEA only) (for countries with >50 employees representing >10% total employees)." 2. **Coverage Rate 0-19%**: Poland is listed under "Employees - EEA," the United States under "Employees - Non-EEA," and no data is provided for "Workplace representation." 3. **Coverage Rate 20-39%**: No EEA countries are listed, Mexico is listed under "Employees - Non-EEA," and no data is provided for "Workplace representation." 4. **Coverage Rate 40-59%**: No data is provided for any column. 5. **Coverage Rate 60-79%**: No data is provided for any column. 6. **Coverage Rate 80-100%**: Portugal and Spain are listed under "Employees - EEA," Argentina, Brazil, Chile, and the United Kingdom under "Employees - Non-EEA," and Spain, Poland, and Portugal under "Workplace representation."
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información no financiera que debe divulgarse, organizada en tres columnas: "Non-financial information to be disclosed", "Chapter/section of the annual report" y "Correspondence with CSRD/other regulations". Los temas incluyen: 1. **Compromisos de la empresa con el desarrollo sostenible**: Impacto en empleo y desarrollo local (capítulo "Sustainability at Santander in 2024", p. 75), impacto en localidades y países (p. 75), relaciones con comunidades locales (p. 22), y acciones de asociación o patrocinio (ej. AEB en España). Correspondencias: MDR-A, MDR-T, MDR-M, S3-4, S3-5, S3-2. 2. **Subcontratación y proveedores**: Inclusión de temas sociales, igualdad de género y medio ambiente en la política de compras, relaciones con proveedores y subcontratistas, y sistemas de supervisión y auditoría (capítulo "Business conduct", p. 100). Correspondencias: MDR-P, MDR-A, MDR-M, G1-2. 3. **Consumidores**: Medidas de salud y seguridad, y sistemas de quejas y resolución (capítulo "Supporting employees, communities and customers", p. 75; capítulo "Risk, compliance and conduct management", p. 505). Correspondencias: MDR-A, MDR-M, S4-4. 4. **Información fiscal**: Beneficios obtenidos por país (informes de auditoría 2023 y 2024), impuestos pagados (p. 199), y subvenciones públicas recibidas (sin subsidios significativos en 2023 y 2024, p. 864). 5. **Taxonomía de la UE**: Información relacionada con el artículo 8 de la Taxonomía de la UE (p. 75, p. 131). Correspondencias: Regulación UE 2020/852 y regulaciones delegadas enmendadas.

It includes the following labels and rows: 1. **Number of employees**: 98,377 Men, 108,319 Women, 6 Other, 51 Not declared, totaling 206,753. 2. **Number of permanent employees**: 96,541 Men, 105,942 Women, 6 Other, 13 Not declared, totaling 202,502. 3. **Number of temporary employees**: 1,836 Men, 2,377 Women, 0 Other, 38 Not declared, totaling 4,251. 4. **Number of full-time employees**: 97,163 Men, 102,740 Women, 5 Other, 50 Not declared, totaling 199,958. 5. **Number of part-time employees**: 1,214 Men, 5,579 Women, 1 Other, 1 Not declared, totaling 6,795. 6. **Number of non-guaranteed hours employees**: 0 across all categories, totaling 0. The table highlights employment contract types and gender distribution for the year 2024.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta los "Disclosure Requirement and related datapoint" relacionados con referencias normativas y su materialidad en el informe. Las columnas incluyen: "Disclosure Requirement and related datapoint", "SFDR (1) reference", "Pillar 3 (2) reference", "Benchmark Regulation (3) reference", "EU Climate Law (4) reference" y "Materiality of the data point and location in the report". Los años no están explícitamente mencionados en la tabla. 1. Los puntos relacionados con ESRS E4-2 (prácticas sostenibles en océanos y políticas contra la deforestación) y ESRS E5-5 (residuos no reciclados y peligrosos) se consideran "Not material". 2. Los riesgos de incidentes de trabajo forzado y trabajo infantil (ESRS 2-SBM3-S1) también son "Not material". 3. Los compromisos de políticas de derechos humanos (ESRS S1-1) están vinculados a "Sustainability at Grupo Santander (1.4.2 Human rights due diligence)". 4. Las políticas de diligencia debida sobre temas de la OIT (ESRS S1-1) se cruzan con el "Delegated Regulation (EU) 2020/1816, Annex II". 5. Los procesos para prevenir la trata de personas (ESRS S1-1) son "Not material". 6. La política de prevención de accidentes laborales (ESRS S1-1) se relaciona con "3.1 Our employees 3.1.2 Working conditions (i. Employee health and well-being)". 7. Los mecanismos de manejo de quejas (ESRS S1-3) están vinculados a "3.1 Our employees 3.1.4 Employee feedback and experience". 8. Los datos sobre accidentes laborales (ESRS S1-14) se cruzan con "Sustainability notes 7.3 Employees (Table 22. Occupational health & safety)". 9. La brecha salarial de género y la proporción de pago excesivo del CEO (ESRS S1-16) están vinculadas a "Sustainability notes 7.3 Employees (Table 16. Remuneration ratios)".

Las columnas incluyen: "SFDR (1) reference", "Pillar 3 (2) reference", "Benchmark Regulation (3) reference", "EU Climate Law (4) reference" y "Materiality of the data point and location in the report". Business conduct 4.2 Ethical conduct". 2. **ESRS S1-17 Non-respect of UNGPs on Business and Human Rights and OECD** (párrafo 104 (a)) tiene referencias en "Indicator number 10 Table #1" y "Indicator n. 14 Table #3 of Annex I", además de regulaciones delegadas de la UE de 2020. 3. **ESRS 2-SBM3-S2 Significant risk of child labour or forced labour** (párrafo 11 (b)) no es material. 4. **ESRS S2-1 Human rights policy commitments** (párrafo 17) y **ESRS S2-1 Policies related to value chain workers** (párrafo 18) no son materiales. 5. **ESRS S2-1 Due diligence policies** (párrafo 19) y **ESRS S2-4 Human rights issues and incidents** (párrafo 36) tampoco son materiales. 6. **ESRS S3-1 Human rights policy commitments** (párrafo 16) y **ESRS S3-4 Human rights issues and incidents** (párrafo 36) no son materiales. 7. **ESRS S4-1 Policies related to consumers and end-users** (párrafo 16) está vinculado a "3.3 Our customers". 8. **ESRS S4-1 Non-respect of UNGPs on Business and Human Rights and OECD guidelines** (párrafo 17) se relaciona con "3.3 Our customers" y "1. Sustainability at Santander (1.4.2 Human rights due diligence)".

Los encabezados de las columnas son: "Nuclear energy related activities", "CCM+CCA", "CCM", y "CCA", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". En la fila 2, las actividades de la sección 4.27 tienen un monto de 1 y una proporción de 0.0% en CCM+CCA y CCM, mientras que en CCA es 0 y 0.0%. 3. En la fila 6, las actividades de la sección 4.31 tienen un monto de 0 y una proporción de 0.0% en todas las categorías. 7. En la fila 7, las actividades elegibles no referidas en las filas anteriores tienen un monto de 403,901 y una proporción de 30.9% en CCM+CCA y CCM, mientras que en CCA es 324 y 0.0%. 8.   • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance": La tabla presenta cinco áreas clave relacionadas con la gestión de riesgos y el cumplimiento: 1. **Inclusive Culture**: Avances en la cultura inclusiva y otras iniciativas como la accesibilidad. 2. **Financial inclusion**: Progresos en los objetivos de inclusión financiera y otras iniciativas clave en la agenda social, como la educación financiera y la inversión comunitaria. 3. **Sustainable finance**: Avances en las finanzas sostenibles y la inversión socialmente responsable. 4. **Climate**: Progresos en el plan de transición y los principales mecanismos para cumplir con la ambición de alcanzar emisiones netas cero. 5. **Governance and cross cutting matters**: Realización de la evaluación de doble materialidad, implementación de políticas de sostenibilidad y mejora de la eficiencia y calidad de los datos.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento en el contexto de la estrategia, modelo de negocio y cadena de valor (SBM-1), los intereses y opiniones de las partes interesadas (SBM-2), y los impactos materiales, riesgos y oportunidades en interacción con la estrategia y el modelo de negocio (SBM-3). En SBM-1, se destacan sub-secciones como "Sustainability strategy" (p. 22), "Supporting our customers in their transition goals" (p. 35), y "Communities' sustainable development" (p. 83), entre otras. Se menciona que los ingresos de sectores relevantes representan solo el 1.46% de los ingresos totales del Grupo. En SBM-2, se incluyen sub-secciones como "Stakeholder engagement" (p. 24) y "Our employees" (p. 75), con énfasis en la evaluación de materialidad y la retroalimentación de los empleados. En SBM-3, se aborda la evaluación de materialidad (p. 27) y el impacto financiero de riesgos y oportunidades, como los activos alineados con la Taxonomía de la UE y el financiamiento verde. También se mencionan posibles pérdidas financieras derivadas de reclamaciones legales y sanciones, según las notas 25.d) y 25.e) de las cuentas anuales. Finalmente, en la sección "Disclosures on the materiality assessment process", se detalla el proceso de identificación y evaluación de impactos materiales, riesgos y oportunidades, incluyendo la metodología de evaluación de materialidad (p. 121).
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre el apoyo comunitario en tres áreas principales: 1. **Apoyo a la educación, empleo y emprendimiento**: Se detalla el monto total invertido en estas áreas, con datos disponibles en la sección 3.2.4 "Apoyo comunitario" y en SN 7.6 "Apoyo comunitario" (tabla 27). Este apoyo refleja la ambición de Santander de contribuir al progreso y crecimiento inclusivo y sostenible de las comunidades donde opera. 2. **Apoyo a otras iniciativas locales**: Incluye el monto total invertido en iniciativas locales para promover la educación infantil, el bienestar social (especialmente entre grupos vulnerables), el arte y la cultura. Los datos también están disponibles en la sección 3.2.4 "Apoyo comunitario" y en SN 7.6 "Apoyo comunitario" (tabla 27). 3. **Apoyo comunitario total**: Representa la suma de las inversiones en educación, empleabilidad y emprendimiento, junto con las inversiones en otros programas de apoyo comunitario. Los datos están disponibles en la misma sección y tabla mencionadas anteriormente.

Je ne sais pas si l'entreprise communique toutes les informations contextuelles nécessaires pour comprendre les données relatives aux salariés en situation de handicap et la manière dont elles ont été compilées.

  • adjustments to compensation. We also measure at a global level the gender pay gap (GPG), which compares the median pay of women and men. In 2024, our GPG was 26% (improving 2.1 p.p. and 4.5 p.p. vs 2023 and 2022)54 . Persons with disabilities We strive for the successful inclusion of our 4,828 employees with disabilities (over 2.3% of our global workforce55). There is a legal requirement regarding the inclusion of persons with disabilities in the workforce at least in 7 of countries with more than 1,000 employees. We have employee networks in several units that aim to include persons with disabilities. Our global Enable network, formed in 2022, has over 2,700 members in 10 countries. In 2024, to promote this network, we boosted awareness and inclusion in the Group through events on visibility, technology, accessibility, and women. Our event to mark international day of persons with disabilities, which we hold every year, included a talk with paralympic adjustments to compensation. We also measure at a global level the gender pay gap (GPG), which compares the median pay of women and men. In 2024, our GPG was 26% (improving 2.1 p.p. and 4.5 p.p. vs 2023 and 2022)54 . Persons with disabilities We strive for the successful inclusion of our 4,828 employees with disabilities (over 2.3% of our global workforce55). There is a legal requirement regarding the inclusion of persons with disabilities in the workforce at least in 7 of countries with more than 1,000 employees. We have employee networks in several units that aim to include persons with disabilities. Our global Enable network, formed in 2022, has over 2,700 members in 10 countries. In 2024, to promote this network, we boosted awareness and inclusion in the Group through events on visibility, technology, accessibility, and women. Our event to mark international day of persons with disabilities, which we hold every year, included a talk with paralympic

  • Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A. As in the rest of this chapter, we only include information about our employees. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. Reported globally since 2023, following local laws for occupational illnesses where they are regulated country-wide or for specific jobs, as soon as a medical examination confirms the cause as occupational. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional Accident rateF 0.03 0.06 0.05 0.02 0.04 0.03 Severity rateG0.05 0.08 0.06 0.03 0.06 0.04 A. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market. Banco Santander only considers occupational accidents and illnesses that, following expert review, are recognized as work-related and reported to official bodies (e.g. in Brazil, through a comunicação de acidente de trabalho — CAT, or work-related accident notice — to the Instituto Nacional
  • To assess how we’re doing on cybersecurity within the industry, we monitor our security rating provided by an independent third party. Bitsight Company gives us with a score between 250 and 900 (with 740-900 considered “Advanced”) based on public information and externally visible network traffic and systems. In 2024, we scored 790 points, which put us in the upper quartile among our peers and meant that we hit our target. Annual report 2024 98 Contents Business model Sustainability Corporate Economic and Risk management and strategy statement governance financial review and compliance Protecting our customers’ and employees’ information is the responsibility of every Santander employee. We outline this in another policy under our cybersecurity framework: Cybersecurity standards for the protection of Santander, which sets out the principles that we must follow. Our model estimates the direct and indirect impact of macroeconomic and climate variables, market trends and regulatory expectations. This model takes a bottom-up approach by considering each client's financial situation and technology. Where we don’t have specific customer information, we use a top-down approach by sector and geographical location. The development of internal models allows us a high degree of Power (Renewables) Transport Auto Consumer AgricultureManufacturing Water & Waste Construction Real Estate Risk level: ¢Very high ¢High ¢Medium ¢Moderately low ¢Low Contents Business model Sustainability Corporate Economic and Risk management and strategy statement governance financial review and compliance 3.Internal climate models Detailed below is an overview of our internal climate model: Our climate internal models enable us to quantify the financial impact4 of transition and physical risks that we monitor through changes in PD and LGD metrics. S1-172

Quel est l'écart de rémunération entre les femmes et les hommes au sein de l'entreprise, en tenant compte des données pour l'année de référence ainsi que pour les deux années antérieures, si ces informations ont déjà été publiées dans le passé ?

nan

L'écart de rémunération entre les femmes et les hommes au sein de l'entreprise, mesuré par le Gender Pay Gap (GPG), était de 26% en 2024. Cet écart représente une amélioration de 2,1 points de pourcentage par rapport à 2023 et de 4,5 points de pourcentage par rapport à 2022 (Context Num-1).


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • We also measure at a global level the gender pay gap (GPG), which compares the median pay of women and men. In 2024, our GPG was 26% (improving 2.1 p.p. and 4.5 p.p. vs 2023 and 2022)54. We also measure at a global level the gender pay gap (GPG), which compares the median pay of women and men. In 2024, our GPG was 26% (improving 2.1 p.p. and 4.5 p.p. vs 2023 and 2022)54.

  • ### END TABLE A. It includes gross annual salary and comparable supplements, pension schemes and variable remuneration. 99% of Santander employees receive other salaries that supplement their salary. B. The categories requested by CSRD, by gender and age groups have been used. Groups with less than 50 employees (others, not declared) are not included because they are not statistically relevant and to avoid statistically erroneous conclusions. C. The average pay of our constant workforce (i.e. employees who were with us at 2023 year end and remained at 2024 year end) grew 11.4% in 2024 in constant euros (this does not include Argentina due to exchange rate distortions between the two periods). If we consider the current exchange rates (including Argentina) and the new hired employees, the average remuneration has had a net increase of 3.1% in comparison with the average for our workforce in 2023 (EUR 51,535). ### END TABLE A. It includes gross annual salary and comparable supplements, pension schemes and variable remuneration. 99% of Santander employees receive other salaries that supplement their salary. B. Groups with less than 50 employees (others, not declared) are not included because they are not statistically relevant and to avoid statistically erroneous conclusions. C. If we consider the current exchange rates (including Argentina) and the new hired employees, the average remuneration has had a net increase of 3.1% in comparison with the average for our workforce in 2023 (EUR 51,535).

  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento, organizada en las siguientes etiquetas: **ESRS**, **IRO description**, **IRO type**, **Value chain**, **Summary of current/potential effects (narrative)**, **People/environment**, **Strategy- and business model-related impacts**, **Time horizon 1**, **Linked to impact due to own operations or business relations 2**, **Systemic/specific**, **Core activities that lead to positive impacts**, **Risks and/or opportunities stemming from impacts**, y **More details**. 1. **S3 - Affected communities**: Se identifican impactos negativos en la cadena de valor "Downstream" y en las "Own operations" debido a actividades financieras que incumplen políticas del banco o por insuficiente involucramiento de stakeholders. Los efectos potenciales incluyen daño al bienestar de las personas y al medio ambiente. Se relaciona con el desarrollo económico, social y financiero de las comunidades, con enfoque en educación, empleabilidad y emprendimiento, en un horizonte de corto/medio plazo. Más detalles en "3.2 Supporting our communities' sustainable development - 3.2.3 Environmental, social and climate change management". 2. **G1 - Business conduct**: Se destacan impactos positivos en las "Own operations" relacionados con la toma de decisiones responsables que consideran intereses de stakeholders, confidencialidad en canales éticos, y promoción de prácticas responsables entre proveedores. Los efectos incluyen mecanismos de reporte confidenciales, evaluación de desempeño ESG de proveedores, y promoción de prácticas responsables en la cadena de valor. Se relaciona con actuar responsablemente mediante una cultura, gobernanza y conducta sólida, en un horizonte de corto/medio plazo. Más detalles en "4.2 Ethical behaviour", "4.3 Ethical channels", y "4.4 Our suppliers". and

    Risk management and compliance

  • La tabla titulada "Assets for the calculation of GAR (Capex) - 2024" presenta datos en millones de euros sobre los activos cubiertos para el cálculo del GAR (Green Asset Ratio) en el año 2024. Los activos están clasificados en las siguientes categorías: "Loans and advances, debt securities and equity instruments not HFT eligible for GAR calculation", "Financial undertakings", "Credit institutions", "Other financial corporations", "Non-financial undertakings", y "Households". Las columnas incluyen: "Total [gross] carrying amount", "Climate Change Mitigation (CCM)", "Climate Change Adaptation (CCA)", "TOTAL (CCM + CCA)", y subdivisiones como "Of which towards taxonomy relevant sectors (Taxonomy-eligible)", "Of which environmentally sustainable (Taxonomy-aligned)", "Of which Use of Proceeds", "Of which transitional", y "Of which enabling". En la categoría "Households", los préstamos garantizados por bienes inmuebles residenciales alcanzan 331,277 millones de euros, mientras que los préstamos para renovación de edificios suman 1,189 millones de euros y los préstamos para vehículos ascienden a 96,477 millones de euros. En "Non-financial undertakings", el total bruto es de 28,232 millones de euros, con 11,539 millones destinados a CCM y 4,248 millones a CCA. En "Financial undertakings", el total bruto es de 25,544 millones de euros, con 5,704 millones destinados a CCM y 1,600 millones a CCA. Los instrumentos de capital en todas las categorías tienen valores bajos o nulos, destacando que en "Equity instruments" el total bruto es de 0 millones de euros en varias subcategorías. Los valores de "Debt securities, including UoP" varían entre las categorías, siendo más altos en "Households" y "Non-financial undertakings". La tabla detalla también los activos que son elegibles y alineados con la taxonomía, así como aquellos clasificados como "transitional" y "enabling". and

L'écart de rémunération entre les femmes et les hommes au sein de l'entreprise pour l'année 2024 est de 26%, ce qui représente une amélioration de 2,1 points de pourcentage par rapport à 2023 et de 4,5 points de pourcentage par rapport à 2022.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • We also measure at a global level the gender pay gap (GPG), which compares the median pay of women and men. In 2024, our GPG was 26% (improving 2.1 p.p. and 4.5 p.p. vs 2023 and 2022)54.
  • ### Summary of the Table The table presents the "Average remuneration of senior management (with variable remuneration not linked to long-term objectives)" in "Thousand euros" for the years "2024" and "2023." It includes data for "Men," "Women," and "Total" across three categories: "Executive directors," "Non-executive directors," and "Senior management." - For "Executive directors," the remuneration in 2024 was "9,137" for men, "12,127" for women, and "10,632" in total, compared to "8,257" for men, "11,544" for women, and "9,900" in total in 2023. - For "Non-executive directors," the remuneration in 2024 was "285" for men, "356" for women, and "309" in total, compared to "368" for men, "327" for women, and "352" in total in 2023. - For "Senior management," the remuneration in 2024 was "3,898" for men, "1,380" for women, and "3,538" in total, compared to "4,112" for men, "1,645" for women, and "3,583" in total in 2023.

It includes three main categories: **Gender**, **Management group**, and **Age bracket**, with corresponding subcategories and average remuneration values. 1. **Gender**: The average remuneration for **Women** is 41,822, for **Men** is 65,625, and the **Total** is 53,131. Categories **Other B** and **Not declared** are not included. 2. **Management group**: The average remuneration for **Senior executives** is 524,748, for **Other executives** is 129,847, for **Other employees** is 36,834, and the **Total** is 53,131. 3. **Age bracket**: The average remuneration for employees aged **<30** is 23,329, for those aged **30-50** is 53,353, for those aged **>50** is 88,044, and the **Total** is 53,131. The table uses categories requested by CSRD and excludes groups with fewer than 50 employees for statistical relevance.

  • ### END TABLE A. It includes gross annual salary and comparable supplements, pension schemes and variable remuneration. 99% of Santander employees receive other salaries that supplement their salary. B. The categories requested by CSRD, by gender and age groups have been used. Groups with less than 50 employees (others, not declared) are not included because they are not statistically relevant and to avoid statistically erroneous conclusions. C. The average pay of our constant workforce (i.e. employees who were with us at 2023 year end and remained at 2024 year end) grew 11.4% in 2024 in constant euros (this does not include Argentina due to exchange rate distortions between the two periods). If we consider the current exchange rates (including Argentina) and the new hired employees, the average remuneration has had a net increase of 3.1% in comparison with the average for our workforce in 2023 (EUR 51,535).
  • ### 14. Remuneration ratios The table presents remuneration ratios for the year 2024. It includes the following metrics: - **Hourly GPG ratio (average)**: 36%. - **GPG ratio (median)**: 26%, which accounts for annual base salary and variable remuneration paid in the year. - **EPG ratio**: Approximately 0. - **Remuneration ratio**: 367.1, calculated as the annual remuneration of the highest-paid individual divided by the median employee annual remuneration (excluding the highest-paid).
  • variable compensation (ranging from 40% to 60%, depending on their level of responsibility) for a period of four to seven years. This variable compensation is paid out 50% in shares and 50% in cash, and is subject to a possible reduction (malus) or recovery (clawback). For more information on adequate salaries, total remuneration ratio, see SN 7.3 'Employees'.

  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta información sobre la gestión de riesgos y cumplimiento, organizada en las siguientes etiquetas: **ESRS**, **IRO description**, **IRO type**, **Value chain**, **Summary of current/potential effects (narrative)**, **People/environment**, **Strategy- and business model-related impacts**, **Time horizon 1**, **Linked to impact due to own operations or business relations 2**, **Systemic/specific**, **Core activities that lead to positive impacts**, **Risks and/or opportunities stemming from impacts**, y **More details**. 1. **S3 - Affected communities**: Se identifican impactos negativos en la cadena de valor "Downstream" y en las "Own operations" debido a actividades financieras que incumplen políticas del banco o por insuficiente involucramiento de stakeholders. Los efectos potenciales incluyen daño al bienestar de las personas y al medio ambiente. Se relaciona con el desarrollo económico, social y financiero de las comunidades, con enfoque en educación, empleabilidad y emprendimiento, en un horizonte de corto/medio plazo. Más detalles en "3.2 Supporting our communities' sustainable development - 3.2.3 Environmental, social and climate change management". 2. **G1 - Business conduct**: Se destacan impactos positivos en las "Own operations" relacionados con la toma de decisiones responsables que consideran intereses de stakeholders, confidencialidad en canales éticos, y promoción de prácticas responsables entre proveedores. Los efectos incluyen mecanismos de reporte confidenciales, evaluación de desempeño ESG de proveedores, y promoción de prácticas responsables en la cadena de valor. Se relaciona con actuar responsablemente mediante una cultura, gobernanza y conducta sólida, en un horizonte de corto/medio plazo. Más detalles en "4.2 Ethical behaviour", "4.3 Ethical channels", y "4.4 Our suppliers".
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos sobre el promedio de empleados en 2024, desglosados por tipo de contrato y rango de edad. Las etiquetas de las columnas son: "Under 30", "30-50", "Over 50" y "Total". Las filas incluyen: 1. **Average employees**: 46,556 empleados menores de 30 años, 129,728 entre 30-50 años, 32,828 mayores de 50 años, totalizando 209,112. 2. **Average permanent employees**: 44,748 menores de 30 años, 127,682 entre 30-50 años, 32,531 mayores de 50 años, totalizando 204,960. 3. **Average temporary employees**: 1,808 menores de 30 años, 2,046 entre 30-50 años, 297 mayores de 50 años, totalizando 4,151. 4. **Average full-time employees**: 45,412 menores de 30 años, 125,537 entre 30-50 años, 30,999 mayores de 50 años, totalizando 201,949. 5. **Average part-time employees**: 1,143 menores de 30 años, 4,191 entre 30-50 años, 1,829 mayores de 50 años, totalizando 7,163. Los datos reflejan el desglose de empleados según la Ley 11/2018.
  • La tabla titulada "Assets for the calculation of GAR (Capex) - 2024" presenta datos en millones de euros sobre los activos cubiertos para el cálculo del GAR (Green Asset Ratio) en el año 2024. Los activos están clasificados en las siguientes categorías: "Loans and advances, debt securities and equity instruments not HFT eligible for GAR calculation", "Financial undertakings", "Credit institutions", "Other financial corporations", "Non-financial undertakings", y "Households". Las columnas incluyen: "Total [gross] carrying amount", "Climate Change Mitigation (CCM)", "Climate Change Adaptation (CCA)", "TOTAL (CCM + CCA)", y subdivisiones como "Of which towards taxonomy relevant sectors (Taxonomy-eligible)", "Of which environmentally sustainable (Taxonomy-aligned)", "Of which Use of Proceeds", "Of which transitional", y "Of which enabling". En la categoría "Households", los préstamos garantizados por bienes inmuebles residenciales alcanzan 331,277 millones de euros, mientras que los préstamos para renovación de edificios suman 1,189 millones de euros y los préstamos para vehículos ascienden a 96,477 millones de euros. En "Non-financial undertakings", el total bruto es de 28,232 millones de euros, con 11,539 millones destinados a CCM y 4,248 millones a CCA. En "Financial undertakings", el total bruto es de 25,544 millones de euros, con 5,704 millones destinados a CCM y 1,600 millones a CCA. Los instrumentos de capital en todas las categorías tienen valores bajos o nulos, destacando que en "Equity instruments" el total bruto es de 0 millones de euros en varias subcategorías. Los valores de "Debt securities, including UoP" varían entre las categorías, siendo más altos en "Households" y "Non-financial undertakings". La tabla detalla también los activos que son elegibles y alineados con la taxonomía, así como aquellos clasificados como "transitional" y "enabling".

L'écart de rémunération entre les femmes et les hommes au sein de l'entreprise, mesuré par le Gender Pay Gap (GPG), était de 26% en 2024. Cet écart représente une amélioration de 2,1 points de pourcentage par rapport à 2023 et de 4,5 points de pourcentage par rapport à 2022 (Context Num-1).

  • impact40 on Santander's results. Therefore, the majority of them are subject to a policy of deferral of a significant portion of theirvariable compensation (ranging from 40% to 60%, depending on their level of responsibility) for a period of four to seven years. This variable compensation is paid out 50% in shares and 50% in cash, and is subject to a possible reduction (malus) or recovery (clawback). For more information on adequate salaries, total remuneration ratio, see SN 7.3 'Employees'. Equal pay Our remuneration practices promote a non-discriminatory salary management in terms of gender and equivalent remuneration, especially in those cases where employees perform the same or similar work (equally remunerated for equal work or work of equal value). Our salary comparison between women and men who perform similar functions remains at c. 0, which confirms our positive performance in recent years and meets the ambition we set for impact40 on Santander's results.   • adjustments to compensation. We also measure at a global level the gender pay gap (GPG), which compares the median pay of women and men. In 2024, our GPG was 26% (improving 2.1 p.p. and 4.5 p.p. vs 2023 and 2022)54 . Persons with disabilities We strive for the successful inclusion of our 4,828 employees with disabilities (over 2.3% of our global workforce55). There is a legal requirement regarding the inclusion of persons with disabilities in the workforce at least in 7 of countries with more than 1,000 employees. We have employee networks in several units that aim to include persons with disabilities. Our global Enable network, formed in 2022, has over 2,700 members in 10 countries. In 2024, to promote this network, we boosted awareness and inclusion in the Group through events on visibility, technology, accessibility, and women. Our event to mark international day of persons with disabilities, which we hold every year, included a talk with paralympic adjustments to compensation. We also measure at a global level the gender pay gap (GPG), which compares the median pay of women and men. In 2024, our GPG was 26% (improving 2.1 p.p. and 4.5 p.p. vs 2023 and 2022)54 . Persons with disabilities We strive for the successful inclusion of our 4,828 employees with disabilities (over 2.3% of our global workforce55). There is a legal requirement regarding the inclusion of persons with disabilities in the workforce at least in 7 of countries with more than 1,000 employees. We have employee networks in several units that aim to include persons with disabilities. Our global Enable network, formed in 2022, has over 2,700 members in 10 countries. In 2024, to promote this network, we boosted awareness and inclusion in the Group through events on visibility, technology, accessibility, and women. Our event to mark international day of persons with disabilities, which we hold every year, included a talk with paralympic
  • companies. Information from People & Culture global platform used harmonized people processes groupwide. B. The total number of terminated employees was 0.9% lower than in 2023, the turnover rate remained stable compared to the previous year, with variations of -1 percentage point in South America and North America and +2 points in Europe. 53.9% of those laid off are women, in line with the distribution of our workforce. C. Turnover rate is calculated over average headcount of the period. In accident ratios, Santander Bank Polska s.a. is not included. B. C. We report occupational injuries that can be documented in 2024, including accidents while commuting. We standardized criteria, processes and systems across our footprint to calculate leave on medical grounds in every market.   • sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable. sustainability reporting. →Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) . The TCFD, which we support since 2017, has developed a framework to help public companies and other organizations more effectively disclose climate-related risks and opportunities through their existing reporting processes. Linked to Advocacy Forums →Instituto Internacional de Finanzas (IIF) : Grupo Santander's Executive Chair is the current IIF Chair and has sat on its board since 2014. The bank participates in several sustainability-related working groups, including the Sustainable Finance Policy Expert Group and the Sustainable Finance Data, Disclosure and Classification Expert Group. →European Banking Federation (EBF) : Santander is a member of several working groups, such as the ESG risk group, which a Santander director chairs; the Sustainable Finance Steering Committee; and the Chief Sustainability Officers Roundtable.
  • shares are meant to help the foundation financially; it can use the dividends to cover some (if not all) of the cost of fulfilling its founding purposes.66 These include managing the bank's art collection and financing numerous literary, educational, social, cultural and environmental productions and activities, in which the remodelling of the Santander's headquarters on Paseo de Pereda in Santander and our relations with universities in Spain will play an important role. For more details, visit the website fundacionbancosantander.com/es/ fundacion/transparencia. We have other Santander foundations in countries where we operate (Argentina, the US, Mexico, Portugal, Poland and the UK), which boost the number of initiatives we run. Their focus varies according to local needs; for instance, in Argentina on art and culture; in Portugal on education, inclusion and culture; and in Poland on education for children and young people. XX

Quel est le ratio de rémunération totale annuelle au sein de l'entreprise ? Quel est le montant total de la rémunération annuelle pour les employés (y compris les salaires, les primes, les avantages et autres compensations)



Pour répondre à cette question, merci de fournir :

Le montant total de la rémunération annuelle pour les employés (y compris les salaires, les primes, les avantages et autres compensations).
Des détails sur la méthodologie utilisée pour calculer ce ratio, y compris les critères pris en compte.
Si disponible, des informations sur l'évolution de ce ratio au fil des années, ainsi que des comparaisons avec des normes sectorielles ou des benchmarks.

Le ratio de rémunération totale annuelle au sein de l'entreprise est de 367.1 pour l'année 2024. Ce ratio est calculé en divisant la rémunération annuelle de l'individu le mieux payé par la rémunération annuelle médiane des employés (en excluant le mieux payé). La rémunération totale annuelle pour les employés, y compris les salaires, les primes, les avantages et autres compensations, s'élève à 14,3 milliards d'euros pour l'année 2024.

La méthodologie utilisée pour calculer ce ratio inclut la rémunération fixe et variable. Les critères pris en compte sont le salaire de base annuel ainsi que la rémunération variable versée sur l'année. La rémunération variable est distribuée à 50% en actions et 50% en espèces, et peut être sujette à une réduction ou un recouvrement.

Il n'y a pas d'informations spécifiques disponibles sur l'évolution de ce ratio au fil des années dans les documents fournis, ni de comparaisons avec des normes sectorielles ou des benchmarks.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • variable compensation (ranging from 40% to 60%, depending on their level of responsibility) for a period of four to seven years. This variable compensation is paid out 50% in shares and 50% in cash, and is subject to a possible reduction (malus) or recovery (clawback). For more information on adequate salaries, total remuneration ratio, see SN 7.3 'Employees'. variable compensation (ranging from 40% to 60%, depending on their level of responsibility) for a period of four to seven years. This variable compensation is paid out 50% in shares and 50% in cash, and is subject to a possible reduction (malus) or recovery (clawback). For more information on adequate salaries, total remuneration ratio, see SN 7.3 'Employees'.
  • ### 14. Remuneration ratios The table presents remuneration ratios for the year 2024. It includes the following metrics: - **Hourly GPG ratio (average)**: 36%. - **GPG ratio (median)**: 26%, which accounts for annual base salary and variable remuneration paid in the year. - **EPG ratio**: Approximately 0. - **Remuneration ratio**: 367.1, calculated as the annual remuneration of the highest-paid individual divided by the median employee annual remuneration (excluding the highest-paid). and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1
    2024
    Hourly GPG ratio (average) 36%
    GPG ratio (median)A 26%

    Remuneration ratio 367.1
  • ### END TABLE A. GPG Ratio (median) includes annual base salary and variable remuneration paid in the year. B. Ratio of the annual remuneration of the highest-paid individual for the performance of executive duties (salary, pension contributions, variable remuneration); divided over Median employee annual remunerations (excluding the highest-paid). This figure is impacted by our business model, with a large presence in three geographical regions (Europe, North and South America) and a large network of branches (c.8,000), since more than half of our employees are based in Mexico and South America (mainly in Brazil) where remuneration is aligned to the local cost of living, much lower than that of other countries that are the reference for establishing the remuneration of executive directors. In addition, the use of the median overstates this effect versus the mean: with average data the result of the ratio would be 239.7. ### END TABLE A. GPG Ratio (median) includes annual base salary and variable remuneration paid in the year. B. Ratio of the annual remuneration of the highest-paid individual for the performance of executive duties (salary, pension contributions, variable remuneration); divided over Median employee annual remunerations (excluding the highest-paid). This figure is impacted by our business model, with a large presence in three geographical regions (Europe, North and South America) and a large network of branches (c.8,000), since more than half of our employees are based in Mexico and South America (mainly in Brazil) where remuneration is aligned to the local cost of living, much lower than that of other countries that are the reference for establishing the remuneration of executive directors. In addition, the use of the median overstates this effect versus the mean: with average data the result of the ratio would be 239.7.
  • ### Equal pay Our remuneration practices promote a non-discriminatory salary management in terms of gender and equivalent remuneration, especially in those cases where employees perform the same or similar work (equally remunerated for equal work or work of equal value). Our salary comparison between women and men who perform similar functions remains at c. 0, which confirms our positive performance in recent years and meets the ambition we set for 202541. In certain jurisdictions we continue to periodically assess compensation levels for pay equity and where appropriate make adjustments to compensation. We often consult our employees to gauge how appropriate and acceptable our remuneration policies are and they recently deemed our remuneration policies competitive. For more information about the employee consultation process, refer to section 3.1.4. 'Our listening strategy'. ### Equal pay Our remuneration practices promote a non-discriminatory salary management in terms of gender and equivalent remuneration, especially in those cases where employees perform the same or similar work (equally remunerated for equal work or work of equal value). Our salary comparison between women and men who perform similar functions remains at c. 0, which confirms our positive performance in recent years and meets the ambition we set for 202541. In certain jurisdictions we continue to periodically assess compensation levels for pay equity and where appropriate make adjustments to compensation. We often consult our employees to gauge how appropriate and acceptable our remuneration policies are and they recently deemed our remuneration policies competitive. For more information about the employee consultation process, refer to section 3.1.4. 'Our listening strategy'.
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table titled "13. Average remuneration by management group, gender, and age bracketª" presents data for the year 2024. It includes three main categories: **Gender**, **Management group**, and **Age bracket**, with corresponding subcategories and average remuneration values. 1. **Gender**: The average remuneration for **Women** is 41,822, for **Men** is 65,625, and the **Total** is 53,131. Categories **Other B** and **Not declared** are not included. 2. **Management group**: The average remuneration for **Senior executives** is 524,748, for **Other executives** is 129,847, for **Other employees** is 36,834, and the **Total** is 53,131. 3. **Age bracket**: The average remuneration for employees aged **<30** is 23,329, for those aged **30-50** is 53,353, for those aged **>50** is 88,044, and the **Total** is 53,131. It includes gross annual salary and comparable supplements, pension schemes and variable remuneration. 99% of Santander employees receive other salaries that supplement their salary. B. The categories requested by CSRD, by gender and age groups have been used. Groups with less than 50 employees (others, not declared) are not included because they are not statistically relevant and to avoid statistically erroneous conclusions. C. The average pay of our constant workforce (i.e. employees who were with us at 2023 year end and remained at 2024 year end) grew 11.4% in 2024 in constant euros (this does not include Argentina due to exchange rate distortions between the two periods). If we consider the current exchange rates (including Argentina) and the new hired employees, the average remuneration has had a net increase of 3.1% in comparison with the average for our workforce in 2023 (EUR 51,535). ### END TABLE A. The average pay of our constant workforce (i.e. employees who were with us at 2023 year end and remained at 2024 year end) grew 11.4% in 2024 in constant euros (this does not include Argentina due to exchange rate distortions between the two periods). If we consider the current exchange rates (including Argentina) and the new hired employees, the average remuneration has had a net increase of 3.1% in comparison with the average for our workforce in 2023 (EUR 51,535).
  • All our businesses and subsidiaries have short-term variable remuneration schemes to reflect what we have accomplished and how, according to Group-wide quantitative and qualitative goals as well as individual and team goals, behaviour, leadership, sustainability, commitment, growth and risk management. These schemes promote meritocracy, recognize individual and team contributions, and promote employee growth and well-being. Aligned with sustainability goals, the variable compensation of executive directors also weighs compliance with our sustainability and climate goals38. In 2024, we paid EUR 14.3 billion in employee wages and benefits39. To comply with EU regulations on remuneration and manage risk correctly, we identified 1.246 employees subject to a deferred variable pay scheme because their decisions can have a material impact" on Santander's results. Therefore, the majority of them are subject to a policy of deferral of a significant portion of their All our businesses and subsidiaries have short-term variable remuneration schemes to reflect what we have accomplished and how, according to Group-wide quantitative and qualitative goals as well as individual and team goals, behaviour, leadership, sustainability, commitment, growth and risk management. Las etiquetas de las columnas son: "Número de accidentes ocupacionales fatales o enfermedades relacionadas con el trabajo", "Enfermedades relacionadas con el trabajo", "Número total de accidentes", "Tasa de accidentes relacionados con el trabajo (criterio CSRD, equivalente a la tasa de frecuencia de la Ley 11/2018)", "Número total de días de ausencia debido a accidentes", "Tasa de accidentes" y "Tasa de gravedad". En 2024, no hubo accidentes ocupacionales fatales ni enfermedades relacionadas con el trabajo (0 para Hombres, Mujeres y Total). Las enfermedades relacionadas con el trabajo sumaron 3 casos (1 Hombres, 2 Mujeres). El número total de accidentes fue de 950 (317 Hombres, 633 Mujeres). La tasa de accidentes relacionados con el trabajo fue de 1.64 (1.15 Hombres, 2.08 Mujeres). El total de días de ausencia por accidentes fue de 36,711 (12,617 Hombres, 24,094 Mujeres). La tasa de accidentes fue de 0.05 (0.03 Hombres, 0.06 Mujeres) y la tasa de gravedad fue de 0.06 (0.05 Hombres, 0.08 Mujeres). En 2023, tampoco hubo accidentes ocupacionales fatales ni enfermedades relacionadas con el trabajo (0 para Hombres, Mujeres y Total). Las enfermedades relacionadas con el trabajo sumaron 15 casos (3 Hombres, 12 Mujeres). El número total de accidentes fue de 399 (128 Hombres, 271 Mujeres). La tasa de accidentes relacionados con el trabajo fue de 0.74 (0.51 Hombres, 0.94 Mujeres). La tasa de accidentes fue de 0.03 (0.02 Hombres, 0.04 Mujeres) y la tasa de gravedad fue de 0.04 (0.03 Hombres, 0.06 Mujeres). and

  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla detalla las metodologías utilizadas por Banco Santander para calcular las emisiones financiadas en diferentes categorías de su portafolio, siguiendo el estándar de la Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials (PCAF). 1. **Emisiones financiadas de corporativos y proyectos**: Se calculan utilizando la fórmula "Emisiones financiadas = Factor de atribución x Emisiones". El factor de atribución se determina como "Monto pendiente / Valor total de la empresa", considerando el total de capital y deuda de la empresa. Para financiamiento de proyectos, se utiliza la producción y un factor de emisión. 2. **Auto - préstamos**: Las emisiones financiadas se calculan como "Factor de atribución x emisiones del vehículo". El factor de atribución se define como "Monto pendiente / Valor del vehículo al origen". Las emisiones del vehículo se basan en datos específicos del vehículo y la distancia anual estimada. 3. **Hipotecas y bienes raíces comerciales**: Las emisiones financiadas se calculan como "Emisiones del edificio x LTV". El factor de atribución se basa en el monto pendiente del préstamo dividido por el valor total de la propiedad al origen. 4. **Agricultura**: Las emisiones financiadas se calculan utilizando la producción, área de producción o número de animales multiplicado por un factor de emisión. Para emisiones por cambio de uso de suelo (LUC), se evalúan las pérdidas de cobertura arbórea y el stock de carbono utilizando metodologías específicas. 5. **Bonos soberanos**: Las emisiones financiadas se calculan como "Exposición al bono soberano (USD) / PIB ajustado por PPP (USD internacional) x Emisiones soberanas (tCO2e)". Las fuentes de datos incluyen informes de sostenibilidad, bases de datos como PCAF, y herramientas específicas como el GHG Protocol y MapBiomas. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    0 1
    Financed emissions from corporates and projects For the financed emissions associated with business loans, equities, investments, bonds, and projects we calculate the emissions in accordance with the methodology established by management that is based on the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials (PCAF) standard for financed emissions. The financed emissions for a corporate client portfolio are calculated using the following equation:
    Financed emissions = Attribution Factor x Emissions The following equations are used to determine the attribution factor at company level: Attribution Factor = Outstanding amount / Total Enterprise Value In the case of corporate business loans (CIB alignment targets), Banco Santander calculates the Total Value of the Company (used to obtain the emissions attribution factor) by adding the total equity and debt of the company to avoid the high volatility in market capitalization. In the case of Project Finance, the financed emissions for a Project are calculated using the production and an emission factor. We use as data sources (non-exhaustive): annual/Sustainability Reports of our customers, Asset Impact, Capital IQ, Carbon Disclosure Project, S&P Trucost, Transition Pathway Initiative, Wood Mackenzie, IBA, JATO, and PCAF database. See data in section Our transition plan in this chapter.
    Auto - lending For the auto lending portfolio for Santander Consumer Finance Europe the financed emissions are those associated with the passenger cars financed and leased (passenger cars being the methodology: most material vehicle type in the Auto portfolio). These are calculated following the PCAF Financed emissions = > Attribution Factor x vehicle emissions To determine the attribution factor of each of the loans, the following formula is used: Attribution factor = Outstanding amount / vehicle value at origination The vehicle emissions are calculated using the emissions of each specific vehicle, where available, multiplied by the annual distance estimated for each vehicle. See data in section Our transition plan in this chapter.
    Mortgages and Commercial Real Estate Mortgages and commercial real estate portfolio emissions lending on residential mortgages includes Scope 1 and 2 emissions based on actual (where available) and modelled EPC's. We define this asset class as on balance sheet loans for specific consumer purposes - namely the purchase and refinance of residential property. The following calculation approach was used to arrive at the financed emissions for each of the properties in the portfolio: Financed emissions = building emissions x LTV The attribution factor is the outstanding amount of the loan as per the reporting year for each mortgage, divided by the total property value at origination for each building. See data in section Our transition plan in this chapter.
    Agriculture Agriculture portfolio emissions for Santander Brazil from lending to farmers associated with primary production activities in Brazil (agriculture and livestock activities), financed through Retail mechanisms. Assessment includes Scope 1 and 2 emissions. In this sector, Santander's financed emissions estimation is based on GHG Protocol guidance and PCAF methodology, with adaptations to accommodate data availability in retail agriculture portfolio. Land management emissions: The general equations used to calculate financed emissions of an agricultural activity are as follows: Financed emissions = > quantity produced or area of production or number of animals x Emission factor Emission factor sources include the GHG Protocol Brazil Tool for the Agricultural Sector, the Reference Report from Brazil's IV National Inventory, among other specialized literature. Land Use Change (LUC) emissions: The total LUC emissions for the portfolio are calculated for each property: collecting shapefiles of farms associated with the operations financed in the retail portfolio, computing annual tree- cover loss areas (in hectares), for the last 20 years, for each property, and evaluate corresponding carbon stock loss using emission factors, applying the Linear Discounting Methodology, and calculating the attribution factor for emissions related to Santander. Sources (non-exhaustive): properties' Rural Environmental Registry number, MapBiomas Collection 8, Brazil's IV National Inventory Carbon Map.x See data in section Our transition plan in this chapter.
    Sovereign bonds For the sovereign bonds portfolio we calculate the financed emissions following the PCAF standard recommendations, as follows: Attributed emissions = Exposure to Sovereign Bond (USD) / PPP-adjusted GDP (international USD) x Sovereign Emissions (tCO2e) See data in section Our transition plan in this chapter.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla "Risk management and compliance" del informe anual de Santander 2024: La tabla presenta datos sobre la proporción de activos cubiertos en términos de sostenibilidad ambiental para el año 2024, expresados como porcentaje del total de activos cubiertos en el denominador. Las categorías principales incluyen "Climate Change Mitigation (CCM)", "Climate Change Adaptation (CCA)" y el total combinado ("TOTAL (CCM + CCA)"). Además, se desglosan los sectores relevantes según la taxonomía ("Taxonomy-eligible") y los activos ambientalmente sostenibles ("Taxonomy-aligned"). 1. **"Local governments financing"**: 83.4% del total de activos cubiertos, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes ni activos sostenibles. 2. **"Housing financing"**: 99.1% del total de activos cubiertos, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes ni activos sostenibles. 3. **"Other local government financing"**: 81.0% del total de activos cubiertos, sin contribuciones a sectores relevantes ni activos sostenibles. 4. **"Collateral obtained by taking possession: residential and commercial immovable properties"**: 0.0% en todas las categorías. 5. **"Total GAR assets"**: 34.0% del total de activos cubiertos, con 3.0% ambientalmente sostenibles, 2.8% destinados al uso de ingresos, 0.7% transicionales y 0.1% habilitadores. La proporción de activos totales cubiertos es del 69.8%. and

Le montant total de la rémunération annuelle pour les employés de l'entreprise, y compris les salaires, les primes, les avantages et autres compensations, est de 14,3 milliards d'euros en 2024. Ce montant inclut les salaires fixes, les rémunérations variables à court et long terme, ainsi que les avantages sociaux tels que les pensions et autres compensations fixes.

Le ratio de rémunération totale annuelle au sein de l'entreprise, tel que calculé dans le contexte fourni, est de 367,1. Ce ratio est déterminé en divisant la rémunération annuelle de l'individu le mieux payé par la rémunération médiane des employés, excluant la rémunération du plus haut dirigeant. Ce calcul prend en compte le salaire de base, les contributions aux pensions et la rémunération variable.

En ce qui concerne l'évolution de ce ratio et les comparaisons avec des normes sectorielles, l'information n'est pas spécifiquement fournie dans les documents disponibles. Vous pouvez consulter d'autres sources ou benchmarks sectoriels pour obtenir des comparaisons plus détaillées.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • variable compensation (ranging from 40% to 60%, depending on their level of responsibility) for a period of four to seven years. This variable compensation is paid out 50% in shares and 50% in cash, and is subject to a possible reduction (malus) or recovery (clawback). For more information on adequate salaries, total remuneration ratio, see SN 7.3 'Employees'.
  • ### 14. Remuneration ratios The table presents remuneration ratios for the year 2024. It includes the following metrics: - **Hourly GPG ratio (average)**: 36%. - **GPG ratio (median)**: 26%, which accounts for annual base salary and variable remuneration paid in the year. - **EPG ratio**: Approximately 0. - **Remuneration ratio**: 367.1, calculated as the annual remuneration of the highest-paid individual divided by the median employee annual remuneration (excluding the highest-paid).
  • ### END TABLE A. GPG Ratio (median) includes annual base salary and variable remuneration paid in the year. B. Ratio of the annual remuneration of the highest-paid individual for the performance of executive duties (salary, pension contributions, variable remuneration); divided over Median employee annual remunerations (excluding the highest-paid). This figure is impacted by our business model, with a large presence in three geographical regions (Europe, North and South America) and a large network of branches (c.8,000), since more than half of our employees are based in Mexico and South America (mainly in Brazil) where remuneration is aligned to the local cost of living, much lower than that of other countries that are the reference for establishing the remuneration of executive directors. In addition, the use of the median overstates this effect versus the mean: with average data the result of the ratio would be 239.7.
  • ### Equal pay Our remuneration practices promote a non-discriminatory salary management in terms of gender and equivalent remuneration, especially in those cases where employees perform the same or similar work (equally remunerated for equal work or work of equal value). Our salary comparison between women and men who perform similar functions remains at c. 0, which confirms our positive performance in recent years and meets the ambition we set for 202541. In certain jurisdictions we continue to periodically assess compensation levels for pay equity and where appropriate make adjustments to compensation. We often consult our employees to gauge how appropriate and acceptable our remuneration policies are and they recently deemed our remuneration policies competitive. For more information about the employee consultation process, refer to section 3.1.4. 'Our listening strategy'.
  • ### Summary of the Table: The table titled "13. Average remuneration by management group, gender, and age bracketª" presents data for the year 2024. It includes three main categories: **Gender**, **Management group**, and **Age bracket**, with corresponding subcategories and average remuneration values. 1. **Gender**: The average remuneration for **Women** is 41,822, for **Men** is 65,625, and the **Total** is 53,131. Categories **Other B** and **Not declared** are not included. 2. **Management group**: The average remuneration for **Senior executives** is 524,748, for **Other executives** is 129,847, for **Other employees** is 36,834, and the **Total** is 53,131. 3. **Age bracket**: The average remuneration for employees aged **<30** is 23,329, for those aged **30-50** is 53,353, for those aged **>50** is 88,044, and the **Total** is 53,131. The table uses categories requested by CSRD and excludes groups with fewer than 50 employees for statistical relevance.

It includes gross annual salary and comparable supplements, pension schemes and variable remuneration. 99% of Santander employees receive other salaries that supplement their salary. B. The categories requested by CSRD, by gender and age groups have been used. Groups with less than 50 employees (others, not declared) are not included because they are not statistically relevant and to avoid statistically erroneous conclusions. C. The average pay of our constant workforce (i.e. employees who were with us at 2023 year end and remained at 2024 year end) grew 11.4% in 2024 in constant euros (this does not include Argentina due to exchange rate distortions between the two periods). If we consider the current exchange rates (including Argentina) and the new hired employees, the average remuneration has had a net increase of 3.1% in comparison with the average for our workforce in 2023 (EUR 51,535).
  • All our businesses and subsidiaries have short-term variable remuneration schemes to reflect what we have accomplished and how, according to Group-wide quantitative and qualitative goals as well as individual and team goals, behaviour, leadership, sustainability, commitment, growth and risk management. These schemes promote meritocracy, recognize individual and team contributions, and promote employee growth and well-being. Aligned with sustainability goals, the variable compensation of executive directors also weighs compliance with our sustainability and climate goals38. In 2024, we paid EUR 14.3 billion in employee wages and benefits39. To comply with EU regulations on remuneration and manage risk correctly, we identified 1.246 employees subject to a deferred variable pay scheme because their decisions can have a material impact" on Santander's results. Therefore, the majority of them are subject to a policy of deferral of a significant portion of their
